Chapter Text

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt come.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat do you mean I can‚Äôt come?!‚Äù Izuku demands, snatching back the notebook he had just handed to Tomura.

‚ÄúI mean you can‚Äôt come. I‚Äôm going. You‚Äôre staying. It‚Äôs a simple concept, brat. Now give me the notes.‚Äù 

Shaking his head, Izuku clutches the book defensively to his chest. ‚ÄúMaybe I‚Äôll give you the notes when you give me one good reason I can‚Äôt come.‚Äù

‚ÄúSensei doesn‚Äôt want you to,‚Äù Tomura says simply, holding his hand out.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a bad reason!‚Äù

‚ÄúWell, bad is in the eye of the beholder or whatever.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not the saying and you know it.‚Äù

‚ÄúMaybe so. You know what I really want to know, though? Who the hell Eraserhead is. Notes - now.‚Äù

‚ÄúSay please.‚Äù

The minute narrowing of Tomura‚Äôs eyes is the only warning Izuku gets before the older boy lunges. Izuku yells, dropping to the ground to avoid Tomura‚Äôs grasping hands and curling up around the notebook. As it is, with all his limbs cocooned around the book, Tomura can‚Äôt get to it without dedicating himself to a pretty high degree of manhandling - and if he does that, he‚Äôll have no way of being certain that he won‚Äôt accidentally touch Izuku with all five fingers. Based on Tomura‚Äôs exaggeratedly long groan, he‚Äôs come to the same conclusion.

‚ÄúWhy do you want to go so bad, anyway?‚Äù he asks petulantly. 

‚ÄúLots of reasons,‚Äù Izuku responds, voice slightly muffled from where his knees are folded up by his mouth. ‚ÄúI want to see everyone in action, I want to analyze their quirks, I want to see if I can figure out how far my quirk awareness can stretch. Besides, it‚Äôs stupid to face a raid boss alone. I‚Äôm your player two.‚Äù

Tomura sighs. ‚ÄúSensei doesn‚Äôt want people knowing about you.‚Äù

Izuku hears Tomura sit down somewhere else in the room and uncurls from his ball, rolling to sit on the floor. He tucks the notebook under his butt, just in case Tomura is trying to lure him into a false sense of security.

‚ÄúNo one has to know I‚Äôm there,‚Äù Izuku says.

‚ÄúOh?‚Äù Tomura asks, sarcastic. ‚ÄúAnd how exactly are you going to escape the notice of the nearly two dozen people we will be attacking?‚Äù

‚ÄúI have a quirk for that. No one will notice me if I don‚Äôt call attention to myself.‚Äù

Wallflower is one of the first quirks Izuku stole, back before he got so many that it became impractical to keep naming them all. It‚Äôs one of his favorites - though he feels guilty for having favorites at all - and he frequently uses it to move around the bar without anyone noticing him when he‚Äôs not in the mood for conversation. 

Tomura hums. ‚ÄúIt would be nice to have you there,‚Äù he admits. ‚ÄúAnd hey, maybe you could steal a couple of quirks from those hero brats while we‚Äôre at it. That would serve them right.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Izuku says a touch too quickly, though Tomura doesn‚Äôt seem to notice. He continues, hurrying to cover his tracks, ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt want to call any attention back to Dad, and someone is bound to make the connection if quirks suddenly go missing.‚Äù 

‚ÄúToo bad,‚Äù Tomura reluctantly agrees. ‚ÄúAre you going to give me those notes, now?‚Äù

‚ÄúI can come?‚Äù

‚ÄúSure, why not. You weren‚Äôt part of the plan, but Sensei never actually said you couldn‚Äôt . But if he gets mad I‚Äôm throwing you under the bus.‚Äù Izuku jumps up, pumping his fist in victory. ‚ÄúJust stay on the downlow, okay? You‚Äôre our party‚Äôs rogue. Thievery, reconnaissance, and stealth - that‚Äôs you.‚Äù

Izuku scoops his notebook up off the floor, passing it over to Tomura who grimaces as he holds it between his hands.

‚ÄúWhy is it so warm?‚Äù Tomura asks, scrunching up his nose.

‚ÄúI was sitting on it.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd? Did you fart on it or something? Nasty.‚Äù

Izuku flusters. ‚ÄúNo! Jesus, you‚Äôre the nasty one, shut up!‚Äù 

As Tomura snickers, Izuku riffles through his pockets for some kind of projectile, coming up with only some pills of lint that just drift lazily to the ground when he tries to throw them. Izuku resorts to shoving his hands into Tomura‚Äôs face instead, but the older boy is undeterred, still laughing as he reaches for one of Izuku‚Äôs curls, tugging on it as he carefully wraps the tip around all five fingers. The hair turns to dust between his fingers that falls onto Izuku‚Äôs scalp like green dandruff. 

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre leaving tomorrow afternoon,‚Äù Tomura tells him. ‚ÄúMake sure you‚Äôre ready.‚Äù

Then he leaves, possibly to make preparations of his own, but more likely to shut himself in his room and play video games while fantasizing about All Might‚Äôs death. 

Alone, Izuku‚Äôs cheeks are still warm with embarrassment, but the bubble of joy and irritation that Tomura‚Äôs presence so often evokes has already popped. For a moment, it leaves him feeling small and deflated, but the empty space is quickly filled by a shame and self-loathing so large that it presses out against Izuku‚Äôs ribs until he thinks they might crack from the pressure. 

Tomorrow, Izuku will accompany Tomura to the USJ, and while it‚Äôs true that he‚Äôs Tomura‚Äôs player two, that‚Äôs not why he wants to be there. It‚Äôs not like he can tell Tomura the real reason he‚Äôs interested in going, not like he can explain his fascination with Erasure and his idle but all-consuming contemplation of what he might be able to use that quirk to do. Tomura would hate Izuku if he knew that Izuku was even thinking about -- what he is thinking about. So Izuku told a lie that was based in truth, one he knew Tomura would be happy to hear, and it had worked. 

Izuku doesn‚Äôt know what‚Äôs going to happen at the USJ. He doesn‚Äôt know what Tomura will do. Doesn‚Äôt know what All Might, the other pros, or the students will do. Even Izuku‚Äôs own actions, 24 hours from now, are a mystery to him. 

So, Izuku does what Tomura suggested. He sits at his desk - scribbling out thoughts and theoreticals, what-ifs and how-tos, ends and means - and he tries to make sure he‚Äôs ready for whatever it is he decides to do. 

 

 

Here is a modified trolley problem:

You and your father stand beside a set of train tracks. As it is, the train‚Äôs path is unobstructed, but there is a lever next to you that will divert it, leading it to kill hundreds of innocent and oblivious people. 

Your father wants you to pull the lever. If you don‚Äôt, he will either make you or he will do it himself. The only way to stop him is to push him in front of the train.

Do you push your father?

 

 

The next day, Izuku stands at Tomura‚Äôs right hand. To Tomura‚Äôs left is the nomu. It is a towering thing with vacant eyes and a beak-like maw filled with teeth like jagged bits of glass. Izuku can‚Äôt stand to look directly at it, but he can see it‚Äôs massive black form, perfectly still, out of the corner of his eye. The unnatural tangle of its quirks snares at Izuku‚Äôs mind. 

The crowd before them looks at the monster with mixed reactions of trepidation - which Izuku thinks is wise - and respect - which is beyond foolish. There‚Äôs more ‚Äúcannon fodder,‚Äù as Tomura described them, than Izuku expected. Izuku doesn‚Äôt know exactly where this meeting place is, since Kurogiri teleported him and Tomura directly in, but the room is large and completely empty apart from the bodies filling it. And they do fill it - not so much that people can‚Äôt easily move around, but enough that Izuku can‚Äôt get an easy head count on just how many villains All for One has recruited for this mission. 

The eyes of the group dart in turns between the nomu, Tomura, and Izuku himself. He hasn‚Äôt activated Wallflower yet, and it‚Äôs an odd feeling, having so many eyes on him like this. Even before coming to live with his father, Izuku had never particularly been the center of attention, and in the last five years he‚Äôs hardly interacted with anyone outside his father, Tomura, and Kurogiri. On the rare occasion that he left the bar, he kept a low profile, frequently with Wallflower‚Äôs assistance, and no one had paid him any mind. 

Once, standing in the middle of a crowd, with people flowing by him on all sides like he was a rock and they were a stream, Izuku had craved to be seen. 

Now, he is seen and wishes terribly to hide. 

But Tomura wants to make sure everyone notices Izuku. Afterall, the attack is likely to get very chaotic very quickly. The cannon fodder exists mostly to occupy the students while Tomura gets the job done, and it wouldn‚Äôt do for one of the NPCs - again, Tomura‚Äôs words - to mistake Izuku for one of the other twenty fifteen year olds, the targets, that were going to be there. 

Tomura himself is covered in the embrace of his severed hands. It‚Äôs nothing Izuku hasn‚Äôt seen before, but it never becomes any easier, watching Tomura‚Äôs face disappear behind a dead hand he calls ‚ÄúFather.‚Äù Like this, Tomura fits in with the swarm of villains gathered here, and Izuku can‚Äôt imagine him playing Animal Crossing with a blanket wrapped around his shoulders. 

This person is more Shigaraki than Tomura, a virtual stranger instead of practically a brother. It makes Izuku‚Äôs chest ache. 

 

 

Let‚Äôs elaborate on the trolley problem:

The scenario is the same, except now there is a third person standing with you and your father next to the tracks. He is not your brother, but also he is. 

Your brother would never push your father in front of the train. Your father, on the other hand, would push your brother in an instant. 

If you push your father, you save your brother as well as the hundreds of innocent people, but your brother will not see it that way. He will not thank you.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs time,‚Äù Tomura announces. Even his voice is different. Soft, not sweet. Perfectly composed, not genuinely calm. He completely lacks his normal animation, blank and indifferent. It's a facade, Izuku knows, but the behavior is no more comforting for its lack of sincerity.

‚ÄúTomura,‚Äù he says softly and the older boy turns. 

Wide red eyes meet Izuku‚Äôs through cracked fingers, pupils constricted into pinpoints. As calm as Tomura sounds - almost bored, really - Izuku knows he is seething. ‚ÄúWait,‚Äù Izuku tells him. ‚ÄúSee how the situation develops. Let the cannon fodder do their jobs.‚Äù The words are bitter on Izuku‚Äôs tongue, but, at least for the moment, Tomura stays by his side, not rushing in to kill anyone or get himself killed.

 

 

Let‚Äôs elaborate on the trolley problem:

If you push your father, your brother will inevitably push you. You have hurt so many people that you probably deserve it, so that is not the moral quandary here. Your brother has just pushed you in front of a train, so you are dead, but the hundreds of innocent people and your brother are safe.

Except now your brother is alone and he‚Äôs angry and your father has always told him that when he‚Äôs angry he should do something about it, but the only thing he's ever been taught to do is hurt people. He has probably never even heard of the trolley problem because your father wouldn‚Äôt have wanted him thinking about things like saving people or the value of life, and he will definitely pull any lever that he thinks your father would have wanted him to pull, even after your father is dead. And then, at some point, your brother will probably wander in front of the train himself, and you won‚Äôt be there to pull him back, so he‚Äôs not safe, either. 

Everyone will be dead.

As it is, the situation develops quickly. One of the people watching from above launches themself down the stairs.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs fast,‚Äù Tomura mutters, rubbing his neck but not digging his nails in. ‚ÄúRelies on speed and precision to take his targets out quickly.‚Äù He smirks as someone gets a blow in against the hero. ‚ÄúBad matchup against mutant type quirks, though. By Izuku‚Äôs side, Tomura has been growing more and more agitated. His tone is still mostly level when he speaks, contained, though his words tremble slightly and his voice occasionally cracks. In the distance, there is a commotion. Kurogiri has left the plaza to deal with Thirteen and the students, according to plan. Unconsciously, Izuku activates one of his many sensory enhancement quirks, the range of his sight increasing and his vision sharpening until he can see what is happening at the entrance. And he can see Katsuki, dressed in black and orange with one arm encased in a grenade-shaped gauntlet that Izuku can guess the purpose of. Izuku can see the way Katsuki moves in tandem with the red-haired boy next to him. Izuku can see the familiar incandescent rage and savage glee that followed him through so much of his childhood.

Now, Izuku has so many quirks from so many people that there‚Äôs no longer a single representative for everyone he has wronged, and the temporary appropriation of Katsuki‚Äôs quirk is among the most minor of Izuku‚Äôs crimes.

Izuku had nearly forgotten about Bakugou Katsuki. 

And now is not the time to remember. 

Izuku swallows, squeezing his eyes shut tight to shut off the enhanced vision, forcing himself to turn his back on the fight in the distance to focus again on the one happening next to him. The scene that greets him is different from what he expected. The space next to him is empty.

It‚Äôs the smile Tomura gets whenever he is about to hurt someone - sharp and bloodthirsty, with too many teeth and wild eyes. It‚Äôs the kind of smile that makes Izuku remember why he was so afraid of Tomura when they first met.

Truely, it‚Äôs a travesty to call it a smile, because this is not what happiness looks like, and Izuku hates that Tomura can‚Äôt tell the difference. Izuku would give anything to teach Tomura what a smile is meant to be. Would do anything to show him that the soft moments they spend together at the bar are far closer to fulfillment than the violence he is praised for. 

 

 

Let‚Äôs elaborate on the --

‚Ä¶ Wait. This stopped sounding like the trolley problem, at some point.

What are the trains supposed to be in this metaphor, again? They were meant to be the villains of the story, but then what‚Äôs the train that‚Äôs hitting your brother? A different villain? That doesn‚Äôt make sense. It‚Äôs gotten a bit tangled up.

Let‚Äôs try again:

Okay. The trains are the villains of the story. Then your father is a train. So are you and your brother. You are all‚Ä¶ sentient trains. 

No. This - this is already worse. 

Maybe the trolley problem has been stretched too far.

With Tomura‚Äôs often childish behavior, it can be easy to forget how intelligent he is. The more his anger builds, the more irrational he will get, throwing away plans in favor of pure destruction, but when he manages to keep a level head, Tomura is capable of being surprisingly analytical and strategic. He is good at picking apart weaknesses. Izuku wishes it weren‚Äôt so.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs hard to see when you keep moving around,‚Äù Tomura says as he charges forward, ‚Äúbut your hair floats when you use your quirk, and the moment it falls - that‚Äôs when you blink. You‚Äôre reaching your limit, aren‚Äôt you?‚Äù Izuku had pointed out the tell of Eraserhead‚Äôs quirk in his notes, along with dozens of other things, but the observation of the timing is Tomura‚Äôs own. Izuku wishes, not for the first time, that Tomura could be stupid, that his intelligence hadn‚Äôt been honed into a sword. 

On a level playing field, Eraserhead would certainly win any fight between him and Tomura, Izuku has no doubt. Izuku has trained with Tomura, and while the older boy doesn‚Äôt completely lack combat skills, he still relies far too much on the raw destructive power of his quirk. Without it, he is built for speed, lacks power, and is fairly frail. Easy to capture or incapacitate. Izuku would know - he‚Äôs done it. 

But the playing field is not level. Izuku had seen to that, tipping the odds in Tomura‚Äôs favor just enough for him to get past Eraserhead‚Äôs guard. Tomura dodges around the capture weapon the hero sends after him, grasping the scarf by the end and wrapping it around his hand. It serves as a tether, reeling them both in closer as they run at each other, Eraserhead‚Äôs hands fisted in his weapon, Tomura with a hand drawn back. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt push yourself, Eraserhead,‚Äù Tomura says into the space between them. His voice, delighted and mocking, makes Izuku reassess his relief.

Eraserhead‚Äôs hair falls.

Tomura‚Äôs obvious grasp went wide when Eraserhead ducked in close to him, but it was a feint all along. With muted horror, Izuku seeks out Tomura‚Äôs other hand, closed around Eraserhead‚Äôs elbow, having caught the blow. ‚ÄúBy the way, hero‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm not the final boss.‚Äù

‚ÄúTomura,‚Äù he chokes out.

‚ÄúNot now, rogue. I‚Äôm busy.‚Äù

Another crack, another thud, the ground trembles faintly beneath Izuku‚Äôs feet.

‚ÄúI put Thirteen out of action -‚Äù thank god ‚Äú-but there were students I was unable to disperse, and one of them was able to run away.‚Äù 

‚ÄúHuh? Kurogiri, you‚Ä¶‚Äù Izuku can hear Tomura‚Äôs building distress. On a normal day, Izuku would try to soothe him. But today is not a normal day. Today, there is blood all over the ground. Because of Tomura. Because of Izuku. He can smell it in the air.

‚ÄúBut first,‚Äù Tomura continues. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve come all this way. It would be a shame not to smash some of All Might‚Äôs pride as the Symbol of Peace before we go. Let‚Äôs leave some bodies for him to find.‚Äù

Izuku had withdrawn so far into himself that he had stopped paying attention. It was foolish of him, beyond foolish, but he stopped keeping track of people. Izuku‚Äôs eyes fly open. 

Time slows around him, stretching one moment into several, allowing Izuku to take in every detail of the situation between one breath and the next. Bullet time - that was what Izuku had named it. The very first quirk his father ever made him steal. 

Eraserhead is facedown on the ground with the nomu on his back. There is blood pooling around his head. Two students lurk nearby in shallow water, not yet having processed the words Tomura just spoke. Tomura has already turned towards them, body leaned forward in a lunge, arm halfway raised. 

No one is coming to save them. Those students cannot react quickly enough. Backup won‚Äôt arrive in the time it takes for Tomura to lay down all five of his fingers. 

Here is what is going to happen: 

Tomura is going to press his hand against one of the students‚Äô faces, likely the girl who seems to have some kind of frog quirk, before they even have time to realize what is happening. She will turn to dust between his fingers. Tomura will become a murderer and he will not even care. Izuku thinks of Eraserhead, who might die here. Of Erasure, that might die with him. He thinks of heroes and villains and how stories are written.

He thinks of Aizawa Shouta - the boy, not the hero - who looked so small in the sports festival‚Äôs large arena, who was unhappy with his lot in life and did something about it , who stood on the podium and smiled in victorious defiance. That boy wrote his own story. That boy made himself the hero. 

Izuku wants to be like that boy.

 

 

The trolley problem isn‚Äôt working anymore, so let‚Äôs simplify: 

There‚Äôs you, your father, and your brother, who are all varying degrees of guilty. Then there‚Äôs hundreds of innocent people.

Either the innocents die, or some combination of you, your father, and your brother do. 

Now let‚Äôs complicate:

Because this is not a theoretical. This is not a thought exercise. This is real life. Real people will die, and you will be the one to kill them. 

So. 




Who do you save?

Chapter Text

Shouta hasn‚Äôt wanted to be a hero since he was a child. 

As a civilian, it‚Äôs easy to want to be a hero, to see the appeal of saving people, to see the thrill and prestige and think it‚Äôs something that could be satisfying to devote a life to. But that‚Äôs not what it means to be a hero, not really. Only fools want to be heroes.

What it really means to be a hero is dealing with endless pain and suffering. 

The people a hero saves are in pain. They are often in the middle of the worst days of their lives, and while saving them may put a stop to that suffering, a hero still needs to witness it, first. There is an abundance of awful things in the world, and a hero - especially an underground one - through the course of their career, is likely to see them all. This burden, though, is made lighter by the virtue of being able to help . Pain paired with healing power. 

But even the people a hero saves others from are often in pain. It is easy to say that villains are evil and pretend that they were born that way, but in reality, while many people are called villains because of the things they chose to do, just as many are born from the things that are done to them. And a hero‚Äôs ability to help these people is limited, at best. In fact, the system often recommends that you hurt them more. Take them down by whatever means necessary, maybe give them some bruises, broken bones, or blood loss along the way. Lock them up, throw away the key. It's an inescapable part of the job, but there is no comfort in being the cause of someone‚Äôs pain.

Then, of course, there is the pain of the hero, themself. The stab wounds, the gunshots, the quirk injuries. Generally, that doesn‚Äôt even bear mentioning over the pain of others - that‚Äôs the way of heroes - but, nevertheless, the injuries accumulate quickly. Being a hero means fighting every day, and when someone fights that often, sometimes, inevitably, they lose. And when they lose, they either get hurt or they die. Or worse - other people die. 

That‚Äôs the greatest pain of all. The pain of the people the hero fails to save. The cases - the bodies - gone cold. The instances where no one gets there in time, either moments or days or years too late. The instances where no one gets there at all - where no one even realizes that anything is wrong, but somewhere someone is crying out for help that they will never receive, not even post mortem. The pain of those people who die alone and scared and the pain of those who outlive them.

Shouta was sixteen years old the first time he failed to save someone and his desire to be a hero died with them. After that, it wasn‚Äôt a want, but a need . He wasn‚Äôt stupid enough to crave the darkness and suffering that shadow a hero‚Äôs footsteps, but Shouta has never been able to watch bad things happen without doing something about them. 

Too many people believe that someone else will take care of the problems in the world and too few people actually do . Maybe someone else would help, but Shouta can , so he will , even if he has already seen enough pain to last a lifetime.

And so, every day, Shouta fights.

The USJ is not his first time losing. It is, perhaps, the most painful losing has ever been, though.

Yes, some of that is Shouta‚Äôs own, physical pain. The pain of flesh flayed away from bone with only a touch. The pain of both his arms being broken, one cleanly snapped and the other twisted into countless shards. The pain of the thing on top of him, compressing his lungs and forcing his body flat to unforgiving concrete. The pain of having his head smashed down so many times that only tenacity and grit are keeping him conscious. It is probably the most pain Shouta has ever been in.

But worse than all of that is the scalding inadequacy that comes with his failure to protect his students. They are who knows where, fighting who knows what. It‚Äôs Shouta‚Äôs job to prepare them for threats like this, but he hasn‚Äôt even had them for a week yet. They‚Äôre all still so new and small and soft, full of potential but also naivety. They all still want to be heroes.

Eventually, every hero hopeful needs to learn the hard lesson that sometimes the heroes lose, but Shouta didn‚Äôt want his first years to learn so soon and he didn‚Äôt want to be the one teaching them, not like this. Not broken and helpless while a maniac rubs Shouta‚Äôs weaknesses in his face.

‚ÄúTomura,‚Äù someone says. Shouta can‚Äôt see the speaker, but they sound like they are on the verge of panic, voice high and choked with tears. They sound young and afraid and it makes Shouta ache at his own uselessness. More pain, and it hurts all the more for not being his own, for being helpless when he is meant to be helping .

‚ÄúNot now, rogue,‚Äù Shouta‚Äôs assailant dismisses callously. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm busy.‚Äù Shouta struggles to raise his head as the man continues to mock him, but can only strain futilely against the beast‚Äôs hold. 

‚ÄúShigaraki Tomura,‚Äù the purple one says as he swirls back into being in the plaza.

‚ÄúKurogiri. Did you kill Thirteen?‚Äù Please, no.

‚ÄúI put Thirteen out of action -‚Äù not dead, then ‚Äú-but there were students I was unable to disperse, and one of them was able to run away.‚Äù It must have been Iida. Thank god he had the wisdom to run. With Thirteen incapacitated as well, their only hope would be backup from the school. Iida is their best chance at getting that before it‚Äôs too late. 

‚ÄúHuh?‚Äù Shigaraki Tomura asks, voice deadly with disgusted disbelief. ‚ÄúKurogiri, you‚Ä¶ If you weren‚Äôt a warp gate, I would have crushed you to pieces. Damn it. It‚Äôs game over. There‚Äôs no point in staying if they‚Äôre going to bring in reinforcements. We can‚Äôt win against dozens of pros. Man, it‚Äôs really game over. Let‚Äôs go home.‚Äù Shouta does not let himself hope. ‚ÄúBut first. We‚Äôve come all this way. It would be a shame not to smash some of All Might‚Äôs pride as the Symbol of Peace before we go. Let‚Äôs leave some bodies for him to find.‚Äù

Shouta did not let himself hope and so he is not disappointed. He is devastated, instead. What is he meant to do, pinned as he is, against a madman intent on shedding blood? 

Being a hero is all about tolerating pain. That‚Äôs the thing no one ever tells you. That‚Äôs why only a fool would actually want to be a hero, knowing what they are asking for. With his head pressed to cracked and crattered concrete, Shouta asks himself derisively: How much can he take before he breaks? How much can he break before he falls to pieces? He is already past his limit. Already broken, already shattered across the floor. 

But Shouta is a hero, not because he wants to be, but because he needs to be. He has felt pain and seen it and caused it - and he has not let it stop him, yet.

Which is why Shouta puts everything he has into raising his head, into locking bleary blood-filled eyes onto the blurry figure who has just launched himself towards the water, where two of Shouta‚Äôs students have found themselves. Activating his quirk makes Shouta‚Äôs entire head scream, like pieces of his skull are coming loose and stabbing into his brain - which, for all he knows, they are. Between the blood, the concussion he certainly has, and whatever other damage has no doubt been done to his face, Shouta can barely see, but it‚Äôs enough. When Shigaraki‚Äôs hand meets Asui‚Äôs face he makes an irritated noise, and while Shouta hears the girl stutter on a breath, she does not scream.

‚ÄúWhat do you think you‚Äôre doing, rogue?‚Äù Shigaraki asks. It‚Äôs only then that Shouta notices the fourth figure - his two students in the water, Shigarki in front of them, and a boy by his side. 

The boy is‚Ä¶ small. Definitely smaller than some of Shouta‚Äôs first years, though he can‚Äôt see clearly enough to get an accurate age estimate. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt kill her, Tomura,‚Äù the boy says, in the same choked, raspy voice from before. Is he crying? Shouta can‚Äôt see well enough to tell. 

‚ÄúPretty sure I can,‚Äù Shigaraki responds flatly, but he neither pulls away nor attempts to attack the boy beside him.

‚ÄúRemember why we‚Äôre here. We‚Äôre after All Might, not the NPCs. The more people you kill, the more this looks like senseless violence, especially if they‚Äôre children.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not opposed to senseless violence.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm aware. But this is a strategy game, Tomura, not a beat ‚Äòem up.‚Äù

There is a tense moment of silence and Shouta struggles to keep his eyes open, struggles to even stay conscious. Somewhere, there is a crash, but Shouta couldn‚Äôt tell you how far away it was or what direction it came from because the blood rushing through his ears makes everything sound distorted. 

He has fought until he was broken, kept fighting until he fell to pieces, and then he picked those pieces up and weaponized them, like using shards of glass as improvised knives. He has reached his limit twice over. His limbs are heavier than the thing sitting on top of him, pain bleeds out of his edges like running ink, and rainbow static dances in all the fuzzy places in his vision. 

Shouta blinks.

His eyes do not open again.

 

 

Izuku closes his fingers around Tomura‚Äôs wrist a fraction of a second before he can lay his hand across the frog-quirked girl‚Äôs face. Izuku‚Äôs hand eclipses the scar he left on Tomura the day they met, a small handprint that perfectly pairs with the larger one on Izuku‚Äôs own wrist. Izuku fears that Tomura won‚Äôt stop at just a touch, but the older boy freezes as if restrained, despite how gentle Izuku‚Äôs grip is. Tomura turns to face him slowly, and Izuku refuses to cower from the flames of anger in Tomura‚Äôs eyes. 

‚ÄúWhat do you think you‚Äôre doing, rogue?‚Äù 

Saving us all, Izuku thinks.

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt kill her, Tomura,‚Äù Izuku says instead, doing his best to sound confident and authoritative despite how near he was to a panic attack just seconds ago. His voice is raspy and his cheeks are still wet, but his tone is steady and he is no longer crying. 

‚ÄúPretty sure I can,‚Äù Tomura responds, but for the moment, he is still listening, not resisting Izuku‚Äôs hold. 

‚ÄúRemember why we‚Äôre here,‚Äù Izuku tries to reason. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre after All Might, not the NPCs. The more people you kill, the more this looks like senseless violence, especially if they‚Äôre children.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not opposed to senseless violence.‚Äù Izuku cringes internally, but matches Tomura‚Äôs impatient look with a level one. 

Izuku swallows. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm aware. But this is a strategy game, Tomura, not a beat ‚Äòem up.‚Äù

Tomura‚Äôs eyes narrow. Izuku knows things could still go either way. He can reason with Tomura, some of the time, but never control him, and at the end of the day, Tomura will do what Tomura thinks is best. 

Izuku considers taking Decay, forcing Tomura to do things the peaceful way by depriving him of his means of violence, but it is unlikely that Tomura would let him. After years of the quirk going back and forth, Tomura has learned to identify the subtle feeling associated with Izuku attracting the quirk away, and now, unless Izuku catches him completely off guard, Tomura can tug back , resulting in a battle of wills that they don‚Äôt have time for in the middle of a literal battle. Izuku would be reluctant to leave Tomura without a means of defense, besides. 

So Izuku and Tomura stand in an uneasy silence while Tomura makes up his mind, Izuku hoping that he can manifest his desired outcome if he stays calm and rational enough. Whichever way Tomura was leaning, Izuku never gets to find out. 

The doors to the USJ blow open, dust billowing around them as they go flying and crash to the ground a short distance away. Attention torn away from the stray students, Tomura spins, dragging Izuku with him until they are both facing the entrance. Slowly, All Might emerges from the cloud of swirling dust, his figure large and distinct even from such a distance. 

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fine now!‚Äù he calls, voice booming across the whole of the training arena. ‚ÄúI am here!‚Äù His face, Izuku can see, is set in grim lines, nothing like the smiling action figures that lined Izuku‚Äôs shelves when he was a child. 

‚ÄúFinally,‚Äù Tomura says. Izuku doesn‚Äôt turn to look at him, eyes fixed on All Might, but he can hear the deranged grin in the words. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve kept me waiting, hero. You trash of society.‚Äù

Izuku did not expect this. You‚Äôre right , Izuku thinks as Tomura scoffs at his side. He can‚Äôt . 

But if All Might doesn‚Äôt die here today, they will be back another day. And if Tomura or Kurogiri or Izuku himself die here, then someone else will come. They will keep coming, over and over, until the job is done. Because they are just pawns on a chessboard, and losing them means little to the man playing the game. 

All for One is always thinking at least ten moves ahead, afterall.

But Izuku - he‚Äôs not actually a pawn, is he? He‚Äôs not even meant to be a piece on the board.

He tells himself that he‚Äôll give it back when he‚Äôs done with it. He refuses to think, for the moment, about what being done with it will mean. 

 

 

Katsuki knew the villains were idiots - they had to be, breaking into UA, of all places, thinking they could kill All Might, of all people - but based on how laughably easy it is to take out the scrubs between the collapse zone and the central plaza, they‚Äôre not only stupid, but fucking incompetent to boot. The attitude grates at Katsuki‚Äôs nerves, all casual and disinterested, like he‚Äôs fucking above them all even though he‚Äôs getting his ass handed to him. ‚ÄúNomu.‚Äù

The thing, still half frozen and stuck through a warp gate, shudders. Only a moment later, the creeping suspicion is confirmed. The monster‚Äôs raw flesh writhes and bubbles outward, swelling and then bursting with a terrible wet noise that turns Katsuki‚Äôs stomach. Katsuki barely has time to contemplate the implication that this thing has more than one fucking quirk - how is that even possible? What kind of freak of nature are they actually dealing with here? A small corner of Katsuki‚Äôs mind, dark and well ignored, grows larger and the thoughts he closes up there leak like a gas into the rest of his mind, faint and intangible, but deadly all the same. Vulnerable and helpless - so, so helpless. Useless and worthless and not even himself, anymore.

He hears Handjob say, ‚ÄúNow, let‚Äôs get our gate back,‚Äù but it seems inconsequential next to the idea of somehow having more than one fucking quirk.

He lands, half sitting half sprawled, next to Shitty Hair and Freezerburn, neither of whom notice him. Katsuki stares as well, entirely unsure about what just occurred. ‚ÄúOh my god, Tomura!‚Äù someone screams, puncturing the moment of silence that had otherwise only been broken by the soft click and clatter of bits of debris from the wall falling against each other. 

Katsuki wonders if maybe he just died. If that monstrous thing slammed into him so hard and fast he didn‚Äôt even get to feel it, if he‚Äôs pulverized into mincemeat somewhere beyond that veil of dust. 

He must be dead, because he‚Äôs looking at a fucking ghost. 

Green hair and green eyes. Too many freckles on too-round cheeks. Trembling lower lip and pathetically beguiling expression. Pitiful and on the brink of tears. 

‚ÄúWhat did you do?!‚Äù Midoriya Izuku demands, clinging to the arm of the villain covered in disembodied hands, clutching at his sleeve and shaking him. 

Or that is what Izuku would be doing, would be demanding, if he were actually here. But he‚Äôs not, because he can‚Äôt be. Katsuki can‚Äôt wrap his head around it. Whatever is happening, Katsuki knows he is angry - or perhaps he has transcended simple anger and jumped into catastrophic outrage - but that is all he understands. Except, in a way, it kind of does, doesn‚Äôt it? Katsuki had been so glad when Deku had been removed from his life, but Katsuki had always been the only one keeping Deku in check, the only one who knew what the other boy was capable of and kept him in his place. Without Katsuki around, who reminded Deku what he really was, huh? Nobody, apparently. 

Because here Deku is, right where Katsuki never expected to see him but always knew he would end up. 

A villain.

‚ÄúWhat did you do?!‚Äù the brat practically shrieks, shaking at Tomura‚Äôs arm with enough force to make him sway slightly back and forth. 

‚ÄúI got our gate back,‚Äù Tomura replies, stating the obvious.

Tomura hasn‚Äôt been blind to Izuku‚Äôs heightening emotional state through the course of the attack, and he shouldn‚Äôt be surprised that it‚Äôs culminating in this kind of breakdown. Tomura scans their surroundings, trying to quickly evaluate the situation. It won‚Äôt do for them to be attacked while Izuku is in the middle of a breakdown. ‚ÄúDeku,‚Äù Blasty growls, low and threatening, more sinister than the feral and violent glee he showed earlier when he had Kurogiri at his mercy. 

Alarms go off in Tomura‚Äôs head, but Izuku ‚Äì whose sense of self-preservation has always been inconsistent, at best ‚Äì doesn‚Äôt seem to notice, attempting to duck out from behind Tomura and into the open. ‚ÄúKacchan!‚Äù Izuku calls. His voice is thick with tears and relief, both of which prick like pins along Tomura‚Äôs skin. ‚ÄúYou dodged!‚Äù

‚ÄúShut up, scum.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe attack did not go according to plan. The nomu you sent with us was defeated. Backup, retrieved by a wayward student, arrived just moments after the young master ordered a retreat. Unfortunately, the single instant of overlap was long enough for one of the heroes to fire a shot.‚Äù

Hisashi interrupts what is quickly becoming the beginnings of a rant. ‚ÄúSit down, Tomura.‚Äù With a bitten back scoff, Tomura does.

Hisashi turns his attention back to his son. Izuku ‚Äì wan on the floor, eyes clenched shut, hissing shaking and uneven breaths between his teeth ‚Äì is holding himself together remarkably well, all things considered. In the grand scheme of things, the injury is not too severe. Nothing of importance was hit and the bullet carved a clean path through and through. With the resources at their disposal, Izuku is in absolutely no danger. 

But that doesn‚Äôt make the injury hurt any less. Before now, the worst Izuku has ever been harmed was likely the sludge villain attack when he was ten. Even that incident resulted in mostly superficial physical damage, the majority of the trauma being mental and emotional. This is certainly the most pain Izuku has ever been in.

As Hisashi cards a hand through the sweat-damp hair at the nape of Izuku‚Äôs neck, he hopes this is the most pain his son will ever be in. He hopes, but he knows that it‚Äôs likely an empty sentiment, especially if Izuku‚Äôs life ends up looking anything like Hisashi‚Äôs own. ‚ÄúYou have a quirk for this, yes?‚Äù Hisashi asks. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm fairly certain I brought you one, at some point.‚Äù 

Izuku nods. ‚ÄúB-but it-it‚Äôll p-put-put me to sle-sl-sleep.‚Äù

‚ÄúPerhaps that‚Äôs for the best. You‚Äôre safe here. You can rest now. Activate the quirk and allow yourself to heal.‚Äù 

Izuku‚Äôs eyes are bright and glassy with pain but intent as he stares up at Hisashi. Hisashi worries for a moment that Izuku will refuse, as unreasonably stubborn as he can sometimes be, but then his eyes dim and flutter shut. The diagnostic quirk pings the additional fatigue. Combined with the exhaustion from the attack on the USJ, it‚Äôs likely that healing the injury will leave Izuku unconscious for several hours, at the least. 

‚ÄúKurogiri, get him cleaned up and put away in his room, would you? Bandage him up, too. He should heal on his own without any difficulty, but it wouldn‚Äôt do for him to bleed all over his things.‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course, Sir.‚Äù Nodding, Kurogiri opens a portal beneath Izuku, dropping him gently in some other location, before disappearing himself to do as Hisashi bade.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going to let them get away with this,‚Äù Tomura says lowly once they are alone. He is seated obediently, but the fury in his eyes has not been tempered.

‚ÄúNor will I. They sealed their fates the moment they touched him. I don‚Äôt take kindly to threats to me or mine, Tomura. You know this.‚Äù

‚ÄúThen why didn‚Äôt you let me go back? I‚Äôd make them pay, you know I would, it‚Äôs what you‚Äôve been training me for‚Äì‚Äù

‚ÄúAn unknown number of professional heroes had arrived on the scene, my nomu was apparently defeated, you no longer had the element of surprise. Would you like me to list more flaws in your plan, or is that enough?‚Äù Tomura scowls, agitation clear as he scratches at his neck, but does not respond. ‚ÄúYou already failed once. Are you really so eager to run in and fail a second time?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe shouldn‚Äôt have failed at all,‚Äù Tomura spits. ‚ÄúAll Might was supposed to be weak. You said Nomu would be able to take him.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd on a different day, perhaps it would have. No plan is perfect. You account for what you can and make up for the rest with luck and skill. Today, you were neither lucky nor skilled. You underestimated them and failed as a result. And on the topic: where is my nomu?‚Äù Hisashi can see the muscles of Tomura‚Äôs jaw twitch as the boy grinds his teeth. 

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know. Gone. All Might blasted him away with one of those ridiculous overpowered smashes of his. Kurogiri might be able to locate him, but‚Äì‚Äù

‚ÄúWith your brother injured, Kurogiri has more important things to occupy his time. We‚Äôll write it off as another loss, then. A shame, given all the time and effort that went into creating it, but I suppose it can‚Äôt be helped.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe were close,‚Äù Tomura says at a whisper. ‚ÄúSo close. Nomu almost had him.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the saying again? Right. Close only counts in horseshoes and hand grenades.‚Äù

Curiously, Tomura doesn‚Äôt shrink from the scorn like he normally would. ‚ÄúHand grenades,‚Äù he says instead, barking a hoarse laugh. ‚ÄúThere were some close calls with those, too. Have you ever considered doing something about Bakugou Katsuki?‚Äù

Bakugou. There‚Äôs a name that Hisashi hasn‚Äôt heard for a while. When Izuku first moved in, he mentioned the family occasionally, but never with enough frequency for them to have occupied any space in Hisashi‚Äôs mind. 

‚ÄúIzuku‚Äôs friend from school? I can‚Äôt say I‚Äôve considered him at all.‚Äù

Tomura laughs again. ‚ÄúOh, they were never friends. I might have been able to kill All Might myself if the brat hadn‚Äôt gotten in the way. He‚Äôs a horrible kid, the absolute worst kind, and he‚Äôs got all that nastiness fixated on our little Izu.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt try to blame your own shortcomings on others, Tomura. The obstacles you faced do not justify your failure, especially if those obstacles came in the form of a fifteen-year-old boy with a week of heroics training under his belt.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not what I‚Äì‚Äù

‚ÄúLearn from this. If you don‚Äôt want this whole exercise to have been entirely futile, figure out where you went wrong and ensure you don‚Äôt make the same mistakes in the future. Next time no number of professional heroes or children will be able to stop you. Next time, Tomura, you will show the world you are meant to be feared. You will become exactly the symbol we need. Do you understand?‚Äù

Tomura stares, eyes steely, jaw grinding back and forth, nails digging into his neck. Then, he nods. 

‚ÄúYes, Sensei.‚Äù

‚ÄúGood. Now, it‚Äôs time to start making a new plan. Consider gathering a team, elite people whose strength can become your strength. You‚Äôve come far on your own, but no one can do everything alone. Even I have you, after all. 

‚ÄúTake all the time you need. It‚Äôs better to wait and secure your chances of success than rush ahead and make a fool of yourself ‚Äì let this incident at the USJ pay testament to that. We‚Äôre in no rush.‚Äù 

Today, tomorrow ‚Äì it made little difference, in the end. Hisashi has been moving these pieces around for decades, carefully nudging them into place millimeter by painstaking millimeter. Sometimes you have to run before you can walk. Sometimes you have to fail before you succeed. Hisashi has weathered it all before. He‚Äôs sure he‚Äôll see it all again. 

Time, as curious and mercurial as it can be, is something he has in abundance, after all.

Chapter Text

The most infuriating thing Katsuki has ever been made to do is sit aimlessly in a classroom immediately after a direct villain attack, told to be patient as the police methodically question each and every one of his classmates before allowing them all to go home. And sure, maybe it‚Äôs important that the police and the heroes know what happened, but with all the adrenaline and anger and fear still coursing through his veins, Katsuki isn‚Äôt exactly thrilled to be told to sit still and wait.

‚ÄúBakugou, are you sure you don‚Äôt want to go to Recovery Girl?‚Äù Shitty Hair asks for at least the third time, mouth twisted up with something close enough to pity that it sends Katsuki‚Äôs hackles rising.

‚ÄúFor the last goddamned time,‚Äù he snaps, most likely not for the last time, given how persistent the extras in his class can be, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm fucking fine.‚Äù His voice scrapes out of his throat rough and broken, as if to prove him wrong, but Katsuki swallows as if it doesn‚Äôt hurt, and ignores the way Shitty Hair cringes in sympathy.

He‚Äôs just fucking fine, for the information of all the people who won‚Äôt stop fucking asking. He‚Äôs not an invalid.

Besides, he was never in any real danger. He had the situation handled. And he definitely didn‚Äôt need goddamned Deku, of all people, to protect him.

Katsuki breaths out hard through his nose and then stifles a cough as the air scrapes at the tender insides of his windpipe. He was meant to be in the US, far far away from Katsuki, causing problems for someone else. He was never supposed to come back. But no, of course not. Katsuki had finally gotten into UA and things couldn‚Äôt just go nice and easy like they were supposed to. Shitty Hair is the next to go in for questioning and thank god for that. Without the persistent thorn in his side, Katsuki can shove his earbuds in and focus on breathing as well as he can, like his mother always insists. In through the nose ‚Äì one, two, three, four; hold for seven; out through the mouth ‚Äì one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight.

Katsuki hates the shitty breathing exercises. Mostly because they work, and the old hag is always smug about it. ‚ÄúJust breathe, brat,‚Äù she says, like that‚Äôll fix all his problems. Anger rises in him again, but this is the well-worn and familiar kind, which fits in his body as well as his bones do ‚Äì the kind that makes him want to slam the door to his room into the wall, as opposed to wanting to slam his fist into some dumbass‚Äô face.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm Detective Tsukauchi,‚Äù the man says after he leads Katsuki to a separate room. ‚ÄúDo you mind if I record this?‚Äù

‚ÄúGo ahead.‚Äù

‚ÄúBakugou Katsuki.‚Äù

‚ÄúSame time everyone else did. Portal opened up in the middle of the place and they all came pouring in. If there was any doubt the bastards weren‚Äôt supposed to be there, Hobo-Sensei cleared it up pretty fast.‚Äù The detective blinks a few times, silent for a moment as Katsuki crosses his arms over his chest and slumps further into his chair.

‚ÄúDo you mean Aizawa?‚Äù

‚ÄúObviously.‚Äù

‚ÄúRight. Can you tell me what happened next?‚Äù

‚ÄúThat warp gate asshole showed up, gave a little speech and scattered us.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe individual with the teleportation quirk ‚Äì did you catch his name?‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt fucking know!‚Äù Katsuki bark, already fed up with the unimportant details. ‚ÄúProbably some stupid shit.‚Äù

‚ÄúMoving on, then. Where did you end up after you were warped?‚Äù

‚ÄúCollapse zone.‚Äù

‚ÄúWere you alone?‚Äù

‚ÄúI fucking wish. Shitty Hair was dropped in with me.‚Äù The detective pauses again, blinking like he has something in his eyes, looking like an absolute dumbass.

‚Äú‚ÄòShitty Hair?‚Äô Are you referring to Kirishima Eijiro?‚Äù

‚ÄúDoes he have shitty fucking hair?‚Äù More blinks from Detective Dumbass. ‚ÄúObnoxious shade of red?‚Äù Katsuki prompts. ‚ÄúSpiky, but not in a cool way?‚Äù He makes a gesture to indicate horn-like spikes over his forehead.

‚Äú‚Ä¶That‚Äôs Kirishima. Did you encounter anyone else in the collapse zone?‚Äù

‚ÄúA handful of no-name villains tried to get the jump on us, but I took care of them without any trouble.‚Äù

The questioning continues along a similar vein, dissecting every small move Katsuki made between the collapse zone and the plaza, grilling him for details on the battle he witnessed and the villains he encountered. Katsuki answers the questions almost reflexively, throwing forward information as the detective requests it, even if Katsuki doesn‚Äôt understand what half the questions are good for. Katsuki‚Äôs whole body grows hot and rigid. He opens his mouth to spit out a vicious answer, but the sharp edges of the words tear at his throat and send him into a coughing fit. Detective Dumbass pushes a glass of water across the table and Katsuki snatches it with a glare.

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù he rasps after draining half the glass. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a fucking villain, just like the rest of them.‚Äù

‚ÄúHave you encountered him somewhere before the attack today?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe went to school together or whatever. When we were younger.‚Äù

‚ÄúIs ‚ÄòDeku‚Äô his legal name?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs his quirk?‚Äù

When Katsuki was four years old, he had made a promise to a woman who was almost like a second mother to him. Her son had come into a very dangerous quirk that he had used against Katsuki, but Katsuki‚Äôs Aunt had sat him down and made him promise that he would never tell anyone. But there‚Äôs no point to the secret, anymore. Deku is on the villains‚Äô side, now. Keeping the nature of his quirk quiet will only put people in danger if the thief is out there using it.

‚ÄúListen,‚Äù Katsuki says, leaning over the table to get closer and keeping his voice quiet and serious. ‚ÄúI know it looks like that handsy guy was the one in charge, but he‚Äôs not the one you‚Äôve gotta worry about. ‚ÄúSteal quirks? Can you elaborate on that?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs exactly what I fucking said. He takes quirks. Then he can use them, and you can‚Äôt.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, well he‚Äôs obviously not in the goddamned registry, dumbass,‚Äù Katsuki snaps. ‚ÄúWould you register a quirk like that? His papers say he‚Äôs fucking Quirkless, but that‚Äôs a lie. He stole my quirk when we were four fucking years old and I barely got it back, so I know what I‚Äôm talking about when it comes to that bastard.‚Äù

This time, when the detective taps on the table, the sound is like a nail being driven into the lid of a coffin.

 

 

Every spike on the heart monitor drives into Shouta‚Äôs head, twisting through one ear to the other in a jagged pulse of throbbing pain, like someone is winding a corkscrew through his brain. He hurts all over, but he refuses to let them raise the dosage on his pain relievers. It‚Äôs bad enough that he needs to be drugged up at all ‚Äì he absolutely refuses to become insensible with it.

‚ÄúHow is being delirious with pain better than being loopy on morphine?‚Äù Hizashi asks, voice even worse than the mechanical beeping that fills the room, even as he does his best to keep it low and soft.

‚ÄúMorphine makes me stupid,‚Äù Shouta grunts in response. His own words ricochet around his head like particularly vicious pinballs.

‚ÄúWell, you seem pretty stupid to me, already.‚Äù Shouta does not justify this with a response.

Shouta‚Äôs eyes ‚Äì along with the rest of his head and both his arms ‚Äì are heavily bandaged, but the lack of sight does nothing to prevent him from noticing as the doctor enters the room. Even the small noises of the door opening and the doctor walking in lick along his sense like fire.

‚ÄúEraserhead,‚Äù the doctor greets, voice considerately soft at barely a whisper but no more bearable for the effort. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs good to see you awake.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the verdict?‚Äù he asks. Hizashi has filled him in on the most important bits ‚Äì namely that Shouta is absolutely fucked up, so much so that the other teachers briefly feared he was dead when they arrived at the USJ ‚Äì but Shouta suspects he‚Äôs lacking some of the finer details.

Her stern tone leaves no doubt that she has dealt with more than her fair share of difficult hero patients ‚Äì the kind who never put the proper effort into their recovery because of their hurry to be back in the field, and then wonder why their field performance is declining. Shouta can‚Äôt say he blames them, understanding the need for action and the hatred for the monotonous and exhausting routine of physical therapy. ‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt recommend it.‚Äù

The doctor sighs. ‚ÄúNo. But exposing your eyes at this point will hurt, I can guarantee you that.‚Äù If Shouta could smile beneath all the bandages and whatever is holding his face together, he would.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs fine,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a pro hero. We‚Äôre accustomed to pain.‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know,‚Äù Izuku forces himself to admit, pushing the words out of numb lips.

‚Äú‚Ä¶Yeah.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äì‚Äù Tomura cuts himself off with a growl, lips curling away from his teeth as his whole expression twitches.

Izuku makes no attempts to stop him. It is rare that Tomura gets upset enough to remove himself from a situation, but on the occasion that he does, it is certainly safer to simply allow him to leave, as much as it may hurt to watch him go.

Sometimes, it seems like every choice Izuku makes ends up being a bad one ‚Äì even ones that seem arbitrary at the time, like taking Tomura‚Äôs so-called ‚ÄúFather.‚Äù Whenever he does anything, people seem to wind up hurt. He‚Äôs tried a million things to circumvent it, but nothing ever works for more than a moment, and then he is back to hurting people again, just like always.

And yet.

His insides are already clenching with guilt just because of the hand. He knows how important the macabre accessories are to Tomura, ‚ÄúFather‚Äù especially, and no matter how much it disturbed Izuku personally, he never intended to lose it.

If he feels like this after accidentally losing something important to Tomura, how is Izuku ever meant to intentionally destroy his brother‚Äôs entire world?

Sometimes, it seems like every choice Izuku makes is wrong. It‚Äôs like he‚Äôs built for regret, no matter what he does.

Late at night, guilt covered by the dark, he sometimes wonders if maybe it‚Äôs not the choices he makes, but the choices he has.

Now is a perfect example, isn‚Äôt it? There are two options in front of him, and Izuku isn‚Äôt sure either of them are good. A certainty churns in Izuku‚Äôs chest, dreadful and inevitable, that he is going to regret whatever it is he does next. The feeling is heavy and unbalancing, threatening to tip him over at any moment. Izuku almost wants to let it. He wants to lie down and let it crush him, or better yet, sleep forever so it can never catch him.

But he only has two choices, and that is not one of them.

He can keep going as he has been. He will hurt more people and every day he will hate himself more. Day by day and week by week, he will feel colder and colder inside, until his bones become brittle with frost, and he shatters into a million pieces.

Or Izuku will kill his father. And that will likely shatter him anyway.

He can keep going as he has been, and so will Tomura. They will both keep going, and maybe the way they have been isn‚Äôt a good way to be, but they will be together.

Or Izuku will kill his father.

And then Tomura will probably kill him.

It hurts to even think about because Izuku knows just how upset Tomura would be, just how betrayed he would feel, and Tomura is the last person Izuku ever wants to hurt. But without All for One, Tomura would have a chance. Izuku isn‚Äôt sure for what, exactly. A chance to make something of himself, maybe. A chance for Tomura to finally make something of himself, instead of simply being what All for One has made him to be.

Izuku has a day and a half to decide.

Tomorrow, he and All for One are supposed to visit the warehouse, and that will be Izuku‚Äôs best and only chance to do the job, if he so chooses. He can‚Äôt afford to wait any longer. As far as he knows, Eraserhead is still alive, and while Izuku is wholeheartedly grateful for that, it also means that it‚Äôs only a matter of time until the man realizes he can no longer use his quirk. The hero may not realize exactly what that means, but the information would undoubtedly make its way to All for One‚Äôs ears, and he would make the connection in an instant and then take the proper precautions to ensure that Izuku‚Äôs new quirk couldn‚Äôt be used against him, just like he has with all the ones he has already had Izuku take.

All this conflict, all this struggle, and he can‚Äôt even be sure that it will work. He‚Äôs still operating on the largely unsupported assumptions that Erasure is capable of erasing multiple quirks and that Izuku‚Äôs father cannot survive even a brief period without the many quirks he has collected to extend his life and compensate for his injury.

And then there is the even bigger assumption that Izuku is even capable of doing what he is asking himself to do.

He lies back in his bed, pressing the heels of his palms into his eyes until he sees burst of bright colors behind his closed lids.

He is writing his own story, now.

It is far harder than Aizawa Shouta made it look.

 

 

The solemn air that fell over class 1-A is gone two days later when classes resume. Katsuki‚Äôs classmates can‚Äôt stop gushing about the news coverage and how amazing All Might was, and the extras in the other courses keep shooting the class side-long glances, like they think they‚Äôre being discrete, whispering behind their hands as if that does a damned thing to stop their words from leaking into the air around them.

With a livid halo of blue and purple circling his throat, Katsuki is stared at most of all. Everyone is all wide-eyed, a mix of morbid curiosity, awe, and fear written clearly across their faces because they don‚Äôt know how to mind their own fucking business or even hide their goddamned nosiness.

Everyone acts like something special happened. Sure, the villains got into UA, and that was admittedly pretty fucking unheard of, but as for class 1-A‚Äôs role in all that? They fought the villains off ‚Äì or at least, some of them did, while others were entirely useless ‚Äì but they are training to be heroes, and that‚Äôs what heroes do. There‚Äôs nothing impressive about doing what you‚Äôre meant to.

Which is also why Katsuki isn‚Äôt screaming about how he‚Äôs going to put his all into the sports festival. But, Katsuki supposes as Round Face lets out another intense cheer, at least the extras are too occupied with that whole business to keep bothering him. Shitty Hair especially has been up his ass all day, concerned about his health or whatever other pussy bullshit and, worst of all, asking persistent questions about Deku, whose existence Katsuki would much rather go back to ignoring.

At the end of the day, when Round Face slides the classroom doors open so they can all make their way home, Katsuki is one of the only people not surprised at the crowd waiting for them, packed in tight to the hallway.

‚ÄúWhat business do you have with class A?‚Äù Glasses asks too loudly and with too much emphasis, chopping robotically at the air while Round Face stutters in surprise.

‚ÄúScouting out the enemy, Robo Nerd.‚Äù Said nerd gapes in offense, jaw moving just as mechanically as the rest of him as he wordlessly works his mouth open and closed. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre the ones who made it out of the villains‚Äô attack. ‚ÄúStop calling people ‚Äòextras‚Äô just because you don‚Äôt know them!‚Äù Glasses scolds. Katsuki considers it, then summarily discards the suggestion. Besides, a decent number of people actually shuffled to the side at Katsuki‚Äôs command, so Glasses can hardly say Katsuki‚Äôs wrong when they‚Äôre actually responding to the address.

One person takes advantage of the new gaps in the crowd, weaving through the spaces without hardly touching anyone at all. He‚Äôs tall ‚Äì taller than Katsuki, but Katsuki‚Äôs not so delicate that shit like that hurts his ego ‚Äì with purple hair that sticks straight out in a mess of waves, bag under his eyes large enough that he‚Äôd have to pay extra to take them on a plane.

‚ÄúI came to see what class A was like, but you seem pretty arrogant,‚Äù he says, voice droll and lacking any hint of the nervousness that Katsuki spotted in the eyes of so many of the extras in the crowd. ‚ÄúAre all students in the hero course like this?‚Äù

‚ÄúHah?‚Äù Katsuki asks, curling his lip into a sneer. Zombie Eyes ‚Äì who didn‚Äôt bother to introduce himself, not that Katsuki cares about his name or would have remembered it in the first place ‚Äì rubs at the back of his neck and glances to the side with an unintimidated sigh.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm a little disillusioned. There‚Äôre quite a few people who enrolled in general education or the other courses because they didn‚Äôt make it into the hero course. Did you know that?‚Äù Katsuki neither knew nor cared. The problems of some second-rate losers who couldn‚Äôt make the cut weren‚Äôt something he cared to bother himself with, but Zombie Eyes keeps going.

‚ÄúBut the entrance exam isn‚Äôt our only chance, you know? Depending on the result of the sports festival, a student can be transferred between courses. A gen-ed student can become a hero student. A hero student can become a gen-ed one.

‚Äú‚ÄòScouting out the enemy?‚Äô Personally, I just came here to say that, if you‚Äôre not careful, I‚Äôll sweep your feet right out from under you, hero course or not. I came with a declaration of war.‚Äù

Dark eyes with pale pupils lock onto Katsuki‚Äôs in undisguised challenge. Katsuki rises to it, staring back with his eyes slightly narrowed, mouth set in a grim line that does nothing to phase Zombie Eyes‚Äô impassive air. The guy has guts, Katsuki will give him that. It‚Äôs almost disappointing that he fell into general education, meaning he most likely lacks the skill or power to prove good on his words. Otherwise, it would almost be the kind of declaration Katsuki could respect.

‚ÄúHey, hey!‚Äù some moron yells, popping out from the back of the crowd. Katsuki only half turns his attention to the newcomer, then half quickly dwindles to nothing as he stares blankly towards the commotion.

‚ÄúYou ignorin‚Äô me, bastard?!‚Äù the extra shouts as Katsuki turns to walk away. Katsuki doesn‚Äôt dignify the question with a response, since that would kind of defeat the purpose of ‚Äì you know ‚Äì fucking ignoring the guy.

‚ÄúWait a minute, Bakugou!‚Äù Shitty Hair shouts, dashing to Katsuki‚Äôs side and flailing an arm in a wide gesture to the crowd. ‚ÄúWhat are you gonna do about all this? Come on dude, it‚Äôs your fault everyone‚Äôs hating on us!‚Äù

‚ÄúDoesn‚Äôt matter,‚Äù Katsuki grunts in response.

‚ÄúHuh?!‚Äù

‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt matter as long as you rise to the top.‚Äù

The spiky bastard, rendered speechless by ‚Äúmanliness‚Äù or some shit, finally lets Katsuki pass and the crowd parts to allow him through. It‚Äôs a simple concept, if you ask Katsuki. You face challenges, you overcome them. None of that making nice bullshit people like to waste their time with. You get strong, you win. That‚Äôs what matters.

You do whatever you have to do.

And that‚Äôs that.

 

 

There is nothing wrong with an inquisitive mind.

That‚Äôs what Izuku‚Äôs father always says, anyway.

But Izuku‚Äôs inquisitiveness borders into dissection. He over thinks and over analyzes until he‚Äôs overwrought, burdened by questions whose answers he either doesn‚Äôt know or doesn‚Äôt want to know, but he can never stop himself from asking. The weight of his own inquisition pins him in place, and he stares into space and wonders.

He wonders if Tomura will ever forgive him. If Tomura will kill him. If Tomura will ever forgive himself if he does. He wonders who will take care of Tomura. If Kurogiri will stay. He wonders.

He wonders who his father will have him hurt next. How many people his father has hurt. How many quirks he has stolen. How many lives have been lost. How many families ruined. How many children left without their mothers.

He wonders if he is really going to do this.

Of all his questions, this is the only one Izuku can even begin to answer.

Is he really going to do this?

Well. It needs to be done. And Izuku is the only one who can do it.

It‚Äôs not a good answer, Izuku acknowledges to himself as he packs some of his belongings into a backpack. It only half addresses the question, at best ‚Äì a deflection instead of a direct response. Things that need to be done go ignored every day. They fall through the cracks, and it only becomes obvious that they needed doing at all in retrospect, when the consequences come to call. This particular task had likely needed doing for years, if not decades, but no one had done it yet, and it would be so, so easy to continue that trend of inaction.

His mother‚Äôs locket sits heavy against his neck. Normally, he would never wear it on a trip to the warehouse. Today, though, he has to bring it with him. If he does what needs doing, he won‚Äôt get a chance to come back for it, and he won‚Äôt risk leaving it behind, even if that means he ends up storing some bad memories.

That‚Äôs what lockets do, after all. They hold memories. Once, Izuku‚Äôs mother used it to store her memories of him, and now he uses it to store his memories of her. He has never wanted to risk tainting them. His mother was bright and good, maybe the only pure and untouched thing in Izuku‚Äôs entire life, and he couldn‚Äôt help but ask himself ‚Äì what would she think of this memory? What would she think of what he has become? Would she still say that there is nothing wrong with him? That he is good?

More questions that Izuku will never have answers to.

Here is the most important question, one Izuku will know the answer to sooner rather than later, for better or for worse.

Not ‚Äì is he going to do this.

But ‚Äì can he do this in the first place?

No, Izuku acknowledges to himself as he slips the last of his analysis notebooks into his bag. His hands shake so badly the edges of the books catch against each other, corners bending and crumpling as he shoves them down. No, he doesn‚Äôt think he can.

The things he has done ‚Äì the lives he has been complicit in the loss of ‚Äì already lurk on the edge of his every thought. Specters loom over his shoulders and clutch at the wayward edges of his bones, leeching all his warmth away. They swarm like rallying bees in the shadows behind his eyelids. He is already haunted.

How is he supposed to count his father among their numbers?

Because that is who he is plotting to kill. His father. Not a villain, not All for One ‚Äì Izuku‚Äôs father.

Sometimes, Izuku thinks there are two versions of Shigaraki Hisashi. One is his father and the other is All for One. One loves him; the other owns him.

For the past five years, Izuku has made this distinction. There is his father and there is All for One, separate entities that Izuku can feel entirely separate ways about, without the need for the cognitive dissonance that would rend him in half, otherwise.

Izuku loves his father. As for All for One ‚Äì hate is far too strong a word, and it doesn‚Äôt fit, anyway. It‚Äôs not fear, either. Neither word encapsulates the dripping melancholy that Izuku associates with the man, the sadness weaved in to every interaction. Hate and fear say nothing of the yearning that leaves a bitter taste beneath Izuku‚Äôs tongue. It is something more akin to regret, maybe.

Shigaraki Hisashi, the father, who Izuku loves. Shigaraki Hisashi, All for One, who Izuku regrets.

Izuku tells himself they are different.

They are not.

‚ÄúAre you ready to go?‚Äù asks Shigaraki Hisashi, the man who is both Izuku‚Äôs loving father and All for One, the villain who treats him like an object, a tool, a weapon.

His father who loves him; All for One who owns him. All for One who is his father and his father who is All for One.

Does his father own him?

Does All for One love him?

Was Izuku ever loved at all?

There he goes again, asking too many questions for his own good. He stares at his father‚Äôs face, at the metal plating that covers All for One‚Äôs eyes, at the scars that trail down his father‚Äôs cheeks, at the way All for One‚Äôs mouth ticks up slightly at one corner, his father‚Äôs gentle smile. The love and regret threaten to drown him. It‚Äôs an odd feeling, to mourn someone not yet dead but simultaneously long lost. Izuku swallows hard, turning his eyes to the ground to hide his rapid blinking under his hair.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù Izuku finally replies, stepping to his father‚Äôs side. His father doesn‚Äôt even spare the bag slung across one of Izuku‚Äôs shoulders a glance. Quirk analysis is part of what they do at the warehouse, after all, so Izuku‚Äôs notebooks are a common accessory to their time there.

All for One, as clever as he lauds himself to be, has no idea what‚Äôs coming to him.

Whether it‚Äôs trust or arrogance, the obliviousness makes Izuku ill. The whole situation makes him feel like he‚Äôs going to be sick, even though he‚Äôs barely eaten a thing since he woke up the day before.

He wants to be sick. He wants to cry. He wants to curl up in a small, dark space and pretend he doesn‚Äôt exist.

Instead, he takes all those feelings, balls them up, and swallows them down. They settle in his stomach as heavy and dense as a neutron star, but the persistent stinging behind Izuku‚Äôs eyes fades and he can finally take a deep breath without feeling like his lungs are being crushed.

Izuku has never used this quirk before. He has never wanted to. He has many quirks that he has never wanted to use, preferring to focus his limited time and energy on extensively training a reliable and versatile few, but this specific quirk has been deliberately and pointedly ignored. He has never wanted to use it; he has wanted to never use it.

Of course, his past compunctions don‚Äôt really bother him, now. Nothing does. That‚Äôs what the quirk is for.

He still knows what he‚Äôs feeling. The emotions are all still there. But they‚Äôre stored inside that dark, collapsed star in the center of his gut, unable to bother him any further. It‚Äôs an interesting change of pace for Izuku ‚Äì who is almost always overwhelmed when left to his own devices ‚Äì and a necessary intervention if he wants any hope of completing his task.

After all, with his emotions intact, Izuku couldn‚Äôt even watch Tomura try to harm a boy he hadn‚Äôt been friends with in over a decade without having a breakdown. Imagine the state he would be in, if he tried to kill his own father in cold blood. Izuku simply wouldn‚Äôt be able to do it. He would collapse beneath the weight of his own guilt and grief.

As it is, he does not cry or shake or wheeze as he and his father step into the warehouse, the portal leading them directly into the lab, like it does almost every week. Laying eyes on the nomu or the people and parts of people that will become nomu normally fills Izuku with disgust and remorse, but today is not a normal day.

Part of Izuku wants to ask questions. He‚Äôs always endlessly questioning things, and there are so many things he could ask his father. Things like why and what next and will it ever end. That part of Izuku wants to talk. It wants ‚Äì so very, very badly ‚Äì to understand. And it hopes ‚Äì with an acknowledged futility that does nothing to dull the sharp edge of desperation ‚Äì to prevent.

But that part of Izuku is neatly quarantined with his other emotions, all caught and contained by their own gravity, nothing more than footnotes on Izuku‚Äôs thoughts.

Rationally, there is no need to ask questions that won‚Äôt get proper answers. There is no reason to waste incredibly limited time catering to sentiment when there are matters of life and death that need handling.

Erasure is activated with a complete lack of fanfare.

Izuku‚Äôs father, facing away from him, halfway through the beginning of a sentence Izuku paid no attention to, stumbles. He lurches an arm out, grabbing the edge of one of many steel tables so hard his knuckles turn white. The tendons on the back of his hand stand out in harsh relief under the unforgiving florescence lights of the lab. All for One‚Äôs head rotates in Izuku‚Äôs direction, though the movement is less precise than usual, blind and undirected in the sudden absence of all the quirks he usually uses to make up for the loss of his eyes.

‚ÄúIzuku?‚Äù he asks, voice rasping and pained. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs going on?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry.‚Äù The words sound flat to Izuku‚Äôs own ears, but he‚Äôs not lying. He is sorry, somewhere in that star, even if he can‚Äôt feel it right now. As soon as he releases the quirk, he is going to be so incredibly sorry.

‚ÄúIzuku,‚Äù All for One repeats, voice simultaneously weaker and more stern. ‚ÄúWhat are you doing?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat needs to be done.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt need to do this. You can still stop. Let me go, tell me what‚Äôs wrong, and then we can fix it.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt,‚Äù Izuku says. ‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt fix it. They‚Äôre dead.‚Äù The words should be sobbed, Izuku is aware. But if he was crying, Erasure would likely deactivate, so it‚Äôs for the best that he can‚Äôt.

‚ÄúWhat does killing me solve? I‚Äôll just be another body on your conscious.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not about me. You‚Äôre the villain in a lot of stories, Dad. I want to see more happy endings.‚Äù

There are no heroes in Izuku‚Äôs story. Only different types of villains.

But ‚Äì there is a hope in Izuku, bright and sharp, that some of them may be able to be redeemed. All for One is not one of them. Izuku most likely isn‚Äôt, either. But Tomura ‚Äì maybe he could be. So, Izuku will make this choice, will make this sacrifice, and maybe in the process he will be able to save the one person in his life who needs it most.

His father‚Äôs knees buckle. The table screeches a couple of inches across the floor as All for One uses it to catch his weight and guide his fall. Izuku‚Äôs eyes are starting to burn. He had hoped this would be faster. If he blinks before it‚Äôs over, he‚Äôll never get another chance, but at the rate things are going Izuku won‚Äôt be able to hold out.

He wanted this to be quick and merciful and passive. Those were all things he needed it to be, when he was building scenarios in his head trying to decide what course of action he was going to take. Now, he just needs it to be over.

What is the best way to kill someone? Of all the questions Izuku has asked, all the wonderings that keep him up at night, he has never much thought about how to best commit murder. He wishes he had dedicated more thought to it earlier.

What is the best way to kill someone? In their sleep, he supposes. That‚Äôs how most people want to die, isn‚Äôt it?

There is a song that Izuku‚Äôs father sings to him whenever Izuku gets particularly upset. There are no words, only melody. Even that is broken into bits and pieces, eroded by all the years between now and his father‚Äôs own childhood. But Izuku has always loved the song, and he hums it now, letting the notes of it ‚Äì soft, soothing, and slightly sad ‚Äì twine through his father‚Äôs ears.

Lullaby is another of Izuku‚Äôs relatively old quirks. Before he had Izuku take it, All for One made sure to have a quirk of his own to prevent himself from being put to sleep, but it was of no help to him, now. After only a couple of bars, Izuku‚Äôs father can no longer fight unconsciousness.

What is the best way to kill someone? Fast, Izuku thinks.

There is a scalpel on the table Izuku‚Äôs father collapsed against. Izuku picks it up and turns it over between his fingers. The metal is cold and the shape is foreign. He doesn‚Äôt know how he‚Äôs meant to hold it. But he knows which end is the sharp one, which is arguably all he needs.

This is how it‚Äôs always done in the movies. One broad cut and it‚Äôs over. It‚Äôs fast. Blood loss isn‚Äôt supposed to be painful, Izuku doesn‚Äôt think. You get cold and tired and then you fall asleep. And his father is already asleep, so this is the best way. Or at least, the best way Izuku can think of.

Whenever Tomura made Izuku watch any of those really bloody horror movies, Izuku always thought they exaggerated. Blood doesn‚Äôt spray like that, he thought. It‚Äôs just camp. Fun with special effects.

There is nothing fun about how hot fresh blood feels against your skin.

It is thick and slippery and it smells.

But Izuku stays next to his father until the puddle stops growing.

Then, he stands. There are still more things that need doing, and he has limited time to do them.

At the bottom of his stomach, the dark star of Izuku‚Äôs swallowed emotions screams.
