Chapter Text

Standing before the gates of UA would evoke a strange combination of emotions in Izuku, if he were able to feel anything. As it is, he can‚Äôt even sense the awe, yearning, or bitter disappointment in the dense mass of repressed emotions that sits in his stomach. The conflicting things that Izuku knows he should be feeling are too drowned out by the buildup of guilt and grief and horror.

Instead, Izuku simply stares at the gate and the building beyond it. Towering, imposing things that are incapable of intimidating him. His eyes slide around the edges of the gate until they land on a camera, a small glassy glint amidst the stone that Izuku likely wouldn‚Äôt have been able to spot if he hadn‚Äôt been trained to. There is someone on the other end of it, watching him, he‚Äôs sure.

Izuku doesn‚Äôt look dangerous, like this. Looking at him now, no one would guess that two hours ago he was covered in the blood of his own father. He had stripped himself down under the staring but unseeing eyes of half a dozen nomu and climbed into the large stainless-steel sink in the back corner of the lab. He had sat, shivering beneath a torrent of freezing water, and scrubbed at his skin with his nails until the water that swirled down the drain finally ran clear. He had tossed his clothes into a stiff, heavy pile that sprayed blood onto the concrete and scrounged through the cabinets against the walls until he found something else to wear. Everything in the lab was too big for him ‚Äì which was inconvenient, though for the best, if Izuku considered the implications ‚Äì but he had made it work. Now, he was dressed in soft blue pants with an elastic waistband and a drawstring that made them perfectly adjustable and a large yellow hoodie with a rabbit on the front, hanging down to his thighs and covering his hands that still had blood dried under the nails. He couldn‚Äôt find a change of shoes, but he had wiped the blood from the white soles of the ones he usually wore with a spare T-shirt and ignored the slightly damp squelch of them beneath his toes.

Izuku just looks like some lazy teenager who threw on some longue clothes before going on an errand. It probably looks like he stopped on his way to gape at the most notorious school in the country, like countless people doubtlessly do on the daily.

‚ÄúHello,‚Äù Izuku calls to the camera. ‚ÄúCan I have a moment of your time? It‚Äôs important.‚Äù

He stares at the small reflection of the lens, shifting from foot to foot. He doesn‚Äôt know the right thing to say here, to gain anyone‚Äôs consideration. Beyond the gate, the building towers silent and still, students having gone home around an hour prior.

‚ÄúI need to see Eraserhead,‚Äù Izuku says, because that is why he is here.

Nothing changes. The camera is inscrutable. The building is unmoved. Izuku knows there is someone on the other side, watching and listening, but how is he meant to know whether or not they are hearing him? There are things he doesn‚Äôt want to say here, out in the open like this.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have much time.‚Äù

The star in Izuku‚Äôs stomach is an unstable thing. It pulses and writhes. It does not bother him ‚Äì it can not bother him ‚Äì but he knows that it is going to become a problem relatively soon. The quirk can only be used for five hours, maximum, and Izuku has already had it on for two. Combine that inherent limitation with the limits of Izuku‚Äôs own quirk ‚Äì namely that it takes time and practice for him to build stamina with each individual quirk he has, time and practice which he has not devoted to this particular quirk in the slightest ‚Äì and he isn‚Äôt sure how much longer he can hold this. He also isn‚Äôt sure exactly what the fallout will be when the quirk finally fails, but he‚Äôs certain it will be debilitating. Chapter Text

Tomura knows loss.

Once, he lost everything. He felt it fall apart beneath his fingers. He tried his best to hold on, but the touch of his hands brought distaster, and then Tomura was alone.

He knows loss. He knows the way it hollows you out. He knows how it feels to wonder why you are the only one left.

Once, Tomura was lost, but then he was found, and after that, everything was meant to be okay.

Now, he stares at the empty bookshelves in his brother‚Äôs room. Bookshelves that are meant to be stuffed with journals that the brat guards better than his own life.

It is Shuzenji, unshakable in the face of anything life throws at her, who moves into action, commanding the other heroes in the room with an easy authority that knocks them all out of their stunned trances.

I needed it to kill my father.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not a cruel man, Yagi,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúPull your head out of your ass.‚Äù

 

 

Tomura knows anger.

Anger is hot and familiar. It warms him from the inside out, so much so that he sometimes feels like he is boiling in his skin. It lives inside him like a parasite, feeding off of everything he does.

Anger is the only thing that has been with Tomura his entire life. Father taught him anger, and then Sensei taught him what to do about it. Tomura knows it inside and out, and it knows him just as well.

Anger is not bloody clothes and empty bookshelves. Phones and panic buttons and other important things left behind. Losing things, losing people, losing yourself.

This is not anger.

This is wrath.

Chapter Text

When they say they are taking Izuku to a safehouse, he expects a small, dark room underground that will keep him contained so he can‚Äôt hurt anyone else.

What he gets is a house.

It is not particularly large. The front door has several locks that only the heroes can open, and the windows are all covered by curtains that wouldn‚Äôt budge even if Izuku pulled at them. There are cameras everywhere ‚Äì some obvious, with blinking lights and bodies that swivel towards motions, others small and nondescript, designed to be unnoticeable like the one at the gates of UA. At least two heroes and one police officer are in the house at all times, sometimes more. They are neither kind nor cruel, as silent and watchful as the cameras.

And Izuku is hardly treated as a mere guest. Bands around both of his wrists keep his quirk suppressed, though they do nothing to inhibit his movement since they‚Äôre no longer connected by a chain. It is, in fact, a safehouse, where Izuku is being kept safe from the outside world just as much as the outside world is being kept safe from him.

For a moment, Izuku doesn‚Äôt understand why they bother. All these amenities and resources are being wasted on his safety and comfort, and the heroes must know that. But then Tsukauchi comes to ask more questions, and the effort makes sense.

When he was very little, he was surrounded by people, loved and adored the way all lucky children are. When he took on the false title of Quirkless and the world turned against him, his mother stayed by his side, and loved him even more fiercely, defiantly. When he lost his mother, his family grew paradoxically larger.

Izuku curls up in a tight, tight ball, and he hopes.

Tomura does not know betrayal.

Izuku hates stuff like that. He always cringes and yells and cries when characters turn against each other, like every pixelized representation of broken trust hits him straight in the heartstrings. Izuku just doesn‚Äôt have the stomach for it. For that cutthroat brutality that is such an essential part of so many people. He can‚Äôt handle it the same way he can‚Äôt handle violence.

He can‚Äôt handle things like ‚Äì things like slit throats and bloody clothes and broken trust.

Tomura does not know betrayal.

But he is learning.

Chapter Text

Izuku spends his third day in the safehouse curled up in the corner of the couch, staring at mindless cartoons on the television, eyes too blank and unfocused to truly say he is watching. Left to his own devices, he would have preferred to stay in bed, continuing with his quest to pinpoint the exact shade of white of the walls, but the hero who brought him breakfast in the morning had gently ushered him out of bed and insisted he stay in the living room. It is probably easier for them to keep an eye on him, this way.

Sometimes, the same hero attempts to speak to him, but Izuku digs his nails into the upholstery and doesn‚Äôt reply. The poor woman looks so uncomfortable. Izuku remembers her debut, around three years ago. She‚Äôs done well for herself, since, and there‚Äôs a part of him ‚Äì the part that is somehow the same even though it feels like everything about him should be changed ‚Äì that wants to ask her about her quirk.

He‚Äôs never really been able to talk to someone about their own quirk, before. All for One was always eager to talk quirks, but only ever to analyze the ones they had stolen or would like to steal. Izuku stares at the TV so long and hard that his vision starts to go grey around the edges. He blinks hard and tries to ignore the fact that his entire family is now in past tense.

He doesn‚Äôt think this hero would appreciate his questions, even if Izuku could un-cement his jaw to ask them. Imagine, the quirk stealing boy bombarding you with questions on how yours works and what you can do with it. Even with his quirk suppressed, that would be disconcerting. She already looks concerned enough, just sitting near him, without him actively making it worse. He wonders how it was determined who would be watching him; he wonders if the heroes assigned to his safehouse are being punished for something.

At almost exactly noon, Tsukauchi arrives. He knocks a distinct sequence that echoes through the small room, and the hero standing near the door ‚Äì an older pro who debuted just after Izuku started primary school ‚Äì begins undoing the multitude of locks with a haste that speaks of relief.

‚ÄúHello Midoriya,‚Äù Tsukauchi says as he enters. ‚ÄúHow are you feeling today? ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs only a few more things I want to ask you, for now. Do you think you can answer?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù Izuku says, aloud, because Tsukauchi will only proceed if he answers verbally. His voice barely cracks.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôve already told me a lot about your father and the League. Thank you for that ‚Äì I know it hasn‚Äôt been easy. We‚Äôve talked about whos and whats and whens, but now I‚Äôm going to ask a couple of whys, alright? Please just answer as completely and honestly as you can.‚Äù

Izuku picks at some dirt that has found its way under his thumbnail. ‚ÄúOkay.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou knew your father was evil, and you didn‚Äôt approve of the things he did. So why did you stay with him?‚Äù

‚ÄúHe wasn‚Äôt e-evil,‚Äù Izuku denies immediately. ‚ÄúEvil is just a w-word people use so they don‚Äôt have to try to un-understand each other.‚Äù

It is a pointless correction to make. To all but a handful of people, Izuku‚Äôs father will never be anyone more than All for One ‚Äì only ever an evil man who did evil things, with not even the faintest shades of grey around the black abyss where his soul was meant to be. It hurt for Izuku to admit that Shigaraki Hisashi was All for One, a duality of a man, and it hurts even more to know that, for most of the world, All for One is the only part of the man that matters.

‚ÄúAlright,‚Äù Tsukauchi ascents, though his eyes clearly say he doesn‚Äôt agree. ‚ÄúYou knew he was a villain, then.‚Äù

‚ÄúI did. But he w-wasn‚Äôt my v-villain. He was my f-f-father.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo you stayed because he loved you?‚Äù

‚ÄúCan you clarify who you mean by ‚Äòall?‚Äô‚Äù

‚ÄúMy f-father. Kurogiri. T-Tom-mura. They ‚Äì They‚Äôre my f-family.‚Äù

Were, Izuku corrects to himself, sternly. Izuku‚Äôs life is in past tense, now. The sooner that sticks in his head, the sooner this painful cycle of forgetting-remembering-forgetting-remembering will stop.

‚ÄúMidori ‚Äì Izuku. Why did you kill your father?‚Äù

Izuku turns his eyes back to the bright colors and graphic lines flashing across the television screen as his chest seizes. ‚ÄúHave you ever heard of the trolley problem?‚Äù Izuku asks. His voice sounds like static in his ears.

‚ÄúOf course.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo you ever wonder why they don‚Äôt just stop the train? In real life, that‚Äôs what they‚Äôd do. They‚Äôd just stop the train.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh.‚Äù

‚ÄúI was so tired of picking lives,‚Äù Izuku admits softly, barely audible against the upbeat theme of the cartoon‚Äôs end credits. ‚ÄúPeople kept getting st-stuck on the ‚Äì on the train tracks, and I ‚Äì Why keep p-pulling l-lev-levers when you c-can j-just‚Äì‚Äù His voice cracks, words shriveling up as his throat closes around them. Tears wells in his eyes abruptly, the sting of them more potent than ever, as if the last few days of doing his best to repress them has somehow made them saltier. ‚ÄúWhen you can just stop the train,‚Äù Tsukauchi finishes. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry you had to do that.‚Äù

Tsukauchi places a hand on Izuku‚Äôs shoulder just as the first sob tears itself free, and Izuku can‚Äôt help the way his whole body trembles at the contact, torn between pulling away and leaning into the touch. ‚ÄúThis won‚Äôt last forever,‚Äù Tsukauchi says quietly as Izuku cries. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve been through a lot all at once, but you‚Äôre still here, and you‚Äôre not going to feel like this forever. If Izuku could make his breath cooperate well enough to form words, he would have questions. Questions like how? and when? and why bother?

But Izuku can‚Äôt speak, only sob, so he just sits, rigid beneath a touch he doesn‚Äôt know how to accept and isn‚Äôt sure he wants, with all his doubts confined to his head.

 

 

Bureaucracy is probably somewhere near the top of the list when it comes to things Shouta hates. He hates meetings and paperwork and having to listen to people talk around issues as they try to further their own agendas. Normally, Shouta would not be caught dead volunteering to be part any committee, not to mention one that is likely to be particularly full of bullshit. Yet here he is, of his own free will, slouched in a chair at a conference room table, nobly resisting the urge to slump to the ground and take a nap. If asked, he‚Äôd claim that he left his sleeping bag in his classroom for the sake of professionalism, but Shouta is unashamed to admit, at least to himself, that he left it behind mostly to remove the temptation it presents.

But, as he eyes one of the representatives sent by the Hero Public Safety Commission on the other side of the table, he can‚Äôt bring himself to regret being here. This particular representative coolly raises her eyebrows as she flips through the information packet Tsukauchi has prepared, expression a study of unimpressed inscrutability.

Shouta ignores his own packet for the moment, familiar enough with the situation from hounding Tsukauchi the last few days, in favor of assessing the gathered group. His eyes ache ‚Äì uncovered for the occasion, much to Recovery Girl‚Äôs chagrin ‚Äì though the room is kept relatively dim, with only half the overhead lights switched on, specifically to accommodate Shouta‚Äôs stubborn insistence that he be able to see what is going on during this meeting.

There are sixteen of them, counting Shouta, sitting in thick silence, broken only by the shuffle of papers and squeak of chairs as they shift around. Tsukauchi and two other officers on the case sit at the head of the square formation of tables, flanked by Nedzu and All Might. Shouta himself has taken a seat near the door, next to Thirteen, who offered him a commiserating smile as they stiffly took their seat. Endeavor, flames extinguished, sits beside the HPSC representatives ‚Äì there‚Äôs three of them in total, counting the woman whose eyebrows have not shifted from their elevated position since she began reading. There are five other heroes in the room, a couple of whom Shouta doesn‚Äôt recognize. Two of them, he knows, were part of the rotations supervising Izuku, and he hopes that‚Äôs a good sign, since anyone who actually spent time around the kid could see he‚Äôs worth giving a chance.

When the knocks come again, this time in early evening, Izuku is back in bed. Izuku rolls into a seated position, pulling the blanket with him so it is wrapped around his shoulders and tucked underneath his toes. Around the time Tsukauchi should be pulling the chair away from the desk, there is a soft rap on the wall. Present Mic ‚Äì in soft-looking civilian clothes, with his hair pulled into a messy bun ‚Äì enters the room with a lazy stride. ‚ÄúWhy are you here?‚Äù Izuku asks without thinking, nearly biting his tongue half-way through the question when he realizes how rude he is being. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm fine,‚Äù Izuku says to his knees. ‚ÄúI won‚Äôt bother him again,‚Äù Izuku says.

‚ÄúEraserhead.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh kiddo.‚Äù Mic scoots along the bed, not far, just an inch closer, but closer all the same. ‚ÄúI took his quirk.‚Äù

The declaration is so cheery and matter of fact, as if returning something stolen is as good as never having stolen it. Present Mic is a good man, Izuku realizes, but a na√Øve one. Good, to want to spare people pain; na√Øve, to not realize that some people deserve it.  

‚ÄúHe doesn‚Äôt blame you for what happened,‚Äù Present Mic says, solemn in a way he never is on the radio.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs got nothing but good things to say about you, actually. And Shouta‚Äôs a great judge of character.‚Äù Izuku shakes his head, back and forth so fast that he would have swayed side to side if he hadn‚Äôt been braced against the wall. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs on your side. We both are.‚Äù

Izuku gasps. He buries his head against his knees again, and the blanket there is immediately too hot, too damp, too close, making it even harder to pull air into lungs that feel like they‚Äôre shrinking.

Izuku doesn‚Äôt have a side. Maybe he did, once, but then he killed one of the only people on it and lost all the others in the process. ‚ÄúBreathe,‚Äù Present Mic says, cutting through Izuku‚Äôs thoughts. The mantra and voice are both too familiar at this point, and Izuku obeys like it‚Äôs a Pavlovian response. ‚ÄúCan I give you a hug?‚Äù Present Mic asks. He makes no move to cross the distance between them, waiting for Izuku‚Äôs response, and his tone is soft and non-threatening, but Izuku flinches so hard that his head snaps back and cracks against the wall. Izuku shakes his head, ardently enough that he nearly knocks it back into the wall, and that‚Äôs that. He doesn‚Äôt want to see any more of those soft looks. He doesn‚Äôt want to see those hands hovering around, fingers splayed in unspoken offer. Izuku can‚Äôt take it. It burns to even think about.

For nearly an hour, though, Present Mic still doesn‚Äôt leave. He carries a gentle and cheerful conversation all by himself, even when Izuku goes half-catatonic with the numb lethargy that always follows a near-brush with hysteria. Present Mic leaves with a soft promise to return, but even if the hero means what he says, Izuku doubts he will be here much longer.

Finally left alone again, Izuku rubs his cheek against the blanket until the fibers scratch at the tear-tender skin beneath his eyes. Alone, he wraps his arms around himself and squeezes until his ribs creek. He imagines his arms as someone else‚Äôs, and his skin feels shivery-crawly, so he squeezes tighter, until the joints of his shoulders protest.

He tries to remember the last time he was hugged.

It‚Äôs not as if Izuku was starved of affection, but affection came in many forms and hugs didn‚Äôt really feature much in Izuku‚Äôs life after his mother was taken from him. Kurogiri didn‚Äôt like touching at all. Kurogiri was the type who provides, a silent, reliable presence. He leaves ‚Äì left ‚Äì small things in Izuku‚Äôs room, just because he knew Izuku would like them. Tomura doesn‚Äôt didn‚Äôt like touching either ‚Äì he was always so careful about his hands. He would touch Izuku though, because Izuku was special. But their affections were always the rough kind, shoving and wrestling, with bruises and breathless laughter.

And his father. His father generally preferred simple, brief contact. Ruffled hair and shoulder squeezes. Most of the time, he was stoic and reserved. He really only hugged Izuku when Izuku was distress. He would hug Izuku, now. Even after everything Izuku has done, if his father were here, he would hug him.

God, Izuku wants it.

But Izuku isn‚Äôt like Present Mic. He‚Äôs neither good nor na√Øve.

He knows what he deserves.

Chapter Text

‚ÄúSo it‚Äôs settled!‚Äù Nedzu declares from the table top he has made into his stage.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù the Commission representative protests. ‚ÄúNothing has been settled at all. ‚ÄúWe can take a vote, then. That‚Äôs what this committee is for, after all! ‚ÄúOf course,‚Äù he says diplomatically. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll take a vote, then. Those in favor?‚Äù Shouta raises a casted arm without hesitation, relieved to see many others, Yagi among them, wisely following suit.

‚ÄúAll opposed?‚Äù A smaller number of hands go up, and Shouta hides a smug smirk in his scarf, as he pointedly avoids looking at that one particularly detestable Commission representative. ‚ÄúAbstentions?‚Äù To Shouta‚Äôs side, Thirteen alone raises a meek hand.  

‚ÄúAlright,‚Äù Tsukauchi says, ‚Äúthat‚Äôs ten for, four against, and one abstention.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat are the margins?‚Äù the representative asks, frowning sternly at one of her companions who had voted in favor.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs in the packet,‚Äù Tsukauchi says drily, but then answers, ‚ÄúTwo-thirds. The majority has it.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis can‚Äôt be allowed. UA is a high school, not a rehabilitation program. You don‚Äôt have the resources.‚Äù

Maybe Shouta is qualified for this on paper, but that‚Äôs the thing, isn‚Äôt it? The difference between knowing and understanding. ‚ÄúSho?‚Äù Hizashi asks, concerned. He shifts until he is propped up on his elbows, rather than laying down. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt tell me they‚Äôre sending him to jail. If they are, I want you to lie to me. Wait, no. Tell me the truth so I can hunt them down. Or break him out! There‚Äôs no way‚Äì‚Äù Shouta forces himself to breathe, to think rationally as Hizashi riles himself up to go to war against the rest of the committee or stage a prison break or both.

Shouta made the right decision, and even if he didn‚Äôt, it‚Äôs been made. He will grow to understand, just like he has with all the other theoretical ideas that crashed full speed into his real world. And he has Hizashi, who already understands and who is far better with these things than Shouta ever will be. Hizashi, who still doesn‚Äôt know what Shouta has done.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs not going to jail,‚Äù Shouta says, interrupting Hizashi‚Äôs rant, which has devolved into threats graphic enough that it‚Äôs good Tsukauchi isn‚Äôt around to overhear. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôll be a ward of UA, so long as he agrees to the conditions.‚Äù

Hizashi collapses back down, resting his chin on Shouta‚Äôs sternum. ‚ÄúWell, why didn‚Äôt you just say so! I probably should have guessed, with Nedzu involved. At least this way we‚Äôll be able to see him sometimes, huh? Make sure everything is going well. Maybe he‚Äôll finally let me give him that hug.‚Äù

‚ÄúOh, we‚Äôll be seeing plenty of him. He‚Äôs coming to stay with us.‚Äù

There is a moment of silence, long enough that Shouta begins to wonder if he was too blunt. Then the windows rattle as Hizashi shrieks something that Shouta can‚Äôt discern over the sudden ringing in his ears. All the cats dart around, startled and frantic and howling, even Lucy, who digs his claws into Shouta‚Äôs shin as he catapults himself from the couch. Without Erasure, all Shouta can do is slam his hands over Hizashi‚Äôs mouth, probably with a touch too much force, considering the hard plaster encasing them, but Shouta‚Äôs head feels like it‚Äôs been cracked open across the eyes, so he can‚Äôt bring himself to be particularly careful.

Hizashi cuts himself off, makes a barely-there sound of apology and disentangles from Shouta to retrieve some painkillers. Lucy and Disco both find corners somewhere to hide away until they deem the apartment safe again; Bastard, on the other hand, continues to ricochet around every inch of space available to her, like a bouncy ball from hell. Hizashi returns, dropping a few pills into Shouta‚Äôs palm which he slams back dry after wiggling his bandages out of the way. Shouta lets his head fall back against the arm of the couch as he waits for the meds to kick in, Hizashi silently taking a seat on the floor next to him.

‚ÄúTo clarify,‚Äù Shouta begins when the pain has died to a manageable ache, ‚Äúthat was a surprised and excited scream, right?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah, Kitten, it was.‚Äù

Shouta can hear the soft smile in Zashi‚Äôs voice, and it‚Äôs always a sound worth hearing, no matter how much it makes his head hurt.

Chapter Text

On Izuku‚Äôs fourth day in the safehouse, Tsukauchi does not come. Izuku eats the breakfast that is prepared for him, and then he returns to the bedroom until lunch. The clock ticks into late afternoon and Izuku remains uninterrupted, staring at the wall ‚Äì it is probably ivory, he has decided ‚Äì and gripping his mother‚Äôs locket so tightly the broken hinge leaves a groove in the meat of his thumb.

Still, Tsukauchi doesn‚Äôt come. But Present Mic does. He stands in the doorway, grinning as Izuku gapes.

Izuku never expected to see Present Mic again. At the end of their last meeting, just yesterday, the hero had promised he would come back, but Izuku was sure he would either forget or Izuku would be moved before then.

‚ÄúHey Little Listener,‚Äù the man says, as he enters the room. This time he makes for the desk chair instead of the bed, but rather than sit in it, he slots his arm through the back and picks it up. ‚ÄúMind joining us in the living room?‚Äù

‚ÄúUs?‚Äù Izuku echoes, mindlessly taking his feet. He feels so unbalanced it‚Äôs a miracle he can stand straight, but the world doesn‚Äôt tip sideways the way it seems like it should, and the ground is solid beneath his feet.

‚ÄúYep! You‚Äôre a popular one.‚Äù Present Mic lowers his glasses enough to offer Izuku an exaggerated wink, then walks back to the door, chair in tow. He knocks the legs of it against the doorframe as he goes. ‚ÄúYikes,‚Äù he says, rubbing his fingers against the wood as if that will remove the scuffs he just put in. ‚ÄúYou didn‚Äôt see that!‚Äù

Izuku hesitates for a moment, standing next to the bed and staring dumbly after the hero who whirled into the room out of nowhere and then back out just as abruptly. When Tsukauchi had not come that day, Izuku had assumed that it was over. That there were no more questions to ask. No more details to carefully pry from the resistant vice of Izuku‚Äôs jaws. No more pitying looks, no more pseudo-comfort. And he had assumed that that meant he would soon be escorted to whatever cell he would be spending the rest of his life in. Probably somewhere deep underground, where he would only see passing guards until the day Tomura found a way inside to put an end to everything.

This visit, with winks and casual property damage, never featured in Izuku‚Äôs imaginings of what would happen next. This is not a part of Izuku‚Äôs plan, not even meant to be a part of the tenuous limbo he has found himself in.

He follows Present Mic with cautious steps, into the living room to face the rest of his ‚Äì visitors? There, at the small table where Izuku eats his meals, sits Eraserhead and Nedzu. Izuku freezes again in the doorway, watching with wide eyes as Present Mic places his stolen seat next to Eraserhead, flopping into it and resting his chin in one hand as he sprawls the other arm across the table. He grins at Eraserhead, who glares at him with bloodshot eyes that just barely peek out between the seams of his bandages. Nedzu stands in his own chair at Eraserhead‚Äôs other side, head fully cresting the table, but barely.

The principal grins as he catches sight of Izuku, small, pointed teeth catching the light with a vicious glint. ‚ÄúIzuku! Come, take a seat!‚Äù He nods to the lone empty chair at the table.

Wordlessly, Izuku does as he is told, moving on autopilot as he still struggles to catch up with the situation he has found himself in. He crosses the room carefully, silently watching the heroes in front of him. Present Mic turns away from Eraserhead to give Izuku another bright smile, cheek squashed against his fist and glasses slightly askew. With the attention of all three heroes on him, Izuku feels impossibly heavy, like he is about to crumple beneath the force of his own gravity. He resists the urge to fold in on himself, glancing quickly between Present Mic‚Äôs amicable smile, the red rimming Eraserhead‚Äôs barely-visible eyes, and the glint of light across Nedzu‚Äôs teeth.  

‚ÄúFirst of all,‚Äù Nedzu begins, ‚Äúwe have something that belongs to you. Mic?‚Äù

‚ÄúRight!‚Äù

Present Mic glances around for a quick moment, then leans over Eraserhead, ignoring the short noise of protest, to scoop something off the floor. He hefts it up with a triumphant cry, slinging it onto the table. Izuku‚Äôs backpack thuds against the wood and slides slightly across the surface. Half-unzipped, several notebooks jar loose, one of which tumbles straight into Nedzu‚Äôs waiting paws.

‚ÄúHizashi,‚Äù Eraserhead scolds flatly. Present Mic shrugs his shoulders with a sheepish laugh. Izuku watches the small exchange with saucer-wide eyes.

‚ÄúVolume 17,‚Äù Nedzu reads. Izuku‚Äôs attention snaps to him as he flips open the book. ‚ÄúThis is one of my favorites!‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù Izuku blurts, eyes locked onto the damning spread of pages in Nedzu‚Äôs paws.

‚ÄúAre we doing apologies again?‚Äù Eraserhead asks dryly. ‚ÄúIn that case, I‚Äôm sorry for erasing your quirk the way I did in the infirmary. I didn‚Äôt realize there would be any kind of backlash on you.‚Äù

Suddenly, Izuku does not know where to look. The notebooks and Eraserhead demand his attention in equal measure. Izuku‚Äôs eyes dart frantically between the two ‚Äì from the hero he wronged, back the book that proves to just how many others he did the same ‚Äì never able to settle on one before the need to address the second itches at him again.

Izuku presses his tongue to the dry roof of his mouth. ‚ÄúWhat? N-no, I ‚Äì the b-books‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúAre quite impressive,‚Äù Nedzu fills in, not at all what Izuku had been intending to say. Izuku bites down the contrary noise that tries to leap from his mouth. ‚ÄúDo you use one of the intelligence quirks in your repertoire when you put together these analyses?‚Äù

‚ÄúI ‚Äì n-no, no.‚Äù Izuku half reaches out to snatch the book away but thinks better of it before the movement can become anything more than a twitch of his already-shaking hands. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt ‚Äì there‚Äôs n-nothing sp-special about i-it.‚Äù

‚ÄúDid All for One have you make these profiles?‚Äù

Izuku thinks, with rising dread, about the number of heroes he has written about in those books. Practically every hero he has ever seen has been catalogued in some capacity, varying from mere lines to entire pages of notes and breakdowns, depending on how much information was available to him. And then there were the quirks that didn‚Äôt belong to heroes at all ‚Äì the quirks that belonged to victims, stolen away by either Izuku or his father and then immortalized and dissected on paper.

He knew the police had the notebooks, knew they had already been filed in the evidence against him. He had handed them over without a single word of argument. At the time, he hadn‚Äôt minded turning them in. In a strange way, it felt like severing a limb, giving up the books that he had spent practically his whole life working on, but he knew the information was better off in hands that wouldn‚Äôt abuse it.

Now, though, confronted directly, Izuku feels sick with shame. Many of the pages in those books had never been seen by All for One. They were Izuku‚Äôs, and Izuku‚Äôs alone. But there were over twenty books in the bag, hundreds of quirks within their pages, and the analysis there had resulted in enough deaths that Izuku had lost count.

‚ÄúI-it‚Äôs just a h-hobby,‚Äù he says, weakly. ‚ÄúMy f-fa-fa ‚Äì no, m-most of them were j-just for m-me. For ‚Äì for fun.‚Äù He chokes on the word. Izuku‚Äôs not proud to have built entertainment from death and destruction, but quirk analysis is a lure he has never been able to resist, even when it meant doubling down on his crimes, adding insult to injury. Like a sociopathic scientist, deaf to the screams of those he studies.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs rare for someone your age to enjoy analysis of this nature, not to mention of this quality.‚Äù

‚ÄúNedzu,‚Äù Eraserhead interjects, just as tears begin to well in Izuku‚Äôs eyes.

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù Nedzu replies, smile turning thoughtful as he assesses Izuku. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not in trouble! I meant it when I said I was impressed. I‚Äôve looked these over extensively and you have quite the gift, Izuku!‚Äù

Confused, Izuku blinks ‚Äì once, twice, eyelashes matting together as his tears spill over, even as his distress is displaced with disorientation. Present Mic shuffles around, patting over his jacket and crowing as he pulls something from one of his pockets. He slides the item ‚Äì a small pack of tissues ‚Äì across the table to Izuku with a satisfied grin.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt un-understand,‚Äù Izuku admits, picking the packet up and pulling a tissue from it to worry between his fingers.

‚ÄúHave you ever thought of putting your skills to use?‚Äù

‚ÄúSkills?‚Äù

‚ÄúLike the analysis!‚Äù

‚ÄúI ‚Äì I tried ‚Äì o-only s-sometimes. W-when T-Tom-mura n-need m-me to, b-but‚Äì‚Äù

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt mean to use for the League,‚Äù Nedzu interrupts. ‚ÄúI mean for yourself. Have you ever considered being an analyst?‚Äù

‚Äú‚Ä¶What?‚Äù Something in Izuku‚Äôs voice, thin and lost as it is, makes Nedzu stop and think for a moment, smiling fading into a more serious, considerate stare, that is no less unnerving.

‚ÄúI suppose what I‚Äôm asking,‚Äù he says slowly, ‚Äúis what you want to be when you grow up. What are your dreams, Izuku?‚Äù

Izuku is still crying, tears flowing sluggishly, but he is no longer sure why. He‚Äôs not sure of much at all at the moment, feeling unmoored in the face of Nedzu‚Äôs question as he picks apart the tissue in his hands. Tiny shards of fiber flutter slightly across the table with each of Izuku‚Äôs exhales. He feels a little bit like those bits of tissue paper. Thin and fragile, fuzzy around the edges, insubstantial like he might float way or dissolve to shreds.

His dreams? These days, Izuku has only been having nightmares, but he knows that‚Äôs not what Nedzu is referring to. His hopes? Izuku tries to think back.

When is the last time Izuku imagined the future and thought of anything other than blood and tears? Why would he bother, when it had nothing else to offer him?

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know,‚Äù he says. The confession echoes around his chest, bouncing between his ribs like his insides are some cavernous space, vast and empty.

‚ÄúSkills like yours could be incredibly useful in heroics, you know.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Izuku denies automatically. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt be a hero.‚Äù

‚ÄúNedzu,‚Äù Eraserhead cuts in sharply.

Simultaneously, the principal himself asks, ‚ÄúWhy not?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm a villain,‚Äù Izuku replies helplessly, looking between the two ‚Äì the mummified glare of Eraserhead, the Mona Lisa smile of Nedzu. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to jail.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not going to jail,‚Äù Eraserhead corrects, tone firm enough that Izuku can only blink and turn the words over in his head, argument stricken from his tongue. He tries to find an angle to look at them that will make them make sense, but everything just gets more tangled up as he does, twisting together into a jumbled mass of nonsense that makes Izuku‚Äôs head hurt. Childishly, he wants to cover his ears, to sing loudly to himself until his own voice blocks out all these statements that he can‚Äôt make sense of.

‚ÄúWhat about when you were little?‚Äù Present Mic asks, drawing Izuku‚Äôs attention away from the unreadable expanse of bandages that mask the nuance of Eraserhead‚Äôs expression, from that slight sliver of eye that pierces Izuku through. ‚ÄúWhat did you want to do then?‚Äù

Izuku thinks back again, farther this time. Long back, before he knew too well how blood felt between his fingers. Back before his mother was taken from him, followed soon after by whatever remained of his innocence. Before his quirk came in, and the world grasped him hard by the shoulders and taught him that not all men were created equal.

‚ÄúI‚Ä¶ wanted to h-help people.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what heroes do,‚Äù Present Mic says, smiling gently. For the first time since Nedzu started speaking, Izuku‚Äôs mouth firms from its confounded slackness, pulling into a brittle frown.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù he says, too harsh. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what they‚Äôre supposed to do.‚Äù He regrets the words the moment they escape him, flinching forward just a fraction of an inch, as if he can reach out and snatch them back out of the air. Present Mic‚Äôs smile falls away, and Izuku finds that the hero is even harder to look at when he is frowning.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre right, kid,‚Äù Eraserhead says. Izuku looks to him sharply, the agreement putting him instantly on edge. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt always do our jobs as well as we should.‚Äù

Izuku backtracks. ‚ÄúT-that‚Äôs not‚Äì‚Äù

‚ÄúNo, it‚Äôs true. There are too many people out there who don‚Äôt get the help they need. Even heroes are only human. We can‚Äôt be everywhere; we can‚Äôt know everything. Can‚Äôt save everyone. Not to mention that some of us don‚Äôt have our priorities in order, to begin with. But that doesn‚Äôt make it any better for the people we fail. Right now, we‚Äôre trying not to fail you.‚Äù

‚ÄúMe?‚Äù

‚ÄúYes, you. Nedzu, cut to the chase.‚Äù

‚ÄúOf course!‚Äù Nedzu exclaims, cheerful composure unshaken by Eraserhead‚Äôs curt tone. ‚ÄúYesterday, a committee of heroes, officers, and members of the HPSC met to discuss where you will go from here.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot jail?‚Äù Izuku asks, still dubious, cutting his eyes to Eraserhead. He feels as if gravity has been reversed, like any moment now he is going to fall up out of his chair, tumbling head over heels into the sky. Then, when everything is set back to sorts, back to the way it should be, reality will come crashing down, and it will bring him with it until he is nothing but a red splatter on the pavement.

‚ÄúNot jail!‚Äù Nedzu confirms.

‚ÄúThen where‚Ä¶?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou have two options in front of you. I am here to offer you a deal, but should you not like it, the HPSC will take custody of you.‚Äù

Izuku tenses. In his five years with his father, Izuku had learned all about the flaws in their hero-centric society, though he never quite grew to hate heroics as a whole, the way Tomura had. The system is flawed, deeply and inherently, but many of the people who participate in it do so with the best of intentions, wanting to help people, the same way Izuku himself had once craved so fervently. But the Hero Public Safety Commission is a different beast entirely, and Izuku knows enough about their inner workings ‚Äì more than they would ever want him to know, he is sure ‚Äì to detest them entirely. Nedzu watches Izuku‚Äôs reaction with sharp eyes, and Izuku meets the beady gaze, swallowing thickly.

‚ÄúAnd your deal?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs simple!‚Äù Nedzu responds, eyes glinting, as he produces a thick sheaf of paper from seemingly nowhere, passing it to Present Mic who, in turn, hands it to Izuku. It is heavy in Izuku‚Äôs palms, looking and feeling anything but simple. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôll become a ward of UA. I‚Äôll take over your education, to assess your skills and guide you on the right path.‚Äù Eraserhead scoffs, but Izuku stares at the papers in front of him with tears once again burning against the backs of his eyes.

‚ÄúUA?‚Äù he asks, tracing a shaking finger over the two large and bold letters at the top of the page. Ink bleeds slightly as a tear drips from his chin onto the typing.

‚ÄúUA,‚Äù Present Mic says. He leans into Eraserhead with a small, crooked smile.

It has been a long time since Izuku had dreams, but he was full of them, once. He dreamed of helping people, saving them, being a hero. UA was always at the center of those dreams, golden and bright.

Once, Izuku had dreamed of helping people. It was a dream like the sun ‚Äì warm and shining, far away but still in sight. But then he hurt people, more and more, until it seemed almost impossible that he could ever help anyone at all, and he was locked away in some cold place where light could never reach him. Now, if Izuku is being painfully honest with himself, the only thing he can still dream of is to someday simply be good. It is a dream more like a nightmare ‚Äì cracked nails on bleeding fingers, scrabbling at dirt as he tries to dig his way out of a grave of his own making.

For years, Izuku had thought that his dreams were dead, killed by his own hand. So he had buried himself with them, had stopped bothering to dream at all. What was the point, when he knew exactly what the future had in store for him? He would never be a hero, would never be anything more than the villain of his own story. He resigned himself to days of blood and theft and freezing cold.

But he has ended that cycle, hasn‚Äôt he? Painfully, in a way he is sure he will regret for the rest of his life, but ended, nonetheless. He will never go back to the warehouse again.

When Izuku decided to write his own story, he had planned to make a single change. Make a scalpel his pen and scratch out his father‚Äôs name. That was all. That alone was enough to domino into massive differences down the line ‚Äì happy endings where there would have been tragedies. Happy endings that would make it all worth it, even if Izuku didn‚Äôt get one of his own. His story has always been a tragedy, after all.

Izuku turns pages with fingers he cannot feel, skimming over words that look hazy through the film of tears over his eyes. It is not simple, what they are offering him. And it is not forgiveness. But simple forgiveness isn‚Äôt what Izuku wants, and it certainly isn‚Äôt what he deserves. No, they are giving him a chance to earn something.

He reads and a bubble grows in his chest, something golden-bright that feels a lot like dreams used to. Something a little like a sunrise.

‚ÄúI can be a hero?‚Äù Izuku asks softly, staring at the bold and capitalized heading: SPORTS FESTIVAL. All three of the others at the table answer his barely-there question at once, a chorus of affirmation that makes Izuku‚Äôs ears ring.

Izuku reads the word ‚Äúrehabilitation‚Äù so many times that it starts to look like ‚Äúredemption.‚Äù

 

 

The safehouse falls into silence, broken only by the whisper of turning pages and the stutter-gasp of breath that is thick with tears. The kid reads and rereads, bottom lip trembling as he soundlessly mouths the occasional sentence to himself. A crease has settled between his brows. Against Shouta‚Äôs side, Hizashi‚Äôs weight becomes heavier as the silence stretches, but he resists the urge he must be feeling to break it and rolls his lip between his teeth, as quiet as the rest of them.

Nedzu‚Äôs proposal is lengthy and dense. It‚Äôs not the kind of thing Shouta would have expected the kid to read and process on his own, but Nedzu seems content to simply watch Izuku‚Äôs reactions rather than to guide him through anything. Shouta stares at the dimple between the kid‚Äôs brows, deep and unwavering. It speaks less of a confusion on the what and more on the why; understanding the contents of what has been put before him, but not believing it.

Through the confusion, disbelief, and despair that still cling to every edge of the kid, it is hard to predict what he is going to say. Certainly, the problem child is thinking he doesn‚Äôt deserve this. Shouta can guess that much. But does he want what Nedzu is offering? If he does, which is more important to him ‚Äì wanting or deserving? Will he prioritize the desire, or will he deprive himself of this opportunity the same way Hizashi fears he deprives himself of comfort?

Each rustle of paper as the kid flips back and forth between pages has something winding tighter in Shouta‚Äôs chest. Anxiety churns in his stomach at the thought of Izuku saying yes, coming home with them, relying on them. Shouta doesn‚Äôt want to fail the kid again, but he doesn‚Äôt even know where to start in order to succeed.

Worse than that anxiety, though, is the dread that bubbles in his lungs like tar at the thought of the kid saying no. Of disappearing behind the concrete, steel, and red tape of the Commission, where the closest thing to comfort he will be offered is raised eyebrows, like he is some trivial curiosity. Locked up and locked away, not even railing against the injustice of it, because it‚Äôs exactly what he thinks he deserves.

Shouta would rather fail the kid a million times over than sit by and watch as Izuku fails himself.

Beneath the table, Zashi squeezes Shouta‚Äôs knee tightly enough that Shouta can feel his nails through the fabric of his pants. Unable to squeeze back, Shouta jogs his leg once in acknowledgement. Nedzu pats his paws silently on the edge of the table, smiling as serenely as ever, apparently unaffected by the unease saturating the air.

‚ÄúSo what happens n-next?‚Äù Izuku eventually asks, voice hesitant in the thick air. He runs his thumb along the side of the packet, a quick shuffle of the pages. ‚ÄúWhere do w-we start?‚Äù

There is another quiet moment as everyone process the unspoken implication in the kid‚Äôs words. Shouta‚Äôs anxiety ramps up into a rolling boil but the tar drains from his lungs, a sweet relief that allows him to breath freely without the air getting stuck in his chest. Hizashi muffles an excited noise against his palm, bouncing slightly in his seat and madly shaking Shouta‚Äôs knee. The burst of energy, as contained as it is by Zashi‚Äôs standards, startles Izuku, who flinches slightly before freezing in place, taut and trembling for a moment before he cautiously relaxes again. Shouta knocks his temple again his husband‚Äôs with a quelling glare.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôll come to stay with us,‚Äù Shouta says, catching the kid‚Äôs wary eyes. ‚ÄúEither today or tomorrow, if you want some time to think.‚Äù

‚Äú‚Ä¶With you?‚Äù

‚ÄúWith us!‚Äù Hizashi exclaims, pulling his hand away from his mouth the reveal the wide grin that has taken up residence there. As Zashi once again begins to vibrate with excitement, voice a touch too loud, Shouta locks their ankles together and jostles his leg. Hizashi‚Äôs smile takes on a slightly abashed tint but doesn‚Äôt dim as he shakes his hands out and settles back into his chair. Izuku stares at the pair of them ‚Äì how close Hizashi placed their chairs together, how Hizashi leans into Shouta until their arms are pressed together, how casually Shouta allows the contact ‚Äì with realization dawning in his eyes. His lips purse, twist into a conflicted curve.

‚ÄúBut I ‚Äì W-why would you‚Ä¶‚Äù

They are still dim, still glazed, and the kid himself still looks listless and washed out, like the world has dug its teeth into him and shaken him about, but there is a fire inside him.

And if you give a fire fuel, it will grow.

 

 

Eraserhead can and will sleep anywhere and Present Mic is not a particularly good singer.

Izuku learns both of these things within the first fifteen minutes of the car ride to the heroes‚Äô home. The home that they share, since they are not only coworkers, classmates, or friends, as Izuku first assumed. Follow. Izuku can do that. Simple, easy, no need to think about anything at all. He nods. Present Mic smiles and Izuku tries to forget the feeling of warm, tight pressure that has settled into the bones of his hand like a craving.

‚ÄúO-oh. Well, uh, s-sir‚Äì‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt call me sir.‚Äù

Izuku‚Äôs mouth clicks shut. Present Mic, obviously holding back laughter, crosses his arms and leans against the wall. ‚ÄúY-yes, sir.‚Äù

‚ÄúBusiness!‚Äù Present ‚Äì no, just Mic ‚Äì prompts from the kitchen.

‚ÄúRight. Well, the important stuff was all covered in Nedzu‚Äôs proposal. If you want or need anything, ask me or Hizashi. Izuku rolls halfway over, stretching out an arm towards the door without thinking or looking. If he thinks, he‚Äôll say no, and if he looks, he‚Äôll have to think. He reaches out, and unseen, unthought of, Present Mic reaches back, grabbing Izuku by the elbow and pulling him into his arms.

Izuku has been so cold for so long that it hurts to thaw. Life stings when frozen blood finally creeps back into nearly-dead tissue. He‚Äôll look at himself and think that it‚Äôs a miracle he has all of his fingers and toes when he has been freezing for years. Maybe he has lost other bits of himself, instead.

But Present Mic is warm. He is warm and he smells like leather and some kind of citrusy hair product, and he holds Izuku just tightly enough that he can feel the solid resistance of his own bones, just tightly enough to keep Izuku‚Äôs soul from trying to slip out of his skin.

And Present Mic doesn‚Äôt pull away, he just keeps holding Izuku perfectly tight, even when Izuku starts crying again, even when Izuku can‚Äôt cry anymore and just breathes long, shuddering breaths. Present Mic doesn‚Äôt pull away, even when Izuku‚Äôs eyelids start to flutter, and his fingers go slack and fall limp.

Izuku falls asleep with a heartbeat in his ears, loud enough to drown out the screams of the ghosts that usually follow him into unconsciousness. He sleeps and he hears, you‚Äôre safe here, you can rest now, and this time it sounds like a blessing in more ways than one.

Chapter Text

This is how the end begins:

Tomura stands in the doorway of Izuku‚Äôs room. It looks more like Kurogiri‚Äôs work than Izuku‚Äôs, but Tomura knows that Kurogiri has not been in here since ‚Äì since.

Crossing from the doorway into the room is too easy. It feels like a barrier should pop up to stop him, like he should face some kind of resistance, something more solid than stagnant air. He sits on the bed, throwing himself down and squirming slightly to muss up the too-perfect blankets. To make it look like someone lives here ‚Äì because someone does, someone did.

Tomura pulls Izuku‚Äôs phone out of his pocket. There is no lock on it. There‚Äôs not much of anything at all on it.

Three numbers ‚Äì Sensei‚Äôs, Kurogiri‚Äôs, and Tomura‚Äôs own.

A few puzzle games.

A news app.

Less than a dozen photos.

Only one of them is of Izuku. That‚Äôs the one Tomura stares at. He zooms in past his own face, scrunched up and unimpressed, until Izuku fills the screen, beaming and enthusiastic. He looks happy, Tomura thinks. Tomura had thought he was happy. Maybe not all the time, but in general, certainly. Happy with Tomura. They had been happy, hadn‚Äôt they?

‚ÄúAh,‚Äù Kurogiri‚Äôs voice breaks the silence, ‚ÄúI was wondering where his phone went.‚Äù His voice is carefully neutral, smooth and slippery enough that Tomura can‚Äôt get a grip on what he‚Äôs thinking.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôll want it when he comes back.‚Äù

‚ÄúMush,‚Äù he says. His transport doesn‚Äôt move. He sighs, ‚ÄúWalk forward. As quickly as you can without slipping or running into anyone.‚Äù

They get through the tunnel with surprising speed, picking their way steadily across the ice, weaving through the clumps of people who‚Äôre still frozen up to the ankles. It would probably be faster to run forward on his own, but Hitoshi isn‚Äôt winning any races on his own stamina, so it seems wise to save that energy for the inevitable obstacle that he won‚Äôt be able to get someone else to do for him.

In front of him, the students of class 1-A shout at each other. Bakugou Katsuki blasts himself forward with his explosions, in hot pursuit of the boy with the candy cane hair. The pink skinned girl glides easily over the ice. The boy with the tail barely touches the ground as he springs off it with powerful and well-practiced motions. Hitoshi watches them, chin propped in his hand, elbow resting on his knee.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre used to using their quirks,‚Äù he tells the boy at the head of the carry formation. Of course, the boy doesn‚Äôt reply, doesn‚Äôt react at all, since it‚Äôs not an order. ‚ÄúExplosions are an easy thing to practice. He probably had people begging him to show it off. Bet they never threatened to put him in ‚Äì I don‚Äôt know, steel gloves or something, just so he couldn‚Äôt use it.‚Äù Hitoshi sneers, rubbing at the bridge of his nose. There is still a small divot there, invisible except to his fingertips.

A loud crash brings him back to the present, but the hulking green metal beast in the middle of the track nearly threatens to send him tumbling back into bitter recollections. Gears and hydraulics grind together audibly as the thing turns towards the students, several of whom trip over themselves in their attempts to abruptly reverse their momentum. The lenses within its eye rotate, red light dancing over the glass.

‚ÄúTargets found,‚Äù an electronic voice announces. Then it adds, with a sadistic glee that machinery should not be capable of, ‚ÄúLots!‚Äù

Fucking robots. Just great. Right in Hitoshi‚Äôs skillset.  

 

 

Izuku walks into the stadium with a mob of seventy-some general education students who pay him no attention. They are all occupied with each other, excited or nervous as they bunch together in little friend groups. On the fringes of the crowd, Wallflower tingles against Izuku‚Äôs skin. There is no real, tangible sensation associated with using the quirk, but the knowledge that it is active ‚Äì that he can slip by unnoticed, his presence crystal clear and unobtrusive ‚Äì settles over his shoulders like a heavy blanket.

Of course, Wallflower isn‚Äôt effective in photo or video. Izuku darts occasional nervous glances to drones hovering around. Certainly, he is on TV, somewhere, a blur of green and navy caught in some broad overhead shot, but for the most part, the cameras either take the whole scene in from an anonymous distance or focus on the hero students.

At the center of the arena, Midnight ‚Äì quirk: Somnambulist ‚Äì stands on a small stage, one hand on her hip, the other gesturing with a multi-tasseled flog. His interactions with ‚ÄúAuntie Nemuri‚Äù ‚Äì self-proclaimed, very loudly, upon their first meeting in the staff room ‚Äì have all been rather brief, but this is his first time seeing her in her hero regalia in person. One of his notebooks ‚Äì volume 11, page 73 ‚Äì has a full redesign of her costume. He had only been twelve or thirteen when he made it, so it‚Äôs a bit outdated at this point, but he wonders if it would be too presumptuous to share it with her, anyway. She‚Äôs a grown woman, of course, and she can dress however she likes, it‚Äôs just ‚Äì well, it doesn‚Äôt look particularly comfortable? Or practical, for that matter. And it feels a little indecent to actually look at her.

Anyway, that‚Äôs irrelevant. She cracks her flog, a surprisingly sharp sound for how small it is, probably to cut off trains of thought exactly like Izuku‚Äôs. Dutifully, he gives her his attention, and pointedly does not think about how a better chest piece could be made that actually provides coverage and support while still paying homage to a harness.

‚ÄúQuiet, everyone!‚Äù she calls. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs time for our player pledge! Representing the students this year is Bakugou Katsuki, from class 1-A!‚Äù

‚ÄúThat guy?‚Äù someone ‚Äì minor transformation quirk, based in their hands ‚Äì asks, under their breath, but still too loud to be discrete.

‚ÄúHe did finish first in the entrance exam,‚Äù Sero Hanta ‚Äì quirk: Tape ‚Äì says, smiling sheepishly.

‚ÄúMaybe on the heroics exam,‚Äù another person ‚Äì emitter quirk, something to do with minerals ‚Äì scoffs. Katsuki had been near the top of the written exam, as well, Izuku happens to know. Nedzu is far to liberal with the information he allows Izuku to access, and the students‚Äô scores and rankings were noted right alongside the recordings from their practical exams, which Izuku has already watched at least three times.

Katsuki stands on the stage, glare harsh and unwavering as he waits, settling for nothing less than everyone‚Äôs full attention. ‚ÄúI pledge that I‚Äôll be number one,‚Äù he says finally, voice crackling through speakers from all directions. The silence that Katsuki waited for breaks in an instant. Groans from class A, including a boisterous scolding from Iida Tenya ‚Äì quirk: Engine. Indignant shouts from class B, scoffs and sneers from the other courses. Katsuki‚Äôs eyes ‚Äì red, fierce, and indifferent to the outcry ‚Äì skim over the crowd, resting on Izuku for a chilling half second before sliding away.

‚ÄúAt least be nice stepping stones for me,‚Äù Katsuki adds. And that is apparently all he has to say. He tosses the microphone to Midnight without even looking at her and hops down from the stage.

‚ÄúHow overconfident can you get?!‚Äù class B‚Äôs Tetsutetsu Tetsutetsu ‚Äì quirk: Steel ‚Äì yells, straining against the arms of a classmate who seems to be considering just letting him have at it. Katsuki doesn‚Äôt spare him a glance, standing with his jaw set next to an exasperated Kirishima Eijiro ‚Äì quirk: Hardening.

Izuku sighs softly to himself. Katsuki is‚Ä¶ different than he remembers. Different and also painfully unchanged. Giving his all, to the exclusion of caring what anyone else has to bring to the table. Obsessed with a very particular kind of strength. Stubborn and rigid to the point of severity, sometimes even savagery. But he is probably the least confident Izuku has ever seen him. Overconfident people don‚Äôt clench their fists and glare at the world like it is an enemy to be defeated.

‚ÄúNow, let‚Äôs gets started right away,‚Äù Midnight announces, compensating for Katsuki‚Äôs spectacle with even more theatric bravado. ‚ÄúOur first game will be the qualifier! Every year, countless sports festival hopefuls become sports festival has-beens in this round. Let‚Äôs see if you have what it takes, shall we?‚Äù

Izuku stands up straight. He knows she isn‚Äôt talking to him ‚Äì she may know he‚Äôs here, but she can‚Äôt even see him. The words are for each and every student there, over 200 people, but of all of them, Izuku is willing to bet that he has the most to prove. Prove he has what it takes, prove he‚Äôs worth it, prove it isn‚Äôt a mistake to give him this chance. Prove that he can be something more than what he has been so far.

Several others in the crowd stand straighter as well, square their shoulders as if Midnight is talking to them, specifically. Izuku may have the most to prove, but he is not the only one here with a purpose. One way or another, dreams will be crushed today. Do they have what it takes? The only way you learn to fly is by falling and hoping you don‚Äôt hit the ground.

Midnight makes a production of revealing the first event, but Izuku pays little attention to the dramatics. First, they‚Äôll be doing an obstacle course race, then a cavalry battle, and finally the one-on-one matches that always determine the winner. The events were decided before Izuku arrived at UA, likely close to the beginning of the year, possibly even earlier. Izuku has known about each event since his third day at the school.

It's not like he went snooping on purpose. It‚Äôs just that Nedzu is sometimes very careless about the information he leaves laying around his office. Well, ‚Äúcareless‚Äù and ‚Äúlaying around‚Äù are probably an obtuse way of putting it, since Izuku is reasonably certain the principal did it intentionally. He‚Äôs reasonably certain the principal does everything intentionally. Izuku ignored the plans when he first saw them, but later that day they had worked their way into his English packet ‚Äì appropriately translated and everything, so he hadn‚Äôt even realized what they were right away.

So, by the end of his third day, Izuku had known the structure of the sports festival, though not any of the details as to what the events would contain. He‚Äôs still uncertain whether Nedzu‚Äôs deliberate dispensing of inside information is some kind of test or a genuine attempt to assist him. Knowing Nedzu, it could very well be a mix of both, but Izuku doubts he‚Äôll ever get an answer, either way.

When the crowd suddenly swarms towards the gates leading out onto the course, Izuku hangs back. At this point, leading the pack would be counter intuitive ‚Äì it wouldn‚Äôt gain him anything in the long term, and the dubious honor of being at the front would inevitably draw attention to him, even with Wallflower active. Besides, the tunnel on the other side of the gate is a long, narrow thing, an obvious choke point that‚Äôs going to result in at least several dozen eager front runners getting jostled and bruised and far more exhausted than they should be this early in the competition. Izuku shudders slightly just at the thought of being pressed in so closely to so many people.

The gates open and the crowd floods through, immediately clogging the tunnel. Izuku waits and counts in his head.

It takes six and a half seconds for the real race to start.

It is Todoroki Shouto ‚Äì quirk: Half-Cold Half-Hot ‚Äì who starts it. As one of the hero course‚Äôs powerhouses, with a quirk well suited crowd control, it‚Äôs no surprise that he‚Äôs the one taking the initiative. When it comes to flashy and game changing displays of quirk use, Todoroki was really one of very few candidates for kicking things off properly, far more than three lights and a buzzer ever could.

After all, this isn‚Äôt a middle school foot race. This is UA‚Äôs sports festival. This is where heroes are born.

Todoroki‚Äôs onslaught has left over half of the students in the tunnel and just beyond it frozen fast to the ground. With the race moving forward, Izuku finally enters the tunnel himself, weaving carefully through the trapped students, more concerned about accidentally bumping into one of them than he is about the ice.

Enhancement quirks are incredibly common, and thus something Izuku has in abundance ‚Äì strength, speed, senses, reflexes, balance, you name it. Izuku has multiple of each, and it is a simple matter to activate a couple of well-practiced ones to handle the situation. Balance, to keep his feet; reflexes to give him the reaction time he needs to make adjustments as soon as he starts to slip.

It is quirks like these that Izuku is planning to use to carry himself as far as possible in the festival. Versatile, and powerful in that versatility, but unobtrusive, sometimes even unnoticeable if properly applied.

The subtle interplay of multiple slight improvements is effective, but it is nothing compared to what is happening ahead of him.

Kirishima Eijiro ‚Äì quirk: Hardening ‚Äì laughs, adrenaline giddy as he leaps over the wave of ice that has consumed the entire beginning of the course, creeping high up the wall around the tunnel mouth. Aoyama Yuga ‚Äì quirk: Navel Laser ‚Äì propels himself forward without touching the ground, winking to the people stuck behind him. Yaoyorozu Momo ‚Äì quirk: Creation ‚Äì produces a strong, thin pole from her palm, vaulting the ice with grim determination. It takes only a second for Ojiro Mashirao ‚Äì quirk: Tail ‚Äì to find a clean patch of ground and use it to spring himself to safety. And with Dark Shadow‚Äôs aid, avoiding the ground is trivial for Tokoyami Fumikage ‚Äì quirk:‚Äì

Actually, it is probably best not to think about that, right now. After spending so much time suppressed, the influx of information from Izuku‚Äôs quirk is novel and nearly overwhelming. To be around so many people, all actively using such amazing quirks is a fascination that Izuku can‚Äôt currently afford to be distracted by.

‚ÄúYou half-and-half bastard!‚Äù Katsuki shouts, voice almost shrill compared to the bone-rumbling bass of his explosions. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not getting away that easy, fucking coward!‚Äù

Todoroki, running with ice chasing his heels, looks back over his shoulder for a brief moment, not slowing as he quickly assesses his classmates. He says nothing in response before turning away, leaning forward as he pushes himself to move faster. Katsuki screams behind him, a wordless sound of frustration as the distance separating them remains stagnant.

 Kirishima shouts as well, but his sharp-toothed grin speaks more of excitement than anger. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs so man‚Äì‚Äù He is slammed to the side, exclamation cut off by a grunt. He goes flying, rolling to the ground nearly ten feet from where he had been, but he pops up unharmed only a moment later.

‚ÄúWarn a guy!‚Äù he shouts at the robot that just flicked him aside like a piece of lint. Its eye glints, red light wavering as the aperture within it expands and contracts with a series of soft clicks.

‚ÄúTargets found,‚Äù the robot declares. ‚ÄúLots!‚Äù

Distantly, Izuku hears Mic shouting about the ‚ÄúRobo Inferno‚Äù as a swarm of massive robots become visible beyond this cluster of smaller ones. He has watched the footage of the entrance exams enough times to immediately identify each of the robots, even down to their assigned point values. He hadn‚Äôt liked them then, somewhat blurry on a computer monitor, and he doesn‚Äôt like them now, solid and imposing and less than thirty feet away.

‚ÄúAren‚Äôt those the zero point villains from the entrance exam?‚Äù Kaminari Denki ‚Äì quirk: no, focus Izuku ‚Äì asks, a nervous lilt to his voice. He takes half a step backwards, but then seems to catch himself, steeling his stance.

‚ÄúSeriously? The hero course had to fight those?‚Äù

‚ÄúThis is what they meant by obstacles?!‚Äù

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs too many! What are we supposed to do?‚Äù

The outcry from the general education and business students is mixed anxiety and indignation, and Izuku can‚Äôt say he blames them. As much as the sports festival is lauded as a school event, it‚Äôs not. Not really. It‚Äôs a hero course event. They‚Äôre the stars, the ones set up to succeed, to benefit, and everyone else is just an extra body to the head count, to make things seem just a little bit more competitive. After all, it‚Äôs far more interesting to pick only three winners out of over 200, rather than a measly forty.

And if you weren‚Äôt in the hero course, but you wanted to be? Then hopefully you spent the months since the entrance exam learning to fight robots.

‚ÄúSo, this is what they used in the general entrance exam?‚Äù Todoroki asks. He sounds as unimpressed as Izuku feels, though it‚Äôs hard to say if he also thinks the robots are ridiculous or if that‚Äôs just the way his voice is.

‚ÄúI wonder where they got the money for it,‚Äù Yaoyorozu says. Like Todoroki, she is unintimated by the army of titans in front of them, her voice only idly curious, even as one of the robots begins to reach forward, its splayed-out claw larger than any person.

Todoroki sighs. ‚ÄúAll this trouble for nothing. I wish they would have at least prepared something more impressive. Give my stupid old man something to watch.‚Äù

The zero pointer is fast for its size, and by the time Todoroki‚Äôs last, bitter word falls from his mouth, it is close enough to him that Izuku‚Äôs whole body has gone tense, prepared to move at a moment‚Äôs notice, in case he needs to take action. But Todoroki merely glares at the obstacle, mismatched eyes glacial.

Frost builds up along his right arm, pale blue and sparkling in the sun. When Todoroki puts that hand to the ground, ice blooms in a perfect circle around him. With rapt attention, Izuku watches Todoroki drag his fingers along the dirt, raising his arm in a wide, sweeping arc. The gesture is almost casual ‚Äì confident and decisive, but lacking force, a fluidly graceful movement. The surge of ice that follows the movement is, in contrast, powerful and jagged. It races up the zero pointer‚Äôs arm, halting the robot‚Äôs movements almost instantly. Ice crackles and metal groans. In seconds, the only army green metal left exposed is near the very top of the bot‚Äôs head, crags of ice rising around it like a crown. The entire zero pointer, hundreds of feet tall, frozen in a single, simple act.

Todoroki exhales, slow and measured. His breath billows in front of him, a cold white fog that drifts away on the breeze. He fists his hand in front of him, still hovering in the air where the swipe of his arm ended, still speckled with glittering crystals of frost. For a moment, it is like everything is frozen, like the entire obstacle course and everyone on it is just as trapped in place as that robot.

Todoroki himself is the first one to shatter the stillness, running forward along the path between the robot‚Äôs legs. As monstrous as it is, the zero pointer casts a large shadow, but sunlight bounces oddly between the facets of the ice, and strange, wavering reflections dance over Todoroki‚Äôs skin as he passes underneath.

‚ÄúHe stopped them,‚Äù someone breathes as the rest of the crowd starts to stir.

‚ÄúFollow him,‚Äù someone else says, awed disbelief beginning to fade back into the frantic determination of competition. ‚ÄúThrough the legs, there‚Äôs a path!‚Äù

‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt do that if I were you,‚Äù Todoroki shouts back over his shoulder. ‚ÄúIt was already unbalanced when I froze it. It‚Äôll fall over.‚Äù

On cue, the ice creaks. A wide fissure traces up the zero pointer‚Äôs base as huge sheets of ice start to crack away from its reaching arm. They shatter when they hit the ground, shrapnel flying in all directions. A sliver scrapes against Izuku‚Äôs cheek, a cold needle that melts against his skin in only a few seconds. More and more ice gives way, a cataclysmic reaction that goes from bad to worse, only speeding up as it continues along. People stumble out of the way, making frenzied dives to the sides as the zero pointer wobbles.

Then, exactly as Todoroki predicted, the entire thing comes crashing down.

Izuku, already safe exactly where he is, stares at the carnage.

‚ÄúTodoroki Shouto from class 1-A!‚Äù Mic shouts, drawing out the syllables of the name. ‚ÄúIn one move, he made an opening for himself and closed it for everyone else! An attack and a defense all in one! How elegant! Amazing!‚Äù

‚ÄúHis actions are logical and strategic,‚Äù Eraser agrees, practically effusive praise coming from him.

‚ÄúAs expected of a recommendation student! And the son of the number two hero, at that! Those Robo Infernos never stood a chance!‚Äù

And as the dust settles and the yelling starts up again, Izuku can‚Äôt help but wonder ‚Äì who exactly is Todoroki Shouto? And what is he trying to prove?

Chapter Text

Oh WOW, the hero course really does get all the best stuff! Mei has heard rumors, of course, about the practical exam that pit hero students against marvelous mechanics, exciting examples of engineering, big beautiful bots, and Maijima-Sensei had indulged some of her questions near the beginning of term, but nothing compares to getting to see them in person. The one, two, and three pointers ‚Äì well, they‚Äôre cute, for sure, but the zero pointers ‚Äì the zero pointers! Mei wants to take one apart and climb inside and figure out how it works. As big as they are, she could probably spend weeks ‚Äì no, months! ‚Äì crawling around its wiring and wouldn‚Äôt that just be a dream.

Of course, she can‚Äôt really get close to one without it trying to kill her. Actually, no ‚Äì this is a school event, after all, so she would probably only end up lightly maimed at worst, but what a way to go! Frosty really did her a favor, knocking over that first one. No death or maiming required, just her and what seems like miles of steel and copper. The fall has even knocked off some of the outer paneling ‚Äì which is a shame, such a shame to see such a beauty broken to bits, BUT‚Äì! But this way she has free access to its inner workings! Which is perfect because robots actually are more beautiful on the inside ‚Äì unlike people, who are actually just very wet and squishy on the inside, no matter what everyone says.

She scrambles up over the zero pointer‚Äôs arm to get a look at the joint there. Her hover boots are a big help in scaling the smooth plates, just like she knew they would be! She splays herself out over the metal, ignoring the ice-chill of it that seeps through her gym uniform, focusing her eyes until the intricate wiring and segmented metal sections of the elbow take up her entire field of view. It‚Äôs brilliant! One of the best things she‚Äôs ever seen, maybe, and AHHH she wishes she had a notebook with her.

Thank god for the marker she keeps with her goggles. There‚Äôs a little pocket along the side of the band specifically for her to slip in her favorite drafting pen ‚Äì this way she never needs to worry about losing it. A pen is an indispensable tool for anyone with a creative mind, after all! Paper ‚Äì well, paper would be nice, but that‚Äôs an easy thing to work around. Now, Mei generally wouldn‚Äôt recommend drawing a schematic on your arm ‚Äì it‚Äôs hard to keep measurements and angles true to life on an elastic, curved surface ‚Äì but it‚Äôll do in a pinch! Ideas have to be seized as soon as they present themselves, even if that means making do with improvised tools.

One moment, Mei is sketching away, tongue poking out slightly in concentration ‚Äì and the next she is on the ground, a metallic taste coating the roof of her mouth.

Accidents happen to Mei all the time. Explosions are part of the process, after all, and sometimes that process happens directly in her face while she‚Äôs focused on some detail or another. So, she‚Äôs quick at bouncing back ‚Äì it‚Äôs one of her many very impressive talents! Which is why it only takes her a couple of blinks to recover after the quick swish and CRASH that have her sliding over and off the zero pointer‚Äôs arm and onto the hard packed dirt of the obstacle course track. She licks blood off her teeth, sticking her tongue out and crossing her eyes to see the shallow bite marks there.

‚ÄúOh my god, are you a-alright?‚Äù A boy slides down the side of the robot‚Äôs arm, knees bending to absorb the impact as he lands. OH, that reminds her ‚Äì shock absorption! There‚Äôs probably lots of cool babies for that, and Mei hasn‚Äôt made any yet. What a terrible oversight.

‚ÄúOh no,‚Äù Mei says as she sits up.

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt h-hurt you, did I?!‚Äù the boy asks as Mei looks around. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm so s-sorry, it‚Äôs just, there was this three pointer, and you seemed really d-distracted so I‚Äì‚Äù

‚ÄúHave you seen my pen?‚Äù Mei interrupts. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a really good pen and I need it!‚Äù

‚ÄúY-your pen‚Ä¶?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah! It‚Äôs black, approximately yea long,‚Äù she holds her fingers and appropriately pen-sized distance apart to illustrate. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs got pink tape on it! With yellow stars! I was using it when I fell, it must have flown off somewhere. Say, did you push me or something?‚Äù The boy opens and closely his mouth wordlessly and after a moment of that, Mei waves him off. ‚ÄúYeah, okay, that‚Äôs not important! Your mission, should you choose to accept it, is to help me find my pen!‚Äù The boy blinks at the finger Mei points at him like he is staring down the barrel of a gun, and she giggles at the dumbfounded expression smeared across his face.

‚ÄúI, uh ‚Äì alright?‚Äù

As silly as his wide eyes and slack mouth are, Mei has to give it to the boy ‚Äì he is a very dedicated and adept pen-finder! By the time she is done checking over all her babies to make sure none of them got damaged in that nasty fall, he is already done. She gasps happily when he hands it over.

Next to her smudged and half-complete diagram of the zero pointer‚Äôs wiring, Mei jots down a note about shock absorption. When she looks back up, the boy is gone.

 

 

Here are some facts about Hitoshi.

The first is that he recently went through a growth spurt. He went from 5‚Äô7‚Äù to 5‚Äô10‚Äù in only a few weeks, and he‚Äôs still growing, steadily creeping closer to 5‚Äô11‚Äù. These days, his dad regularly laments the constant need to buy him new pants. Hitoshi‚Äôs uniform is already a touch too short around his ankles and wrists, even though they had intentionally been slightly too long at the start of term.

The second follows from the first: Hitoshi does not have a particularly good sense of balance. It‚Äôs not that he‚Äôs clumsy, per say, but he‚Äôs still getting used to all of his limbs suddenly being in new places. So yeah, he sometimes bumps into things or trips over himself ‚Äì whatever, sue him, he‚Äôs a teenaged boy and puberty is a bitch.

The third and final fact is that Hitoshi isn‚Äôt a fan of heights. To be perfectly clear, he isn‚Äôt afraid of them. He‚Äôs just not a fan. Which is pretty normal, really. Who actually likes heights? That would be weird. Not liking heights is just the default human condition, and it‚Äôs not a big deal or anything, but sure, they make him a little uncomfortable and that‚Äôs all instinct.

These three things combined find Hitoshi standing at the edge of The Fall ‚Äì a bit on the nose, that name ‚Äì with his eyes closed for just a moment while he takes a bracing breath. First robots, now this shit. Hitoshi had known coming into the festival that things would be stacked against him, that he would have to fight like hell to get through, but this is starting to feel a little personal.

He doesn‚Äôt bother with trying to tightrope walk across. He just bids his dignity goodbye and hopes that all the cameras are too occupied with the flashy hero students to pay attention to the random gen ed kid who managed to work his way up the ranks. His thighs burn as he crosses his legs around the rope and shimmies along; his palms burn from gripping the coarse fibers; his ears and neck burn from embarrassment that he stoically pretends not to be feeling.

Man, he really should have nabbed that support girl when he had the chance. Who the hell knows what her quirk is, but who the hell cares when she has all those gadgets to do the job for her. She had a jetpack. Hitoshi could have been jetpacking across, right now. Doing things on his own power really is overrated.

Progress is uncomfortable, but it‚Äôs steady. Hitoshi, at the very least, is still in the race, which is more than can be said for the poor fools he sees losing their grip and falling all around him. He‚Äôs doing well ‚Äì well enough to be proud of himself along side the bitter frustration of the situation and the irritated disgust of sweat dripping into his eyes. All the frustration and discomfort and embarrassment will be worth it, when he makes it to the other side. And he is going to make it, he‚Äôs certain of that much.

Or at least, he is until some idiot ‚Äì some idiot, some flash bastard, some hero course asshole ‚Äì leaps over Hitoshi like he is a hurdle in a fucking track competition. The rope shudders, waves of movement traveling up and down its entire length, and just like that, Hitoshi loses his grip, like all the poor fools he was lamenting mere moments ago.

Yuga wants to be an inspiration. He wants stars to be born in peoples‚Äô eyes when they look at him. He wants to be a beacon of light that never goes out.
