‚ÄúIt was nice while it lasted,‚Äù Hitoshi says faintly. ‚ÄúDamn it. Fuck.‚Äù

Midoriya looks at him, the most acknowledgement he has given so far to anything Hitoshi has said. Hitoshi laughs, and Midoriya gives him the moment, not attacking. Burns have spread across his face, a new blister rising on his cheek, freckles standing out oddly against the redness of his skin. His eyebrows are singed and asymmetrical, the tail of one burnt off.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm jealous,‚Äù Hitoshi admits, apropos of nothing. Maybe it‚Äôs a last-ditch effort, maybe it‚Äôs just something that needs to be said. Who knows. ‚ÄúEveryone has always told me that I have a villain‚Äôs quirk. They say it with so much certainty that it‚Äôs like they want me to become one. Like it doesn‚Äôt matter that all I want is to be a hero. And you ‚Äì you literally have a hero‚Äôs quirk. Endeavor is the number two! All he does is make fire; you can actually control it. It‚Äôs just ‚Äì that‚Äôs so fucking ironic.‚Äù

Hitoshi, with his villain‚Äôs quirk, striving to be a hero. Midoriya, with his hero‚Äôs quirk, possibly a villain.

‚ÄúIt would almost be funny, if we weren‚Äôt the butt of the joke.‚Äù

Hitoshi blinks. It is the same higher-pitched-than-expected voice that surprised him when he first ran into Midoriya in the hallway last week, an even more surprising sound now, when Midoriya is fierce and flaming and so stubbornly silent. But that was definitely Midoriya‚Äôs voice, and the connection blossoms at the back of Hitoshi‚Äôs head waiting for him to grab hold and complete it. He does, of course he does, and Midoriya‚Äôs eyes, already so disconcertingly blank, fog over. Hitoshi holds on tight to his command, feels as the tether strains slightly on Midoriya‚Äôs end, but it doesn‚Äôt give.

Hitoshi doesn‚Äôt know what changed. Maybe with Hitoshi prone on the ground, Midoriya thought he was defenseless. Maybe Midoriya‚Äôs stunt with a face full of fire has somehow messed up his head. Maybe Hitoshi‚Äôs glancing implication to Midoriya‚Äôs villain background had unbalanced him enough to trick him into responding. Hitoshi doesn‚Äôt know, and he can‚Äôt bring himself to care.

‚ÄúWalk out of bounds,‚Äù he says.

Midoriya does.

Hitoshi laughs to himself. A finalist. He‚Äôs moving on to the final round. Somehow, he managed to come out of his fight with Midoriya less injured than he did his match with Monoma, and now he‚Äôs a finalist.

Here‚Äôs to spite and a contrary disposition, he thinks, a giddy toast in his head. They haven‚Äôt failed him yet.

 

 

Everyone will know exactly what happens during the sports festival. Ask anyone and they‚Äôll agree. Shinsou Hitoshi beats Monoma Neito. Shoji Mezo beats Asui Tsuyu. Bakugou Katsuki beats Iida Tenya.

Shinsou Hitoshi beats Midoriya Izuku.

That‚Äôs all anyone will ever say.

Except there are a million sides to every story. Doesn‚Äôt it seem a shame to leave so many untold?

Everyone will know that Shinsou Hitoshi beats Midoriya Izuku.

But only Shinsou Hitoshi knows that he didn‚Äôt even have to use his trump card, that he won without resorting to the nuclear option, that he moved that one step closer to fulfilling his dreams without compromising his own idea of what it means to be a good person. Only Aizawa Shouta knows that he was rooting for Shinsou in the back of his head, because he has a soft spot for underdogs ‚Äì secret or not so secret depending on who you ask ‚Äì and as much as Izuku needs help and support to build confidence, his capability has never been under question. Only Bakugou Katsuki knows that the festival might as well have ended right there with that match, because none of it matters anymore, not with Deku out of the running, because he was the only challenge on the bracket, the only one who has ever made Katsuki feel weak and without fighting Deku at the end, without beating him, there‚Äôs no way Katsuki can show everyone how strong he really is. Only Shigaraki Tomura knows that it‚Äôs all a sham, because the boy standing on screen used to stand by his side and Izuku could destroy each and every one of them ‚Äì could and would, leave others to clean up the throats he slits ‚Äì and Tomura knows that there‚Äôs no such thing as heroes and villains, not really, all just people who hurt other people, violence bred from violence until death is the only language everyone can understand.

And only Midoriya Izuku knows that there was never a way for him to win, not really, because there's no black and white in his world, and when everything is shades of grey, sometimes even a victory can look like a loss.

 

 

Shinsou Hitoshi is surprising.

That‚Äôs what Izuku thinks as he claws at the fabric covering his face with his free hand ‚Äì his other, still fisted in the collar of the jacket that is now restraining him, is caught next to his ear, and his shoulder strains uncomfortably if he tries to free it. This is a resourcefulness that Izuku wasn‚Äôt expecting, though it‚Äôs nice to see, since it adds some depth to Shinsou‚Äôs skillset, that seems otherwise one-dimensional. So far, he‚Äôd been relying solely on his quirk, and this display of adaptability implies he has more potential than Izuku had begun to suspect.

Izuku still hesitates to call Shinsou clever or particularly strategic. He pulls the jacket tight to Izuku‚Äôs face, yanking back against it as Izuku struggles to free himself, but he lacks follow-up. Restraining Izuku like this is ultimately useless on its own, only the first of what should be several essential steps if Shinsou actually plans to win.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre looking a little tied up,‚Äù Shinsou says, voice close to Izuku‚Äôs ear but muffled by fabric and his own breathlessness. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd get it if you wanted to call it quits. No hard feelings, promise.‚Äù

He‚Äôs trying, Izuku will give him that much, but he‚Äôs using the same old tricks that have already proven ineffective. It‚Äôs a weak attempt to garner a response ‚Äì trivial words, like un-baited hooks. Izuku feels no compulsion to banter with someone in the middle of a fight, especially when he knows the consequences of doing so. Did Shinsou manage to catch Aoyama and Monoma with so little effort?

Another sharp pull on the jacket cranes Izuku‚Äôs neck into an uncomfortable angle, and he lets himself go slightly limp to relieve the stress. This is getting them nowhere. He sighs, clicks it in the back of his throat, lets his breath come out hot and suffocating. There is a moment, before fabric gives way as fibers disintegrate into ash, where Izuku feels like he is boiling, and then he stumbles forward, unbound. The air, heated into wavering lines by the flames dancing around him, feels blessedly cool against his flame-tender face. Behind him, Shinsou makes a bitten off sound of pain, falling to the ground with a thud that reverberates up Izuku‚Äôs ankles. Izuku pulls his new fire into unruly organization, gathering the sparks flitting through the air into a continuous stream that circles around him.

‚ÄúIt was nice while it lasted,‚Äù Shinsou says, seemingly to himself. His voice, soft and faint, grows frustrated as he adds, ‚ÄúDamn it. Fuck.‚Äù

Izuku turns back to face him. Shinsou sits on the ground, long legs sprawled in front of him, propped up on one hand. The other, the one Recovery Girl tutted over when he visited the infirmary after his match with Monoma, hovers limply in front of his abdomen. A lividly red welt stands out against his skin, starting near his wrist and curving back around his arm, nearly to his elbow. He laughs, strange and strained.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm jealous,‚Äù Shinsou says, a sharp-edged confession. ‚ÄúEveryone has always told me that I have a villain‚Äôs quirk. They say it with so much certainty that it‚Äôs like they want me to become one. Like it doesn‚Äôt matter that all I want is to be a hero.‚Äù

Shinsou looks tired. Angry, too, but the anger is like a faded, threadbare thing ‚Äì an old blanket that is too worn away to keep him warm anymore. The tiredness, that‚Äôs more like stone ‚Äì heavy and lasting, changed only in the tiny, unnoticeable increments of erosion. His eyes spark and dim, challenge and resignation in turns.

And Izuku remembers Aizawa Shouta.

It feels like a lifetime since Izuku has thought of Aizawa Shouta, even though it‚Äôs only been a couple of weeks since he first learned the name. So much has changed since then, and now Izuku thinks more of Eraserhead than the boy who became the hero. But it was Aizawa Shouta who brought Izuku here, Aizawa Shouta who made himself a hero when the world didn‚Äôt want him to be one, who fought and defied and preserved.

Shinsou Hitoshi is a bit like Aizawa Shouta. He‚Äôs not as skilled ‚Äì at least, not yet ‚Äì and he relies far too much on his quirk, where Aizawa Shouta always knew that his greatest strength was skill. But even beaten down, Shinsou is fighting back. Writing his own story.

Shinsou is more like Aizawa Shouta than Izuku could ever hope to be.

‚ÄúAnd you,‚Äù Shinsou continues, swallowing bitterly around the words, ‚Äúyou literally have a hero‚Äôs quirk. Endeavor is the number two! All he does is make fire; you can actually control it. It‚Äôs just,‚Äù he laughs without humor, ‚Äúthat‚Äôs so fucking ironic.‚Äù

A hero‚Äôs quirk. If only Shinsou knew, Izuku thinks wryly.

There is nothing heroic about him, especially not the Frankenstein amalgamation of stolen quirks that he is using to put on a show. Izuku has fooled them all so well ‚Äì the audience members who are cheering for him from the stands, Aoyama and Tokoyami who want to eat lunch with him, Eraser and Mic who let him sleep down the hall, Shinsou who doesn‚Äôt know the half of it.

Irony ‚Äì a state of affairs opposite to what one would expect. Why should Izuku get a second chance when Shinsou Hitoshi hasn‚Äôt even gotten his first? Izuku is trying to be good, isn‚Äôt he? If he wins here, he‚Äôll be adding Shinsou‚Äôs future onto the long list of things he has stolen. Nothing good about that.

‚ÄúIt would almost be funny,‚Äù Izuku says, because irony is meant to be amusing, even if it‚Äôs not this time, ‚Äúif we weren‚Äôt the butt of the joke.‚Äù

The surprise in Shinsou‚Äôs eyes is blatant, but he doesn‚Äôt hesitate. He has Izuku under his control in less than a second.

Brainwashing is a fuzzy grey space. It is a fog so dense that it cradles Izuku, supporting his limbs, filling his eyes and nose and ears. It is even better than the emotional suppression quirk. Nothing to do, no responsibilities. Just a hazy-warm embrace, like falling asleep in the backseat of a car on a long drive, knowing your destination will come to you. Izuku can see why people hate it so much, after the fact. Some must find it terrible, to have your agency taken away from you between one moment and the next, and then to find the violation of your will comforting. Izuku doesn‚Äôt mind it.

He presses back against the fog around him, and as soft as it was, it resists the pressure, solidifying around him. Curiosity satisfied, Izuku relaxes, allows himself to drift in this welcoming non-space.

‚ÄúWalk out of bounds,‚Äù Shinsou says, and Izuku is vaguely aware that he does.

He comes to on the other side of the boundary line, with the crowd cheering around him. Not cheering for him this time. Shinsou sits on the ground still, eyes shining, shoulders shaking with a laugh that Izuku can‚Äôt hear. It‚Äôs a nice moment ‚Äì Izuku will remember it fondly, as soon as proper fondness is something he is capable of. For now, he nods to Midnight and makes his way to exit the stadium, leaving Shinsou to revel in his victory, the surreal joy of seeing dreams come true.

Shinsou deserves it.

Chapter Text

Shouta has watched enough sports festivals to know how they go. He‚Äôs gotten predicting them down nearly to a science, especially when his own students are involved. This year‚Äôs festival has certainly been more eventful than most, what with Izuku and Shinsou Hitoshi both stirring the pot and disrupting the usual status quo, but with both those wildcards on the sidelines, the match between Bakugou and Shoji isn‚Äôt likely to contain yet another twist. Shouta is sure enough of this that he doesn‚Äôt actually bother to watch the fight ‚Äì he‚Äôll review the recordings later, in case they reveal anything for him to address with either of the boys in training, but he‚Äôs relatively certain that he won‚Äôt be missing anything by not watching the matchup live.

Instead, he exchanges a look with Hizashi and heads for the infirmary, where he‚Äôs sure to find his resident problem child.

Approaching the doors, Shouta hears Izuku ask, ‚ÄúCould your quirk regrow my eyebrows?‚Äù Apart from sounding vaguely sleepy, the kid‚Äôs voice holds only a reserved curiosity, apparently completely oblivious the frustrated exasperation he has once again awoken in Shouta. Oblivious or uncaring ‚Äì in Izuku‚Äôs current state, it‚Äôs hard to say which. Shouta allows himself a moment to lean against the wall next to the door, listening to the exchange within.

‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt even if I could,‚Äù Shuzenji replies, flat and unamused.

‚ÄúI wonder what the prerequisite is. You speed up the body‚Äôs natural healing processes, but why not any others? Why my skin and not my eyebrows?‚Äù Izuku mutters something to himself, and Shuzenji clicks her tongue over his indistinct words.

‚ÄúWell, that‚Äôs the way it is. I‚Äôll fix your injuries, but when you burn off your eyebrows, you have to live with the consequences. Unless you have a quirk of your own that will do the trick?‚Äù

Izuku hums. ‚ÄúI have a quirk that lets me grow flowers from my hair follicles,‚Äù he offers thoughtfully. ‚ÄúBut I don‚Äôt really want daisies for eyebrows. Some kind of grass could probably work, but the quirk only grows flowers. I‚Äôm not sure why, since a blade of grass is made up of the same components and arguably far simpler, but‚Äì‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôll just have to wait it out, then,‚Äù Shuzenji interrupts. ‚ÄúMaybe after three months of looking like a fool, you‚Äôll think twice before setting yourself on fire.‚Äù

‚ÄúDoes it really look that bad?‚Äù Izuku asks.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù Shouta answers as he shoulders the door to the room open.

Truthfully, Shouta notes as he looks Izuku over, it doesn‚Äôt look that bad at all, even on a superficial level. Shuzenji has already healed the burns on Izuku‚Äôs face, leaving only the damage to his eyebrows. The tail of his left eyebrow has been burnt off entirely, but the remaining hair just looks marginally more scraggly than before. Shouta expected far worse, but it wouldn‚Äôt do for him to say as much, when Izuku would think that meant he could set his head on fire without any kind of lasting consequence.

Granted, the rest of Izuku isn‚Äôt in as fine shape as his face. Shuzenji likely prioritized healing the injuries there. She is wrapping his arms past the elbow, the mottled red-pink of his skin looking all the more startling as it disappears beneath pristine white bandages.

‚ÄúEraser,‚Äù Izuku greets, unsurprised by Shouta‚Äôs sudden appearance. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt need to check up on me; I‚Äôm fine.‚Äù

‚Äú‚ÄòFine,‚Äô‚Äù Shuzenji scoffs. ‚ÄúThanks to all my hard work, maybe.‚Äù She turns to Shouta, hands on her hips. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve healed the second-degree burns, but left most of the first-degree alone, for now. I‚Äôll take care of the rest on Monday, or you can leave them to heal naturally. At the moment, all he really needs is rest.‚Äù Under her breath, though still audible, no doubt intentionally, she adds, ‚ÄúAnd a sense of self-preservation.‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm perfectly preserved,‚Äù Izuku counters, argument weakened by the yawn that splits it. He rubs his eyes, fingers skipping up briefly to trace along the missing tail of his eyebrow. Shuzenji shakes her head, giving Shouta a pointed look before heading into her office.

‚ÄúI really am fine,‚Äù Izuku assures, folding one of his legs out of the way as Shouta takes a seat on the edge of his cot.

‚ÄúGood,‚Äù Shouta says. And it is a relief, but Shouta already knew the kid was at least mostly okay, and it wasn‚Äôt Izuku‚Äôs safety that drove Shouta to hunt him down. Straight to the point, he asks, ‚ÄúAre you going to try to pretend that you didn‚Äôt throw that match?‚Äù

Izuku blinks. ‚ÄúNo?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo, you‚Äôre not going to pretend? Or no, you didn‚Äôt throw the match?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo, I‚Äôm not going to pretend, I guess.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou guess?‚Äù

‚ÄúWell, it seems pointless to pretend. But I also wasn‚Äôt going to bring it up. It didn‚Äôt think it was a big deal.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot a big deal?‚Äù Shouta parrots incredulously. ‚ÄúKid, why did you throw that fight?‚Äù

‚ÄúShinsou deserved to win,‚Äù Izuku says simply, shrugging.

Shouta inhales deeply through his nose, trying to follow the logic that leads to Izuku making such an absurd statement with all the confidence of a known fact. There is a silent implication ‚Äì Shinsou deserved to win; Izuku didn‚Äôt ‚Äì and it weighs heavily on Shouta, but he doesn‚Äôt question it. He already knows exactly how that line of inquiry would end. That particular misconception will only be cured with time. Time and therapy ‚Äì Shouta will have to be sure to mention this incident to Izuku‚Äôs doctor before their next appointment.

‚ÄúIf he deserved to win, he would have won. Handing him the match is the exact opposite of him having earned it.‚Äù

‚ÄúSometimes there‚Äôs more to deserving than earning.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat about Shinsou?‚Äù Shouta asks. ‚ÄúDo you think he‚Äôll feel like he deserves it, when he finds out?‚Äù

Izuku frowns. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt see why he would find out. Are you going to tell him?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Shouta admits. He shudders to imagine getting that deeply involved in student business, even if he‚Äôs personally responsible for one of those students. ‚ÄúBut if you aren‚Äôt prepared for what happens when someone learns you did something, you should at least consider not doing the thing at all.‚Äù

‚ÄúI did consider it. And then I decided it was the best thing to do.‚Äù

Shouta sighs, shuffling until he is sitting across from Izuku, cross-legged at the foot of the bed, leaning against the footboard. Izuku blinks back at him, placid and unconcerned. Turning off the emotional repression quirk will be terrible, Shouta is sure ‚Äì in fact, he‚Äôs already planning to ask Nemuri to be present in case the kid needs to be sedated ‚Äì but he is looking forward to parting ways with this Twilight Zone version of Izuku.

‚ÄúExplain to me,‚Äù Shouta says, more demand than request. ‚ÄúWhy did Shinsou deserve to win?‚Äù

Izuku thinks for a moment, then nods to himself. ‚ÄúShinsou and I both have ‚Äòvillainous‚Äô quirks. I‚Äôve always thought it was ridiculous to classify quirks that way, but all the people who say things like that about people like us‚Ä¶ I‚Äôve proved them right.‚Äù Shouta purses his lips, but doesn‚Äôt interrupt, shooting Izuku a warning look that has no effect on him. ‚ÄúShinsou can still prove them wrong. He deserves a chance to do that. He‚Äôs never given into the pressure or scorn of the people around him.

‚ÄúI know it ruins the rehabilitation plan a little, but I think it‚Äôs for the best. I don‚Äôt belong in the hero course, especially not over someone like Shinsou. This way, he can transfer.‚Äù

Shouta‚Äôs chest aches slightly to hear Izuku‚Äôs thought process, the way he condemns himself so dispassionately. Insecurities so deeply ingrained they transcend emotion, scratches on the lens through which Izuku views the world, falsehoods written in permanent marker.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs illogical,‚Äù Shouta says tiredly when Izuku is clearly finished speaking. Izuku cocks his head. ‚ÄúProblem child ‚Äì how many seats are open in 1-A?‚Äù

‚ÄúTwo,‚Äù Izuku answers instantly. ‚ÄúMineta Minoru was expelled on the third day of term and Nishioka Kin‚Äôs parents pulled him out of UA after the USJ attack.‚Äù Shouta waits expectantly, and after a moment, Izuku grasps what he‚Äôs getting at, only saying, ‚ÄúOh.‚Äù

‚ÄúExactly. You didn‚Äôt need to let Shinsou win to give him a chance to transfer. As for your own transfer ‚Äì I have no doubt that Nedzu will proceed as planned.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs still better this way,‚Äù Izuku decides a second later. Shouta resists the urge to groan, once again listening patiently for the kid‚Äôs justification. ‚ÄúThe higher Shinsou places, the better his chances are. He doesn‚Äôt have Nedzu scheming for him.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Shouta corrects sharply. ‚ÄúHis chances are unchanged. Transfers to the hero course are done entirely at staff discretion. The sports festival provides students with the opportunity to catch a teacher‚Äôs attention ‚Äì and Shinsou has had mine since the cavalry battle. He could have lost in his first match, and I still would have approached him. Coming in first, second, or third doesn‚Äôt matter. All you did was compromise your integrity. And Shinsou‚Äôs.‚Äù

After a long pause, Izuku admits, ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt consider that.‚Äù

‚ÄúI know,‚Äù Shouta sighs. ‚ÄúLearn from this ‚Äì consider it next time. Next time you want to do something for someone, ask yourself if it even needs doing. And consider that helping someone else doesn‚Äôt always have to involve hurting yourself.‚Äù

Izuku nods, a pensive frown marring his face. He looks away from Shouta to the TV in the corner. A single glance is enough to reveal that Bakugou has the clear upper hand, overwhelming Shoji with bright bursts of light and noise.

‚ÄúKatsuki‚Äôs going to be upset,‚Äù Izuku says. An explosion on screen, unnecessarily forceful, agrees with him. ‚ÄúI told him I would see him in the finals.‚Äù

Shouta leans forward, bringing one of his casts down on Izuku‚Äôs head, just hard enough to catch the kid‚Äôs attention. Shouta glares at him, keeping Izuku‚Äôs head in place with his arm.

‚ÄúFocus on yourself,‚Äù he orders. Izuku nods, rubbing his scalp lightly when Shouta releases him. Shouta locates the television‚Äôs remote on the small table between the two cots, turning the screen off just as Bakugou secures his victory.

Be selfish, Shouta wants to say. Help yourself. Fuck all the other. Not everyone needs to be a hero. There‚Äôs nothing wrong with being the one to need saving.

Of course, Shouta doesn‚Äôt say any of that because the kid won‚Äôt understand it. Not yet. Another reason he shouldn‚Äôt have been participating in the festival to begin with. Izuku is so eager to give away pieces of himself without taking anything in return, like he doesn‚Äôt realize that his time, his energy, his spirit, are all limited resources.

Civilians will say that good heroes are willing to make sacrifices. They‚Äôre not wrong, but like with most aspect of the hero industry, they also don‚Äôt see the full picture of things. Good heroes are willing to make sacrifices; great heroes know when not to. As a direct result, the primary difference between good heroes and great ones is how long they live.

Come Monday, Izuku will most likely be seated in class 1-A, one step closer to being a good hero. And he will be good ‚Äì as far as Shouta‚Äôs concerned, that‚Äôs a foregone conclusion. But it‚Äôs still up to Shouta to make sure the kid lives long enough and stays whole enough to become a great one.

 

 

Behind the scenes of the sports festival, there‚Äôs an unlisted match being fought only in Hitoshi‚Äôs head. Midoriya Izuku versus Bakugou Katsuki ‚Äì who‚Äôs scarier? Let‚Äôs see what the participants have going for them.

In one corner ‚Äì Midoriya. Definitely not what you‚Äôd expect from a finalist in a fight like this ‚Äì short, fluffy hair, huge eyes, smattering of freckles, overall just very green. Cute, in a simple, woodsy kind of way. Don‚Äôt judge a book by its cover though, folks ‚Äì Midoriya killed his dad. That‚Äôs right! Killed ‚Äì as in murdered ‚Äì his dad ‚Äì as in his own fucking father. That‚Äôs a pretty big point in his favor ‚Äì or is it a point against him? A point in the definitely terrifying column. He‚Äôs also powerful and ruthless. Admittedly the intimidation factor of those traits pales somewhat in comparison to the patricide bit. Keep in mind, though, Midoriya cried ‚Äì like, a lot ‚Äì about that whole murder thing, which might not bring anyone back to life, but it does make Midoriya slightly less terrifying in Hitoshi‚Äôs books. And of course, Hitoshi has already beaten Midoriya, an important factor to consider.

In the other corner ‚Äì Bakugou. Now he‚Äôs what you‚Äôd expect to see in this competition ‚Äì spiky hair, perpetual scowl, red eyes to match. Bit of a stereotypical thug, really, with exactly the shitty manners you‚Äôd associate with that sort of person. This is a book you can judge by its cover ‚Äì one look tells you the whole story, and Hitoshi‚Äôs not going to lie, that story is pretty intimidating. But hey, at least there are no nasty surprises hiding in the pages. Bakugou is also powerful and ruthless. In fact, he seems to be ruthless, not just in the I‚Äôll do what it takes to win way, but in the I don‚Äôt care if anyone gets hurt way. To Hitoshi‚Äôs knowledge, Bakugou hasn‚Äôt actually killed anyone, but honestly, Hitoshi wouldn‚Äôt be surprised it that knowledge proves to be incorrect or outdated somewhere down the line. More often than he would like, Katsuki remembers the hollow, hopeless feeling of calling for a quirk that doesn‚Äôt answer. Dear Katsuki Kacchan,

Chapter Text

The dirt is spongey and slightly wet beneath Izuku‚Äôs knees. A chill eats through the denim of his jeans, prickling against his skin as a breeze raises the hair on his arms. The smell of the earth is gentle and soothing. The grass is springy, green, and well-manicured. Everything is hushed, near silent.

It is a good place to rest, Izuku thinks. There is a body beneath him, resting eternally.

Is it as peaceful as it seems? Or does she toss and turn, churning up soil with stiff limbs?

Beneath his fingers, the tombstone is glossy and smooth. Letters are carved into the rock, deep and bold, the edges slightly rounded over. He traces the characters, slow and methodical, lets the message sink through his skin to his soul.

Midoriya Inko.

Loving friend and mother.

She was only 32 when she died, the headstone says. Somehow, Izuku didn‚Äôt know that. When he was ten years old, his mother was still some ageless, super-human entity to him. He knew her birthday, sure, but he hadn‚Äôt understood that she had been a child once, just like him.

The quiet in the graveyard is the kind that feels like it can‚Äôt be broken. Even the soft sounds of nature are muted, leaves murmuring low and unobtrusive out of respect for the dead. ‚ÄúI love you,‚Äù Izuku finally says, ‚Äúand I miss you.‚Äù Whispered, the words still sound too loud, popping the fragile bubble of serenity that floats around this place, but they spill out like water set loose as soon as he opens his mouth. ‚ÄúYour mother, she loved being pregnant,‚Äù Aunt Mitsuki says, looking from Izuku to the headstone with sad fondness filling her eyes. ‚ÄúShe had that whole clich√© glowy bullshit going on for her. ‚ÄúExcept she wasn‚Äôt miserable. If anything, she only got happier after you were born. She glowed even brighter. Which seemed fucking impossible to me. ‚ÄúThen,‚Äù she continues, smile quirking wryly, ‚ÄúMasaru and I babysat you for the first time. And sorry to break it to you, Izu, but you were no angel. Hell, you made Katsuki look like an angel. Izuku bites his lip, breathing carefully around the tears that well up against his eyes and clog his throat. He presses the backs of his hands against his eyes, cool skin soothing against the raw, irritated heat of his eyelids.

Loving friend and mother.

For the first time, Izuku resents having his quirk suppressed. His mother‚Äôs headstone looks barren, a cold grey monolith poorly serving memorial for such a warm and colorful life. Izuku wonders if his father had a funeral. What did Tomura and Kurogiri do with the body? How did they mourn? Did he get a eulogy? Was he buried? Does he have a grave somewhere?

If he does, it must be unmarked. Izuku imagines it overgrown with weeds, forgotten by everyone but the decomposers that make new life from old death. Shigaraki Hisashi.

Loving leader and father.

No. Kurogiri probably burned him. Less evidence that way. All that‚Äôs left is ash and memories that taste like it.

 

 

Dear Mom,

I don‚Äôt actually know how you died. I think someone must have told me, but all I remember is your mother has been in an accident. I‚Äôm sorry. I should have asked. You deserved at least that much from me.

 

 

Shouta picks a random point near the wall of the Bakugous‚Äô living room. He stares at the brass handle of a side table drawer and sits completely still. ‚ÄúOh! Photo albums. Feel free to have a look ‚Äì Mitsuki got them out for Izukun. That was her original plan for this afternoon. She spent all night gathering photos from all around to put in for him. We figured he probably didn‚Äôt have many photos of his mother.‚Äù

Shouta reaches forward, snagging the red book, the thicker of the two, and dragging it into his lap. ‚ÄúOur wedding,‚Äù Mr. Bakugou says, leaning forward in his seat so he can see what image Shouta has landed on. ‚ÄúInko was Mitsuki‚Äôs maid of honor. ‚ÄúIncredibly,‚Äù Mr. Bakugou replies. ‚ÄúMore like sisters than friends, really. They met in high school. Mitsuki was a few years older, but she got attached to Inko immediately. And when Mitsuki gets attached, there‚Äôs no escaping.‚Äù

Escaping seemed to be a good word. The first few pages of the album are filled with pictures of Ms. Midoriya, with and without Mrs. Bakugou, looking incredibly anxious either way. ‚ÄúI met them in college,‚Äù Mr. Bakugou says as years pass by with simple movements of Shouta‚Äôs hands. ‚ÄúProbably the best thing that ever happened to me. Mitsuki, obviously, I love dearly. Izuku looks a lot like his father, Shouta acknowledges. The dark mess of his hair, the freckles covering his cheeks. But his smile ‚Äì he got that from his mother.

‚ÄúAkatani,‚Äù Mr. Bakugou says after a heavy pause. ‚ÄúHisashi. I didn‚Äôt know him very well. None of us did, I suppose. There‚Äôs only a photo of two of him in there, I can take them out‚Äì‚Äù He reaches out for the album, but Shouta pulls it away.

‚ÄúHe doesn‚Äôt have any photos of his father,‚Äù Shouta says, still staring at the immortalized face of the boogey man that terrorized Japan from the shadows for centuries. Knowing what he will do, has done, Shigaraki Hisashi looks far too innocuous.

‚ÄúI‚Ä¶ assumed he wouldn‚Äôt want any, given what you told us today.‚Äù

‚ÄúMaybe he won‚Äôt,‚Äù Shouta agrees, ‚Äúbut he might. Either way, he can make that choice for himself. Eventually, Mr. Bakugou clears his throat and resumes his commentary. ‚ÄúPregnancy somehow brought them even closer. Especially after Akatani‚Ä¶ left. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre back!‚Äù Mrs. Bakugou calls. A moment later, the group enters the living room. Izuku trails behind the adults, eyes hazy and directed towards the floor. ‚ÄúHow are you feeling?‚Äù Shouta asks. Izuku glances up and shrugs half-heartedly.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm feeling.‚Äù He sounds subdued, but he musters a small smile for Shouta‚Äôs sake. Unconsciously, Shouta smiles back.

‚ÄúWhatcha got there?‚Äù Hizashi asks, sliding onto the couch. ‚ÄúI thought she would never stop crying,‚Äù Mr. Bakugou recalls, coming to his wife‚Äôs side.

‚ÄúThey were good tears.‚Äù

Nestled against Hizashi‚Äôs side, Izuku nods. He pays no mind to the tears spilling from his own eyes, tracing a reverent finger over his mother‚Äôs extended hand. And then Izuku is there in the photos, too.

Shouta has never found babies cute. They‚Äôre too small, their proportions make him uncomfortable, and they‚Äôre generally blotchy and oddly colored. ‚ÄúMy deal?‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what I fucking said, isn‚Äôt it? I want what‚Äôs best for Izuku. I would take him in myself if I could, but I think there‚Äôs more than one reason that that wouldn‚Äôt work. It feels alien to consider. Not impossible, no, but ‚Äì like an alternate reality, a parallel universe. Shouta can easily imagine a world where Izuku is somewhere else. ‚Äú‚Ä¶Aizawa Shouta.‚Äù

‚ÄúShouta, right. Shouta, Shouta, Shouta. Gonna have to remember that one. We‚Äôre practically family now, after all.‚Äù

 

 

Dear Tomura,

I want to hit you in the head with a bat to get through your thick skull! How can one person be so endlessly frustrating?! You‚Äôre smart but you‚Äôre so stupid! He‚Äôs dead!! He‚Äôs dead, and that‚Äôs ‚Äì

Izuku is starting to recognize himself again.

The uniform still seems to fit him oddly, and he still doesn‚Äôt know how to tie a tie, and there are still bags under his eyes, but the wrongness of it is being gradually worn away with repetition. Every morning, he takes a moment to stare at his reflection and remind himself that this is real, that this is him, that life continues undeterrably onwards and he is continuing on with it. He flicks a piece of confetti off his shoulder and turns back to Lucy, snoozing in his favorite spot on the middle of Izuku‚Äôs bed.

‚ÄúGonna wish me luck?‚Äù Izuku asks. Lucy, of course, doesn‚Äôt reply, curled up in featureless white ball of fluff. Izuku pats the covers a couple of times, gaining Lucy‚Äôs attention, a head emerging from the cloud of fur. ‚ÄúWish me luck,‚Äù Izuku says when Lucy looks at him. Lucy chirps.

It‚Äôs an inane interaction. Lucy always makes noises when he realizes someone is speaking to him. It‚Äôs not like the cat has any idea what‚Äôs going on, not the faintest notion of all the monumental ways Izuku‚Äôs life is changing so rapidly. Still, the little sound calms some of the nerves rampaging in Izuku‚Äôs gut. Lucy twists on the bed, uncurling and wiggling around until his head is close enough to Izuku‚Äôs hand to demand affection. Compliantly, Izuku cups Lucy‚Äôs face between his palms, rubbing and scratching behind the cat‚Äôs ears and along his neck.

As if sensing the soothing moment, Bastard interrupts, yowling and sticking a paw through the open crack of Izuku‚Äôs door. A wide amber eye glares at him accusingly as she mutters something nonsensical. Giving Lucy a final scratch, Izuku opens the door fully, allowing Bastard to nip the hem of his pants before she darts back towards the kitchen. He follows at a more sedate pace, hesitating only briefly before taking his now-usual seat next to Eraser.

The hero takes one look at Izuku, glowers, and says, ‚ÄúNo.‚Äù

Izuku blanches. ‚ÄúNo?‚Äù he echoes, fumbling the chopsticks he had just picked up.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Eraser affirms. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not leaving the apartment like that.‚Äù He twists on his stool until he is facing Izuku fully, gesturing for Izuku to do the same. ‚ÄúNow that I can actually use my arms again, it‚Äôs time for you to learn how to tie a damn tie.‚Äù

‚ÄúAw, come on Sho!‚Äù Mic says, leaning over the counter to poke Eraser in the side of his head. ‚ÄúThe little listener has a style! I think it‚Äôs cute!‚Äù

‚ÄúRedo it however you like, Sprout,‚Äù Mic says, resting his chin on the top of Eraser‚Äôs head. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not technically breaking dress code, so you do you! ‚ÄúReady to face the day, Greenbean?‚Äù Mic asks.

Izuku still can‚Äôt say yes and mean it. But the truthful answer‚Äôs not no, either, not anymore. He takes a deep breath.

‚ÄúReady as I‚Äôll ever be.‚Äù

You are a work in progress. Subject to change. Game footage not final.

I am the only person who will ever read this, but there‚Äôs something I think everyone needs to hear, you and I included. It‚Äôs hard to really believe it, sometimes, but that‚Äôs all the more reason to say it, often and loudly.

You are better than the worst thing that you have ever done. And you are stronger than the worst thing that has ever been done to you.

Chapter Text

In a welcome change of pace, Hitoshi sleeps like the dead. Not so welcome is the waking up. His whole body is sore and stiff in ways he didn‚Äôt realize it could be, his mouth tastes like something died under his tongue, and his eyes resist creaking open, like doors with rusted-over hinges. Bright light streams through the crack of his curtains, telling Hitoshi that the day is already well on its way ‚Äì exactly what day it is is a mystery though, because as far as Hitoshi is concerned, he could have slept a handful of years just as easily as hours.

Hitoshi turns his face further into his pillows to spare his tender eyes from the sun, reaching blindly for his phone. His arm doesn‚Äôt respond quite as intended, knocking into the corner of his bedside table before flopping onto it like a dead fish with another clumsy movement. It‚Äôs embarrassingly uncoordinated, even with no one around to bear witness, and pathetically painful.

Hitoshi‚Äôs protesting hiss is muffled by his pillow as he finally closes uncooperative fingers around his phone, bringing it close to his face to squint at the time. 10:08 in the morning. And Hitoshi went to sleep ‚Äì when? Well, he got home after the festival, raided the kitchen for anything that required minimal effort to shove in his face, and then immediately crashed. He can‚Äôt remember his dad ever coming home, so he must have been out before six. Sixteen hours of sleep then, as a conservative estimate.

Hitoshi drops his phone next to his head and considers letting himself drift off again.

Sixteen hours or not, he definitely could go straight back to sleep, as exhausted as he is. ‚ÄúYour transfer is dependent on your success in a training program. We‚Äôll need to get you up to snuff before you can officially join 1-A.‚Äù

‚ÄúUp to snuff?‚Äù Hitoshi asks. He is conscious of the fact that he sounds a bit like an echo, repeating everything Aizawa says back to him, but Hitoshi is too indignant to worry about that for the moment. ‚ÄúI won the festival; I think that makes me ‚Äòup to snuff.‚Äô‚Äù

‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt,‚Äù Aizawa counters mercilessly. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt even know how to throw a punch.‚Äù

‚ÄúDo you have any physical training?‚Äù

‚ÄúI have a mental quirk.‚Äù

‚ÄúAll the more reason to have physical training. I‚Äôll take that as a no.‚Äù

‚ÄúAizawa,‚Äù Hitoshi‚Äôs father begins, a hint of warning in his tone that Hitoshi simultaneously appreciates and resents. Aizawa waves him off.

Glaring at the floor, Hitoshi grits his teeth. It‚Äôs the same rhetoric he‚Äôs been hearing for years. Mental quirks are inferior to physical quirks. ‚ÄúShinsou,‚Äù Aizawa says sharply. Hitoshi shifts his glare from the floor to the man. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not saying you are any less capable than they are. ‚ÄúAlright then. If you agree to what principal Nedzu and I have arranged, your training will begin on Monday. After classes, four days a week, you‚Äôll be with me and another student. ‚ÄúWhat about his regular studies?‚Äù Hitoshi‚Äôs father asks, while Hitoshi himself just blinks dumbly, turning the new information over in his head.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôll be expected to keep his grades up, but if he starts struggling, we can provide additional academic support. ‚ÄúThis is a lot,‚Äù Hitoshi says.

‚ÄúIt is,‚Äù Aizawa agrees. ‚ÄúCan you handle it?‚Äù

And really, who ever knows what they can handle until they‚Äôre face-to-face with it in real life? It‚Äôs a question whose answer really only exists somewhere in the future. Yes, say the arrogant. No, say the insecure.

Hitoshi says, ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs find out.‚Äù

Aizawa grins at him, and it‚Äôs even more intimidating than the blank look from before. Hitoshi grins back.

Hitoshi sighs. ‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt trust it if it was.‚Äù

‚ÄúKaminari! Language!‚Äù

The recording light blinks a new pattern.

¬∑ ¬∑ ‚Äì ‚Äì ¬∑ ¬∑

Is everything alright?

Izuku would be removed from the situation within minutes if he gave the slightest indication that he wanted to be. Izuku can‚Äôt feel it now, but the hair along his arms stands on end, all the same, as he runs a finger along the smooth surface of the suppressing bands around his wrists.

‚ÄúWhat did you n-need, sir?‚Äù Izuku asks when it becomes obvious that All Might will not be the one to speak first.

‚ÄúRight. Yes,‚Äù All Might begins. ‚ÄúWell, my boy, getting straight to the point, you‚Äôve gotten an offer from a hero.‚Äù

Izuku frowns. ‚ÄúAn internship offer?‚Äù Izuku has gotten hundreds of offers and he has no idea who the vast majority of them are from. It‚Äôs not like it actually matters, since he can‚Äôt accept any of them.

‚ÄúYes. This one came in past the deadline, technically, but‚Ä¶ The hero‚Äôs name is Gran Torino.‚Äù

‚ÄúGran Torino? Is he‚Ä¶‚Äù Izuku hesitates as he searches for the appropriate words. ‚ÄúAbout Recovery Girl‚Äôs height? With a similar, um, no-nonsense attitude?‚Äù

‚ÄúA kind way of putting it.‚Äù

‚ÄúHe was ‚Äì wasn‚Äôt he one of the heroes g-guarding me when I was‚Ä¶?‚Äù Izuku trails off, remembering the hazy days he spent in the safe house that feel like years ago.

All Might spares him from elaborating, replying, ‚ÄúYes. Did you speak to him much?‚Äù

‚ÄúNo.‚Äù Izuku didn‚Äôt speak much at all, in that time. The only person he talked with at any length was Tsukauchi, and even those conversations were far from coherent. ‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù

‚ÄúAs I said, he put in an internship offer for you,‚Äù All Might answers, turning away from Izuku to pace a short path back and forth across the room. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm trying to figure out why, myself. ‚ÄúShimura Nana,‚Äù Izuku remembers.

‚ÄúYes.‚Äù

‚Äú‚Ä¶What happened to her?‚Äù he asks quietly after a moment of indecisive deliberation. He suspects he already knows the answer. All Might looks at him silently, and Izuku can‚Äôt meet his eyes, suddenly sure that he shouldn‚Äôt have asked at all.  

‚ÄúShe died when I was just a boy,‚Äù All Might eventually answers. Izuku swallows at the heaviness of his voice, the gravity of the words. ‚ÄúShe fell in a battle against All for One.‚Äù

Izuku nods. He swallows again. This time it feels like swallowing a ball of needles. Perversely, the confirmation of Izuku‚Äôs suspicions feel like a boon. His father hurt so many people, and Izuku knew so few of their names. He knew faces and quirks and nothing more.

‚ÄúMay‚Äì‚Äù Izuku‚Äôs voice cracks, hoarse. He clears his throat and tries again, ‚ÄúMaybe that‚Äôs why. If he was f-friends with her and my f-father‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù All Might says. His tone shocks Izuku, surprisingly gentle, kind. Izuku looks away again, staring out the windows over the still campus. Reflexively, he fidgets with the bands around his wrists, running his nails between the metal and his skin.

‚ÄúH-he was your teacher?‚Äù he asks.

 All Might nods. ‚ÄúOfficially, for a year. But he taught me far more than that.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy not ask him, then?‚Äù All Might blanches, an almost laughable expression on such a large and powerful man. He shakes his head, legs visibly trembling as well, much to Izuku‚Äôs surprise.

‚ÄúI couldn‚Äôt possibly,‚Äù All Might denies vehemently. ‚ÄúFor him to use his old name for this‚Ä¶ he must be planning something. Are you certain you have no ideas about why he‚Äôs taken an interest in you?‚Äù

Izuku fidgets, shrugging helplessly, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm s-sorry, sir. But I‚Äôll be doing my internship with Eraserhead, so if he is, uh ‚Äì pl-planning something, then it‚Äôs, um, it‚Äôs not going to work, at least?‚Äù

‚ÄúMaybe,‚Äù All Might allows, though he sounds incredibly doubtful. ‚ÄúOr maybe he knows something that I don‚Äôt.‚Äù He shakes his head briskly. When he speaks again, his voice has regained its characteristic boom. This is All Might speaking, Izuku realizes. The man before ‚Äì that was Yagi.  ‚ÄúAnyway ‚Äì I‚Äôve pulled you away from your friends for long enough. Thank you, young Midoriya, for entertaining the worries of an old man. With a shallow bow, All Might retreats, leaving Izuku alone in the room. He pulls a seat away from the table and throws himself into it, spinning around a few times. Coming to a stop, he glances back up to the camera.

‚ÄúThat was weird,‚Äù he tells it.

The light blinks back: ‚Äì ‚Äì ‚Äì ¬∑ ¬∑ ¬∑   ‚Äì ¬∑ ‚Äì ‚Äì ¬∑ ‚Äì

‚ÄúNot helpful.‚Äù

 

 

Day two of Hitoshi‚Äôs training is nearly satisfying. Aizawa is a stern but surprisingly patient teacher, walking Hitoshi through physical movements, offering clear and concise solutions for problems as Hitoshi runs into them. Even when Hitoshi needs the same move demonstrated five times in a row, only to still mess it up when he makes his own attempt, Aizawa maintains his bored composure, never growing obviously frustrated.

Unlike Hitoshi himself, who can‚Äôt help but keep up a running internal monolog that grows increasingly vitriolic whenever he fails to grasp a basic concept. That‚Äôs all they do today, just the basics. How to throw a punch, simple offensive and defensive forms, how to block, dodge, roll, fall without busting himself up. But already, Hitoshi is struggling. Aizawa tells him ‚Äì factually, not assuringly, and yet still assuring by virtue of how factual it is ‚Äì that it‚Äôs normal to have difficulty. He says that it will get easier as Hitoshi grows more accustomed to using his body this way.

And despite Hitoshi‚Äôs mounting frustration, the session is still nearly satisfying. Nearly. The source of that caveat, the key obstacle, actually has nothing to do with Hitoshi‚Äôs performance. No, it‚Äôs Midoriya‚Äôs performance that tanks Hitoshi‚Äôs mood right into bleak, bitter territory.

Of course, wonder kid Midoriya is excellent at everything, first try. Hitoshi tells himself that it‚Äôs not a fair comparison. Midoriya obviously already knows what he‚Äôs doing, while Hitoshi still has to learn it all. It does little to dull the sting of the fact that, somehow, Midoriya already knows what he‚Äôs doing. He‚Äôs not only learned it, he‚Äôs perfected it. Sometimes, he chimes in from the sidelines with tips and tricks ‚Äì and goddamn him, they‚Äôre actually useful.

Somewhere in the middle of training, Hitoshi‚Äôs inner voice helpfully informs him that Midoriya could destroy him, if he wanted to. And that‚Äôs where shit really starts going downhill. It‚Äôs a familiar sentiment. Hadn‚Äôt Bakugou said something similar, before the awards ceremony? Bakugou had rambled on like a mad man, and among all the crazy bullshit, he had said Deku should have fucking destroyed you.

Midoriya catches Hitoshi‚Äôs attempt at a punch and has the gall to tell him that his ‚Äúform is good,‚Äù but he‚Äôs ‚Äúprojecting his intentions too obviously.‚Äù Of course, Midoriya stutters his way through the words, but that doesn‚Äôt make them any less infuriating. Hitoshi rips his fist away with a curt nod, diligently resetting his stance to match what Aizawa had shown him at the beginning. The next punch Hitoshi throws, Midoriya claims is ‚Äúbetter,‚Äù but he still effortlessly dodges past Hitoshi‚Äôs fist.

Alright. Hitoshi can admit that Midoriya is leaps and bounds ahead of him, physically. But just because the guy can run fast, hit hard, and whatever else, doesn‚Äôt mean he should have destroyed Hitoshi in their match. He can duck Hitoshi‚Äôs punches as much as he likes ‚Äì none of that matters when it‚Äôs Hitoshi‚Äôs quirk that Midoriya failed to dodge. Brainwashing can reduce even the physically strongest of people to nothing. Hitoshi has proven that.

Except ‚Äì and Hitoshi hates that there‚Äôs an except, but he can‚Äôt stop himself from thinking it ‚Äì Midoriya didn‚Äôt fight back, did he? Hitoshi caught him, ordered him out of bounds, and Midoriya went. Hitoshi won. That was that. Except everyone always resists, even if it does them no good. Especially in the middle of a fight, struggling in Brainwashing‚Äôs grip is basically an instinctual response.

And ‚Äì and Hitoshi hates that there‚Äôs an and, when the except is already bad enough ‚Äì Midoriya hadn‚Äôt exactly denied it.

Hitoshi tells himself he‚Äôs just being paranoid. He probably is. Still, even if it‚Äôs just paranoia, the creeping, itching feeling only gets worse as the session wears on. By the time Aizawa calls training to a stop, Hitoshi feels like he is going to crawl out of his skin, overanalyzing Midoriya‚Äôs every movement and coming up with nothing but more doubt. It wiggles in through his ears and chews away at his brain. Because Midoriya didn‚Äôt fight back and Midoriya didn‚Äôt deny it and there is no doubt at all that Midoriya could have destroyed Hitoshi and maybe all those things together means that Midoriya should have destroyed him.

Without choosing to, Hitoshi finds himself asking, ‚ÄúDid you let me win?‚Äù

The question probably makes him sound like an idiot. A needy, self-conscious one, at that. He struggles to keep his face blank while a flush rushes up the back of his neck, the heat of it leaking into his ears. God, way to beg for validation and show just how pathetic he is in the process. At least Midoriya is ‚Äì well, Hitoshi doesn‚Äôt like him, but he seems nice enough. Nicer than Hitoshi, at least. Except ‚Äì because there‚Äôs always a fucking exception, isn‚Äôt there, quickly working its way up Hitoshi‚Äôs list of least favorite words ‚Äì Midoriya still doesn‚Äôt deny it. ‚ÄúOh, look at that,‚Äù Aizawa says dryly. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm getting a phone call. I have to take this.‚Äù There‚Äôs not a single chime or beep or buzz. Aizawa doesn‚Äôt even bother taking his phone out of his pocket, just turns and walks out of the building.

‚ÄúMidoriya,‚Äù Hitoshi prompts, voice slightly strained. He keeps a tight grip on the knot of anxiety in his chest, trying to keep himself from jumping to conclusions, but the longer Midoriya is silent, the more foregone those conclusions seem. Finally, Midoriya faces him, hands clenching spastically by his sides, eyes locked on Hitoshi‚Äôs forehead. Once, then twice, he opens his mouth, only to close it, gaping like a fish out of water.

‚ÄúI d-did,‚Äù he admits on the third try, thin and thready as if the words are being forced through a physical barrier. ‚ÄúI th-thought I was trying to h-help you,‚Äù he goes on to explain, ‚Äúbut really, I was just being s-s-self-fish. Hitoshi blinks. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not worth anything,‚Äù he says numbly.

It‚Äôs odd when paranoia is proven right. Afterall, paranoia is, by definition, irrational and unfounded. Which means Hitoshi was never actually being paranoid at all. He was being oblivious, and anything he mistakenly labeled ‚Äúparanoia‚Äù was a niggling sense of reality. He suspected, he feared, but he wasn‚Äôt prepared to be right. Confirmation feels like slamming against a brick wall at a hundred miles an hour. Slowly, and then all at once, Hitoshi‚Äôs surprise gives way to anger. He straightens his spine, glaring down at Midoriya, whose eyes skirt from the lines of Hitoshi‚Äôs forehead to his shoulder.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not here to make friends,‚Äù Hitoshi spits, ‚Äúand I don‚Äôt want your pity, either. You can take that and shove it up your ass.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not p-pity‚Äì‚Äù

‚ÄúOh? What is it, then? Charity? Look at the pathetic gen ed kid, look how desperate he is. Let‚Äôs throw him a bone and then pat ourselves on the back for a job well done. Am I meant to say thank you?‚Äù

Midoriya frowns. ‚ÄúNo. I already said‚Äì‚Äù

‚ÄúWell forgive me for not giving a shit what you have to say!‚Äù Hitoshi interrupts, wringing a hand through the hair at the nape of his neck. ‚ÄúDo you have any idea how hard I worked to get here? This time, it is Midoriya interrupting Hitoshi, ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not how it works.‚Äù

‚ÄúEnlighten me then,‚Äù Hitoshi sneers. Midoriya tilts his chin back, eyes snapping to Hitoshi‚Äôs, vibrantly green, glaring just as fiercely as Hitoshi is. His hands are tightened into still fists by his sides, no longer fidgeting.

‚ÄúI let you win,‚Äù Midoriya says, like a challenge rather than a confession, ‚Äúbut you beat Katsuki all on your own. Everyone who made it to the final event was good enough. ‚ÄúSure,‚Äù Hitoshi scoffs, ‚Äútalk to me about luck. That‚Äôs easy to say for someone who‚Äôs had enough of the good kind that they can go around passing up opportunities.‚Äù Midoriya looks away again, glaring hard at the ground.

‚ÄúI get that you‚Äôre angry,‚Äù Midoriya says. A caustic laugh crawls up Hitoshi‚Äôs throat, acidic on the back of his tongue. ‚ÄúBut you don‚Äôt know anything about me.‚Äù

‚ÄúReally? Not anything? I know that you came out of nowhere and got handed everything I‚Äôve ever wanted. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know what that‚Äôs like?‚Äù he echoes.

Midoriya‚Äôs tone, suddenly quieter, close to a whisper, is simultaneously mournful and somehow threatening. ‚ÄúWell, someone like you can get away with that.‚Äù

‚ÄúSomeone like me?‚Äù

‚ÄúYou have an amazing quirk.‚Äù

‚ÄúMy quirk?‚Äù Midoriya repeats, a baffled echo. Hitoshi takes a step back, mouth twisting uncomfortably. ‚ÄúGod, Shinsou, do you even hear what you‚Äôre saying?‚Äù

Hitoshi opens his mouth to retort but Midoriya cuts him off, spitting to the side. Orange and yellow lights dance off the suddenly reflective surface of Midoriya‚Äôs skin, dazzling Hitoshi‚Äôs eyes. Blue filaments join the lightshow, bright, wavering lines stretching from Midoriya‚Äôs palm and between his fingers.

‚ÄúDo you get it, yet?‚Äù Midoriya asks.

‚ÄúWhat the‚Äì‚Äù

For a moment, Hitoshi loses himself. The white noise of his thoughts swarms into a thick, white fog that swallows him whole. He presses against it, and it presses back. It seeps through him, fills him up, surrounds him completely, until he doesn‚Äôt know where he stops and where it begins.

‚ÄúListen to me,‚Äù a voice says, and Hitoshi does. ‚ÄúLet this sink in. There‚Äôs more to people than quirks. And there‚Äôs more to quirks than meets the eye. You, of all people, should know that.‚Äù

And then Hitoshi belongs to himself again, though he can still hardly think. ‚ÄúWhat the hell?‚Äù Hitoshi asks weakly, finishing the question that had been so unceremoniously interrupted.

Midoriya looks from his hands to Hitoshi, eyes growing wide, then wider still. A tremor starts in the tips of his fingers, propagating through his frame until even the ends of his hair are quivering faintly. One of his hands covers his mouth, fingers digging divots into his cheeks. His breath hitches against his palm. Hitoshi takes a step backwards and glances to the door, wondering if the time has come to get Aizawa. Midoriya follows the retreat, reaching out, only to yank his hand back away again, like Hitoshi has burned him.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry!‚Äù Midoriya blurts, voice muffled against his hand.

‚ÄúFor what?‚Äù Hitoshi asks dumbly.

‚ÄúFor ‚Äì for‚Äì‚Äù Hitoshi uses the response to snag Midoriya, to subdue the blossoming hysteria that Hitoshi can very clearly see and very much does not want to have to deal with. Hitoshi is left standing alone, wondering what the hell he is even meant to be reporting. Obviously, something has happened. Something important. But Hitoshi doesn‚Äôt know what or how. He doesn‚Äôt know how they went from yelling at each other to Midoriya fleeing like a bat out of hell. He doesn‚Äôt know what I took it, I‚Äôll give it back is meant to mean. Chapter Text

Sometimes, this whole guardianship business feels like counting the days between massive fuck ups, always hoping to set a new record and rarely succeeding. Izuku stumbles two steps out of the gym and looks side to side, glazed eyes scanning over his surroundings, probably too rapidly to really interpret any of what he is seeing. Shouta, seated on the ledge of a cracked-open window, hops down from his perch. He ignores the twinge that landing sends through his knee, approaching Izuku to grab him firmly by the upper arms. Immediately, the kid grasps back, reaching for Shouta‚Äôs capture weapon with fumbling fingers.

‚ÄúW-where are my c-cuffs?‚Äù he asks, tripping over the words as they spill off his tongue too quickly. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sup-posed to ‚Äì I n-need‚Äì‚Äù

Shouta moves his grip from Izuku‚Äôs bicep to his wrist, halting the uncoordinated movements of the kid‚Äôs hands while Shouta retrieves the bands from an internal pocket of his jumpsuit. With unnerving focus, Izuku watches Shouta‚Äôs progress, eyes intent on the glint of silver even after the bands are snapped into place and Izuku‚Äôs quirk is sealed away again. Then Izuku‚Äôs gaze, stricken and overwhelmed, shifts to meet Shouta‚Äôs. Shouta curses under his breath.

‚ÄúHow are you feeling?‚Äù he asks firmly, maintaining eye contact. It‚Äôs a stupid question when all the kid‚Äôs emotions are written in his eyes, none of them good, but it‚Äôs become nearly routine at this point. Izuku blinks, visibly anchoring himself.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm feeling,‚Äù he responds. There is nothing comforting about the words, really, but Shouta finds himself relieved, nevertheless. Priority one ‚Äì averting a complete breakdown ‚Äì secured. Priority two ‚Äì getting some damn privacy away from nosey passersby and the all-seeing eyes of the rat ‚Äì still in progress. Hopefully Shinsou can handle the fallout of their confrontation alone because Izuku certainly can‚Äôt. Shouta hates to prioritize one student over another to this extreme, but when one of those students is his kid ‚Äì his traumatized and mentally unstable kid, at that ‚Äì the choice is easy to make, regardless of the sour taste it leaves in his mouth.

Keeping a grounding hand on Izuku‚Äôs shoulder, Shouta steers them back to the apartment. Izuku matches Shouta‚Äôs brisk pace without complaint, head down, bottom lip pinched between his teeth, hands tangled together. Occasionally, his breath hitches, but he is holding himself together remarkably well. Ironically, this only put Shouta more on edge. Shouta continues to guide Izuku through the apartment, leading him to the couch and pressing down on his shoulders until he sits mechanically. Bastard runs off to her closet, likely sensing the emotional tension, while Disco watches with curious caution from one of the stools by the counter. Todoroki must have gotten desperate, because that‚Äôs when he used the fire, trying to keep our team from reuniting, but of course, that did him little good against our fire bending Izuku.‚Äù He sends a wink Izuku‚Äôs way as he finishes, basking in the awed noises of Ashido and Hagakure.

‚ÄúIt was pretty amazing,‚Äù Yaoyorozu agrees, though she is frowning softly and rubbing the top of her shoulder.

Izuku grimaces. ‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù he says, for the second time. Yaoyorozu, eyes briefly hazy with recollection, looks at him, hurrying to shake her head.

‚ÄúNo, no. You‚Äôre fine. You surprised me at the time, but you got the points fair and square. It didn‚Äôt hurt that much, honestly.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat did he do?‚Äù Hagakure asks eagerly. Yaoyorozu flushes and Izuku grimaces again, deeper this time.

‚ÄúSt-stood on her. And Uraraka. So I wouldn‚Äôt t-touch the ground.‚Äù

‚ÄúWait,‚Äù Ashido blurts. ‚ÄúLike Bakugou? I thought he was crazy for doing that!‚Äù

Izuku jumps as Kaminari slams a fist onto the table. ‚ÄúBakugou!‚Äù he shouts. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the deal with you two, anyway? Like, I‚Äôm not imaging it, right?‚Äù He turns to Ashido who nods in support. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs definitely something going on there!‚Äù

Izuku‚Äôs mouth goes dry. His tongue feels thick and stiff, and it sticks to the back of teeth that are suddenly locked in space. He forces himself to swallow, and the wet clicking noise of it fills his ears. Here they are, gossiping about Izuku‚Äôs confrontations with Todoroki, like that is the thing most worth talking about. They must know better. Were they beating around the bush out of kindness or reckless disregard? Do they realize what they are asking him now, by bringing up Katsuki? He swallows again.

‚ÄúBakugou has a problem with everyone,‚Äù Aoyama dismisses casually while Izuku is stuck like a dear in headlights.

Undeterred, Ashido insists, ‚ÄúNot like this! He calls him Deku! What‚Äôs the deal with that? Is that your v‚Äì Ow!‚Äù Across from her, Kaminari widens his eyes conspicuously. ‚ÄúFine, geeze,‚Äù she mutters. ‚ÄúYou didn‚Äôt need to kick me.‚Äù

They know, Izuku thinks, verging on hysterical. They all know. Of course they know. He already knew that they knew. It‚Äôs good they know. Lambs shouldn‚Äôt stay ignorant of wolves in their midst. These questions, this cheer. They are curious, but they‚Äôre treating him like this because they are being careful. Careful with him, careful of him. Like he is porcelain, or maybe a time bomb. Izuku can‚Äôt tell the difference. Can they?

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a very personal question,‚Äù Yaoyorozu scolds after a silence that stretches a few seconds too long. ‚ÄúMaybe Asui had the right idea.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù Ashido asks, voice rising in pitch as she approaches a whine. ‚ÄúI was just curious, since when is that a crime?‚Äù

Sternly, Yaoyorozu frowns, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a crime when you make your classmates uncomfortable, Ashido.‚Äù

‚ÄúA classroom crime,‚Äù Kaminari agrees solemnly.

‚ÄúMaybe we should go‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Ashido groans, three syllables longer than the single word should be. ‚ÄúWe haven‚Äôt gotten the chance to talk hardly at all!‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs only his third day,‚Äù Hagakure points out, more subdued than before. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôll be plenty of time to talk later on. When he‚Äôs had some more time to, um, adjust, maybe.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo, no, no. Look, I won‚Äôt ask about Bakugou or any of the ‚Äì other stuff, swear. Pinky promise! And let me tell you, my pinky promises are the super special unbreakable kind. I‚Äôm very trustworthy! That‚Äôs fine, right Mido?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äì‚Äù Izuku says and gets no further. He can‚Äôt think of anything else to say, much less force the words out of his mouth, out of his throat that closes down around them like a vice.

‚ÄúThat means scram,‚Äù Dark Shadow says, suddenly popping up over the edge of the table, yellow eyes neon bright and menacing.

‚ÄúYou too, Tokoyami?‚Äù Ashido laments, resting her arms in front of her and collapsing into them. ‚ÄúThe entire table, plotting against me. Fine! Let‚Äôs go.‚Äù She springs back up, jumping out of her seat in the same movement. As Kaminari and Hagakure stand, Ashido takes a few steps away, but then she stops and turns back, rocking on her heels with her arms folded behind her. ‚ÄúI really am sorry if I made you uncomfortable, Midoriya. I‚Äôll try to be better about it the next time we talk. Okay, bye!‚Äù Half-skipping, half-jogging, she goes off to a different table, and with soft apologies of their own, Kaminari and Hagakure both follow.

The only person remaining on the other side of the table, Yaoyorozu taps her hands on the tabletop. A second later, she nods resolutely to herself and stands.

‚ÄúSorry,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúI know that we ‚Äì 1-A ‚Äì can be‚Ä¶ a lot. They didn‚Äôt mean any harm. They‚Äôre just excited. The questions‚Ä¶‚Äù She takes a deep breath and looks Izuku in the eye with uncharacteristic directness. ‚ÄúWhat you tell us and when is up to you. We trust our teachers. If you never want to tell us what brought you here, you don‚Äôt have to. But‚Ä¶ just for the record, I don‚Äôt think you need to be afraid to tell us. We really are happy to have you, Izuku. Thanks for letting us sit with you for a bit.‚Äù

Eyes stinging, Izuku reaches across the table as Yaoyorozu turns to leave. He catches himself just short of touching her, but she stops as if he had grabbed her sleeve, looking back to him. Patience and curiosity turn to concern as the tears gathered in his eyes spill over. He sniffs a rough breath through his nose, scrubbing beneath his eyes with the cuff of his sleeve.

‚ÄúYou can st-stay, if you w-want,‚Äù he offers, proud of himself for not sounding completely choked and equally anxious to be offering at all. Rushed, he adds, ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt h-have to if you don‚Äôt want t-to, ob-obviously, but you c-can, I wouldn‚Äôt m-mind‚Ä¶‚Äù

Belatedly, Izuku realizes that Aoyama or Tokoyami might have an opinion on the matter, and he looks between them with the faintest beginnings of panic. Aoyama smiles serenely and Tokoyami nods. Even Dark Shadow, with her obvious dislike of many social situations, doesn‚Äôt seem to resent the offer.

Yaoyorozu blinks a few times. Normally she eats with Todoroki, Izuku knows. Sometimes, Jirou joins them, but today Jirou is sitting with Ojiro and Shoji, and Yaoyorozu never joins them, so she would be going back to Todoroki. Who, just earlier, she had admitted to not being particularly close to. If not for that, Izuku doubts he would have gathered the nerve to extend the offer at all.

But Izuku likes Yaoyorozu. She is soft spoken to the extent that she‚Äôs often overlooked, but intelligent and discerning, not to mention incredibly capable, and more mellow than the majority of class 1-A, who put Izuku on edge with their well-intentioned exuberance.

After a moment, Yaoyorozu smiles, shy and hesitant. ‚ÄúI would love to,‚Äù she says, lowering herself back into her seat. Izuku breathes a silent sigh of relief, built up tension finally unspooling along his spine.

The five of them settle into silence for the moment ‚Äì Tokoyami and Yaoyorozu perhaps naturally, though Aoyama is certainly forcing himself to give Izuku some time to recover. Lunch, in general, is something that Izuku doubts can ever truly be peaceful. There are at least a hundred people in the cafeteria, talking, shrieking, yelling. Loud and abrupt noises come from every direction, only some of them easily identifiable. Even as Izuku finally starts to relax and give some focus to his meal, he remains vigilant to the things around him. No, the moment certainly isn‚Äôt peaceful, but it is probably as close as it can get, and for Izuku, it‚Äôs close enough.

This thought, of course, is a veritable sign to the universe, like a challenge or a dare to prove him wrong.

‚ÄúWere you here yesterday?!‚Äù a voice yells, growing louder as it rapidly grows closer. ‚ÄúNo, you weren‚Äôt! I looked; I would have seen you ‚Äì looking is one of my specialties!‚Äù

All of a sudden, Izuku‚Äôs field of view is filled as Hatsume Mei shoves herself into the narrow gap between his seat and Tokoyami‚Äôs. Surprised, Izuku leans back, accidentally bumping into Aoyama, who props Izuku up with his shoulder, so Izuku doesn‚Äôt go scrambling to the floor. Mei leans in close, the crosshair in her eye expanding and contracting as if to demonstrate that she is, in fact, very good at looking.

‚ÄúWhere have you been, Pen Boy?!‚Äù she demands, far too loud now that she is in Izuku‚Äôs personal space. ‚ÄúI have stuff to show you! Do you mind if I sit here?‚Äù Without waiting for a response ‚Äì which would have been how will you sit here, there‚Äôs no chair ‚Äì Mei plants her butt on top of the table, swinging her legs up and around to the other side in a smooth arc that nearly catches Yaoyorozu. Mei hops down into the neighboring seat.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm Hatsume Mei, future CEO of Hatsume Industries,‚Äù Mei introduces herself to a baffled Yaoyorozu. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre Yaoyorozu Momo. If you ever want more costume, I‚Äôm in class 1-H. Now, Pen Boy, I need you to check the balance on this.‚Äù

No further warning is given ‚Äì a single innocuous statement, and then Mei reaches into one of the many blocky pouches along her belt and pulls out a knife. She slaps it onto the table with a triumphant noise. Izuku yelps. Yaoyorozu muffles a gasp behind her hands. Aoyama makes a choked noise that can‚Äôt decide between being a cough and a laugh. Dark Shadow squawks discordantly. Tokoyami remains silent, but the feathers on the crown of his head fluff out from each other, standing on end. With another noise, almost like a giggle, Dark Shadow reaches for the knife, but Tokoyami snatches it away, tucking it under the table. He holds it in his lap, knuckles white around the handle.

As uncomposed as Izuku has ever heard her, Yaoyorozu hisses, ‚ÄúHatsume!‚Äù

‚ÄúCall me Mei!‚Äù

‚ÄúWhy do you have a knife?‚Äù

‚ÄúSo Pen Boy can check the balance. I thought I already said that.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt just carry a knife around the school!‚Äù

‚ÄúNo one stopped me.‚Äù

‚ÄúDid they know?‚Äù

Mei thinks for a second. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt see how they would‚Äôve. I didn‚Äôt tell anyone.‚Äù Yaoyorozu stares at her, horrified. The odd noise in Aoyama‚Äôs throat finally settles on laughter.

‚ÄúHello, you merveilleux m√©canicien,‚Äù he greets.

Mei smiles blankly. ‚ÄúHi, I don‚Äôt know what that means.‚Äù Aoyama laughs again. ‚ÄúAnyway, the knife. Balance? Good? You‚Äôre the one who‚Äôs going to need to use it, so give it a whirl.‚Äù

‚ÄúMe?‚Äù Izuku asks.

‚ÄúYes, you, dummy. You promised you‚Äôd let me make your babies‚Äì‚Äù Yaoyorozu repeats the word in a small, strained voice, ‚Äú‚Äìso here I am! By the way, I am very annoyed that you haven‚Äôt come to the studio. It has been three whole days Pen Boy, get with it, chop chop! Also, do you want a jet pack? I remember you liked the jet pack. That was only a prototype. I could make you an even better one. And don‚Äôt forget about the knife! I need to know! Balance is key, Pen Boy!‚Äù

Beneath the table, Tokoyami passes Izuku the knife. Izuku glances around, sure that someone is going to pop out of thin air and lock him up in chains for this ‚Äì like they needed any reason to, on top of the Shinsou incident. He weighs the blade in his palm, spins it a few times. It feels impeccable, and he tells Mei as much. Too nervous to pass it back to her, he rests it on his thigh and tries to arrange the hem of his jacket to conceal it.

‚ÄúI‚Äôll make it better before it‚Äôs finalized,‚Äù she assures him, even though Izuku hadn‚Äôt offered any complaints. ‚ÄúNow ‚Äì jetpack?‚Äù

‚ÄúUh, no. No jetpack.‚Äù

‚ÄúNo jetpack?!‚Äù she groans and glares at him as if he has personally wronged her. Izuku just shrugs under the brunt of her discontent. With the quirks at his disposal, a jetpack would be more of a burden than a boon. Of course, Mei doesn‚Äôt exactly know that, but he has the sneaking suspicion that the information wouldn‚Äôt have made a difference in her offer or her displeasure in his rejection.

Mutinously, Mei mutters under her breath, ‚ÄúYour designs are so simple.‚Äù The corner of Izuku‚Äôs mouth twitches, amused, but still a bit too nervous to smile considering the weapon in his lap.

‚ÄúP-practical,‚Äù he corrects.

‚ÄúBoring!‚Äù She pouts at him, then shakes her head rapidly. ‚ÄúYou should come to the studio after lunch. I‚Äôve got more stuff to show you, and! Some ideas! That are ‚Äòpractical,‚Äô‚Äù she mimes dramatic air quotes around the word, ‚Äúand super cool!‚Äù

‚ÄúI have class.‚Äù Mei blinks at him as if the thought has never occurred to her. Likely, it never has. The twitching at the corner of his mouth intensifies as Izuku actively tries to repress a smile. Mei narrows her eyes.

‚ÄúFuck class!‚Äù she declares. Yaoyorozu gasps again, sending Mei a scandalized look. Izuku ducks his head as the people sitting nearest to them all fall quiet, glancing curiously at Mei‚Äôs commotion. Mei herself looks terribly proud of her proclamation.

With gleeful rebellion, Dark Shadow echoes, ‚ÄúFuck class!‚Äù

‚ÄúDark Shadow!‚Äù Tokoyami groans.

‚ÄúI like you,‚Äù Mei decides, reaching across the table to give Dark Shadow a high five. Dark Shadow, at first very confused by the gesture, enthusiastically returns it when she realizes what is happening. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre my new favorite.‚Äù

‚ÄúIzuku is my favorite,‚Äù Dark Shadow tells Mei, earning another groan from Tokoyami. Izuku feels himself flush red, pulling at the curls on his forehead until they cover his eyes.

Mei nods agreeably, then asks, ‚ÄúWho‚Äôs Izuku?‚Äù

Aoyama, watching the interaction like it‚Äôs his favorite television program, breaks down laughing again, wrapping his arms around his stomach and leaning forward until his forehead rests on the table. Even Yaoyorozu is biting her lip, holding back mirth, despite her obvious confusion, edging close to distaste, towards Mei‚Äôs behavior. Dark Shadow attempts to use the moment as a distraction to sneak the knife from Izuku‚Äôs lap, but Tokoyami spots her, wrapping his arms around her face before she can get too far.

And Izuku still feels like everything is about to go wrong. Things can‚Äôt stay right forever, they just can‚Äôt. Moments like these, foreign and joyful as they are, are strictly rationed in life. He will only get so many, and then he will go back to starving, he‚Äôs sure. Someday, the other shoe will drop, like an executioner‚Äôs blade, like a body limp on a hanging post. But until then ‚Äì

Until then, Izuku can pretend that he‚Äôs just a regular fifteen-year-old, making friends for the first time.
