Chapter Text

Hitoshi is soup.

He has been doing some thinking since yesterday afternoon, arguably too much, and he has decisively concluded, with the specific kind of certainty possessed only by the enlightened or exhausted ‚Äì or perhaps both, considering that the more thinking Hitoshi does, the less sleep he gets ‚Äì that he is soup. Now, that may sound like nonsense, but bear with him.

First, there‚Äôs the broth of confusion. Broth is the base of any good soup, and Hitoshi‚Äôs has been boiled down for potency. His restless night has only served to cement the fact that he has no idea what‚Äôs going on. Trying to slot the pieces of the puzzle together just gives him a headache ‚Äì not that that has stopped him from turning the situation around in his mind, failing over and over to find an angle from which things make sense. The only conclusion he has to show for all his hard work is that he is confused. And also, possibly an idiot.

Next there‚Äôs the chunks ‚Äì because a soup without chunks is just an oddly savory drink, and that‚Äôs a hill Hitoshi will die on. Hitoshi Soup calls for some roughly diced cubes of resentment and bitterness. Admittedly, after the whole fiasco, Hitoshi can‚Äôt find it in himself to direct any of those feelings towards Midoriya, but they‚Äôre still there, just kind of bobbing aimlessly in the broth.

Finally, sprinkled over top like a melted cheese ‚Äì self-loathing. Because Hitoshi fucked up, somehow. He doesn‚Äôt regret calling Midoriya on his bullshit, but Hitoshi can acknowledge that he quickly became the asshole in that conversation. It‚Äôs not even that hindsight is 20/20 ‚Äì he knew at the time that he shouldn‚Äôt have been running his mouth like that, and he chose to do it anyway, even after it became obvious that he was whacking a wasps‚Äô nest with a stick. Worst part is, he‚Äôs pretty sure that Midoriya‚Äôs the one who ended up getting stung. Hitoshi doesn‚Äôt have any excuses. The only explanation he can offer is that being an asshole is apparently the one thing that comes naturally to him.

So, there‚Äôs the recipe. Put some hard-to-swallow bitterness and resentment into a base of confusion, shred some self-loathing over the top, and that‚Äôs Shinsou Hitoshi‚Äôs patented special. Congratulations, it tastes like shit. Hitoshi has been stewing in it. The bitterness coats his mouth; the self-loathing gives him heartburn.

‚ÄúReady to go, Listener?‚Äù Yamada-Sensei asks. While Hitoshi stared resolutely at his desk, his classmates have all dispersed to go home or attend whatever after school activities they invest their time into. Hitoshi‚Äôs chest burns when he swallows, as if the acid from his stomach is encroaching on his throat, but he nods without looking at Yamada.

This morning, Hitoshi‚Äôs homeroom teacher had approached him very gently to suggest that he and Midoriya talk after class to ‚Äúsort things out.‚Äù It was made abundantly clear that Hitoshi could say no if he wanted to ‚Äì and boy did he want to. He can‚Äôt really see any conversation that he‚Äôs involved in going well. His track record provides ample evidence for his complete lack of diplomacy, or even civility. Hitoshi agreed anyway.

Yamada claps once, a sharp, abrupt noise puncturing Hitoshi‚Äôs apprehensive silence. ‚ÄúGreat! Then follow me!‚Äù With excessive enthusiasm, Yamada leads the way to the teachers‚Äô lounge, holding the door open and gesturing a much more subdued Hitoshi inside. Several teachers look up as he enters and Hitoshi slouches down under their curious eyes.

‚ÄúI need the room!‚Äù Yamada announces, reversing the motion he just made to usher Hitoshi in, shooing everyone else out. Two of the room‚Äôs occupants comply, with only a shrug and a shaken head. Hitoshi shrinks slightly away from them, avoiding their eyes as they pass him by. From the couch, Kayama-Sensei raises her eyebrows. She sits with her feet up on the cushion next to her, bare, heels discarded to the side, a bag of chips open in her lap.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm a teacher,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm lounging.‚Äù Pointedly, she pops a chip into her mouth, crunching it loudly.

‚ÄúEveryone out!‚Äù Yamada gestures again, exaggeratedly sweeping his arm back and forth. ‚ÄúThis is a hostile takeover!‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm grading,‚Äù Snipe-Sensei says flatly, pointing at the haphazard pile of papers in front of him.

‚ÄúGrade in your office!‚Äù

‚ÄúMy office smells like gunpowder.‚Äù

Kayama scrunches up her nose. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not your office. That‚Äôs just you.‚Äù

‚ÄúIzuku should be here, soon,‚Äù Yamada says. Hitoshi thinks, for a moment, that the seeming non sequitur must be for his benefit, but Yamada is looking at Snipe with a teasing smile, just a touch malicious.

‚ÄúRight,‚Äù Snipe says, standing abruptly. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll grade in my office, then.‚Äù He gathers his papers into a neat stack and leaves to the backtrack of Kayama‚Äôs laughter.

‚ÄúBetter run!‚Äù she calls after him. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt want the scary fifteen-year-old to catch you!‚Äù Snipe flips her off as he goes, hiding his middle finger behind his hand like that will prevent Hitoshi from figuring out what he‚Äôs doing. Yamada waves Snipe off cheerfully, then looks expectantly to Kayama. He clears his throat, wiggles the door slightly on its hinges. With a put-upon sigh that makes her fringe flutter over her forehead, Kayama stands.

‚ÄúFine,‚Äù she relents, rolling up the top of her bag of chips and stashing them under her arm as she crouches to retrieve her shoes. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll go. But you owe me! Really, you could have used any room in the building, but no ‚Äì you just had to pick the one I‚Äôm in.‚Äù

‚ÄúYep!‚Äù Yamada chirps. ‚ÄúThis is an intentional attack against you, personally! Now scram!‚Äù

Kayama‚Äôs theatrical pout gives way to giggles at Yamada‚Äôs bright grin, and she crosses the room on bare feet, heels dangling from her fingers by their straps. With her free hand, she ruffles Hitoshi‚Äôs hair as she passes, and he reflexively bats her hand away before freezing up with his arm half-raised and his shoulders hunched up towards his ears.

‚ÄúTell Izu I said hi,‚Äù she says, patting Yamada on the arm as she exits. He closes the door behind her.

‚ÄúHow are you feeling?‚Äù Yamada-Sensei asks when they‚Äôre left alone. Hitoshi blinks, still standing stiffly near the door, even as Yamada grabs a chair from the table, drags it across from the couch, and collapses into it, legs sprawling out in front of him. Yamada nods to the couch. ‚ÄúTake a seat! It‚Äôs the comfiest couch in the building, you know.‚Äù

Hitoshi stares at the piece of furniture for a moment, plush navy-blue cushions faded in their centers. When he sits, he sinks in slightly, as if the couch is fighting his attempts to perch on its edge by pulling him backwards. It is comfortable, he‚Äôll admit, and Hitoshi wonders if this is why Yamada brought him here, specifically. Comfortable couch for an uncomfortable conversation. Maybe Hitoshi is reading too much into it, but it puts him slightly at ease, nonetheless.

‚ÄúSo?‚Äù Yamada prompts. ‚ÄúFeelings? You doing okay?‚Äù

‚ÄúOh. Oh, uh, yeah, I ‚Äì I‚Äôm fine.‚Äù This is probably an obvious oversimplification, at best. Hitoshi isn‚Äôt fine ‚Äì he‚Äôs soup. But he‚Äôs not going to get into all that, right now. He suspects the whole analogy would make far less sense if he said it aloud. Hitoshi squirms, settling more firmly into his corner of cushions. Still, Yamada just smiles and nods, not pressing.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm glad. Let me know if that changes. You don‚Äôt have to be here, and you don‚Äôt have to talk about anything you don‚Äôt want to, ya dig?‚Äù

After a moment, Hitoshi realizes he is meant to reply. ‚ÄúI‚Ä¶ dig. It‚Äôs dug.‚Äù

When the door opens a moment later, Hitoshi‚Äôs fingers tighten on the arm of the couch, nails digging into the fabric like claws before he forces himself to relax. He smooths his expression to an approximation of unimpressed boredom, meeting Aizawa‚Äôs similar, though likely more convincing, mask as the man enters the room. Midoriya follows him in, guiding the door as it closes so it doesn‚Äôt slam shut, eyes fixed on the handle while Aizawa drags a chair next to Yamada‚Äôs. Door latched into place, Midoriya turns, bending at the waist so abruptly that Hitoshi is briefly disoriented.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù Midoriya says, voice forced into such evenness that it‚Äôs nearly inscrutable, especially with his face directed towards to floor. ‚ÄúI acted rashly and lashed out, and I‚Äôm sorry. However, I know that an apology doesn‚Äôt reverse my actions or the harm I‚Äôve done. If you speak to Nedzu about my behavior, he‚Äôll see that it‚Äôs reported to the proper authorities and dealt with appropriately.‚Äù

Any composure Hitoshi managed to gather melts away under the brunt of soup. To hear of rashness, of lashing out, of harm and inappropriate behavior from Midoriya ‚Äì it calls forth all the confusion, the bitterness, the self-loathing as intensely as ever. Hitoshi is the one who threw shit at the fan, but Midoriya is here apologizing for Hitoshi-doesn‚Äôt-even-know what.

‚ÄúNo,‚Äù Hitoshi blurts. ‚ÄúWhat? Stand up.‚Äù The words come out too aggressive, like an order instead of a request, but after a second, Midoriya listens. His face is blank when he first straightens, disconcertingly so, but cracks of uncertainty quickly spread through that facade. He clasps his hands behind his back. His too-big eyes are too expressive, doubtful, trepidatious, and contrite. Rather than look at him, Hitoshi stares at a frayed thread sticking out of a seam on the arm of the couch.

‚ÄúTake a seat, Izuku,‚Äù Yamada says.

Midoriya glances from Yamada to the couch and back again. Silently, he does as told, pressing himself into the corner opposite to Hitoshi, more than an entire empty cushion left between them. With a quick look at Hitoshi, Midoriya carefully removes his shoes, setting them neatly to the side and folding his knees up against his chest. His socks are black, but the toes are covered by a cartoonish white cat head, with wide blue eyes. Stupidly, Hitoshi wants to ask where Midoriya got them. He bites his tongue around the impulse.

Chapter Text

There are good days and there are bad days.

The bad days are achingly familiar, so well-worn Izuku was almost numb to them, until recently. They have begun to burn again, like the fire of screaming nerves that lines torn skin. In that sense, the bad days are worse than they have been in years, every bad second of them reaching down into the marrow of Izuku‚Äôs bones, but he tells himself that it‚Äôs a bit like waking up from a coma. His body, his mind ‚Äì they don‚Äôt always want to support him. But he is regaining the strength he has lost, bit by bit.

There are bad days and there are good days.

Sometimes, a good day can abruptly become a bad one, the change lurching through Izuku like a gravitational shift. Nedzu will poke and prod and test Izuku‚Äôs limits until he finds a sore spot, and he won‚Äôt stop digging his claws in until Izuku cracks. A classmate, careless, oblivious, will say something they shouldn‚Äôt ‚Äì or rather, they‚Äôll say something Izuku shouldn‚Äôt hear. Izuku will remember something, something he that makes him sick to think of, something that makes him sick to have forgotten in the first place.

Good days. Bad days.

Good days, tenuous at best. Bad days, like a miasma, always threatening around the edges of things.

It‚Äôs a change. Izuku thinks it wouldn‚Äôt sound very good to most people, but to him it‚Äôs ‚Äì words escape him. He has good days. A few weeks ago, he would have said that wasn‚Äôt possible, anymore.

Somedays, he wakes up, stretches lazy and warm, and tries not to disturb Lucy as he gets out of bed. He plays with Bastard, dancing around her teeth until she shrieks at him in frustration, demanding that he allow her to deliver her good morning nip. He and Eraser and Mic all eat breakfast together ‚Äì or drink it, in Eraser‚Äôs case ‚Äì and Izuku doesn‚Äôt feel like an intruder in the kitchen.  

Day by day, good by bad, things continue on. And, gradually, the students surrounding Izuku morph from class 1-A ‚Äì separate in an unattainable and poignant way, something he is apart from ‚Äì into Izuku‚Äôs classmates ‚Äì classmates, friends, a group of people he is a part of.

 

 

Quirkless sparring is probably Mashirao‚Äôs least favorite training exercise, for a variety of reasons.

For one thing, doing something without your quirk takes on a whole new meaning when your quirk is literally an extra limb. Blocking a blow with his tail and using it to control his movements is more than second nature to Mashirao ‚Äì it‚Äôs first. Especially with the degree of muscle memory he has, it takes constant focus to prevent himself from bringing his tail into the equation. Keeping it out not only distracts him, on top of interfering with his sense of balance.

Then there‚Äôs his opponents. As uncomfortable as the quirkless nature of the exercise is, the sparring in and of itself tends to be just as, if not more, frustrating for Mashirao. He‚Äôs the only member of the class with extensive martial arts training, putting him at a distinct advantage in these kinds of exercises. He takes no issue with his classmates‚Äô lack of formal skill ‚Äì no opponent should be underestimated. Mashirao himself has admittedly only achieved his rigid discipline by trading adaptability and improvisation, so it‚Äôs not as if he never loses. The problem is that many of his classmates don‚Äôt take the training seriously.

Despite his complaints, Mashirao can acknowledge the importance of learning to defend himself and others without the use of his quirk. Aizawa-Sensei is perfect evidence of how unreliable quirks can be, and while Mashirao himself doesn‚Äôt have to worry about counters like Erasure, he still may find himself in a situation where his tail is unable to help him, where it may even become a hinderance.

His classmates don‚Äôt all seem to see the situation as Mashirao does. They grumble, groan, roll their eyes. They don‚Äôt apply themselves half as ardently as they do to exercises where they can use their quirks.

Midoriya, though ‚Äì he‚Äôs good enough that Mashirao is surprised. There‚Äôs an obvious sloppiness to some of his forms, but he‚Äôs fast and he integrates several fighting styles so smoothly that he becomes hard to predict. ‚ÄúYou would have had me if you were more decisive,‚Äù Mashirao says, because it‚Äôs true. He‚Äôs noticed that Midoriya has a habit of pulling his punches, short seconds where he overthinks and hesitates. It wasn‚Äôt something Mashirao could take advantage of, really, but it could spell disaster in an actual battle. ‚ÄúWhere did you train?‚Äù Mashirao asks. Midoriya shakes his head. ‚ÄúI, um, I don‚Äôt ‚Äì I haven‚Äôt. My d-dad trained me and my br‚Äì‚Äù The sentence cuts off abruptly, Midoriya‚Äôs lips forming a pale seal over a bitten off word.

Group work is hard. It just is. Especially in heroics, when lots of complicated things need to be discussed in a strictly limited amount of time. His own passive participation smarts, a shameful awareness of his lack of contribution that burns particularly hot when he actually has thoughts that could advance a strategy, thoughts that he almost always ends up holding back because he can‚Äôt overcome his own stupid issues. Toru isn‚Äôt a strategic genius or anything, but she has a pretty solid plan A. It does the trick nine times out of ten, in all types of situations. She‚Äôs been carefully honing this particular strategy for over a decade now, and she thinks the time investment shows in how effective it is.

That‚Äôs right! Be invisible. People can‚Äôt stop what they can‚Äôt see. Most of the time, anyway. Nine times out of ten. Well, twelve times out of seventeen, but that doesn‚Äôt have the same ring to it. She rounds up ‚Äì sue her.

Plan B isn‚Äôt as well-developed as plan A. It‚Äôs more circumstantial, too. More of your traditional ‚Äúassess the situation and respond accordingly‚Äù type deal. Area of effect quirks and sensory quirks. AKA, the banes of Toru‚Äôs existence! Some people, it turns out, can stop what they can‚Äôt see ‚Äì either by releasing such large attacks that they can inadvertently catch her in the crossfire or by hearing instead of seeing. Disgusting.

Today, the stars have aligned and none of those nasty plan B-ers are on the team Toru‚Äôs facing. She creeps down a hallway, pressed close to the wall. The class listens intently. This is the first time any of them have brought up Izuku‚Äôs history with their class, explicitly and to his face. They have all been waiting for this moment, and curiosity had been creeping closer to its boiling point every day. Patience was a rare and limited resource in 1-A.

Tsu keeps her focus on Izuku, ignoring the attentive eyes around them. The dimple on Izuku‚Äôs forehead deepens. The consternation on his face is almost comical, especially with the asymmetry of his eyebrows, but Tsu refrains from speaking that particular thought out loud.

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt do anything,‚Äù he argues.

‚ÄúThat man, Shigaraki, he could turn things to ash with his hands. He was hardly an inch away from grabbing my face when you stopped him.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat?‚Äù Uraraka gasps. ‚ÄúTsu, you never said anything about that!‚Äù

It‚Äôs true; Tsu has mostly tried to forget the helpless horror of the whole situation, comforting herself with her survival and refusing to be haunted by what ifs. Tsu watches him withdraw, a rapid shift that leaves him feeling much farther away than he physically is. He retreats into himself without moving at all; the only change is something intangible in his eyes.

Maybe Tsu should have waited longer to bring it up. Maybe she never should have gotten so detailed. She remembers the way Izuku had been crying, the way Shigaraki had called him Rogue, the familiar way they had spoken to each other. Everything has happened so quickly.

‚ÄúYou shouldn‚Äôt thank me for that,‚Äù Izuku tells her, nearly a whisper.

Tsu hesitates but shakes her head. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm glad you were there,‚Äù she insists. ‚ÄúI think it would have been worse if you hadn‚Äôt been. Thank you, Izuku.‚Äù

 

 

I‚Äôm glad you were there.

I‚Äôm glad you were there and an audience of idiots, listening with bated breath as a villain is declared a hero.

 

I‚Äôm glad you were there.

 

Katsuki wasn‚Äôt glad.

When he saw Deku at the USJ, Katsuki had thought that he was dead. He had thought he was in fucking hell. If souls existed, Katsuki‚Äôs had screamed in the face of perpetual torment, that‚Äôs how in hell he had thought he was. His own personal demon, there to torture him, punish him, ruin him.

Deku ruined everything. He ruined Katsuki.

Of course he did, he was a goddamned villain.

 

 

 

Katsuki needs him to be the villain. Because Katsuki is going to be a hero. Everyone knows that the hero always wins. If Deku is the villain and Katsuki is the hero, then everything is going to be fine. If Deku‚Äôs not the villain, then ‚Äì

What does Katsuki punch? How does he win?

If Deku‚Äôs not the villain, then what are Katsuki‚Äôs nightmares about? And how does he stop having them? When will things be fine again?

 

Do you ever feel like you‚Äôre already dead? Or maybe like you were never alive to begin with. Katsuki doesn‚Äôt know if he has a pulse.

 

He thinks this might be hell. It feels like Deku has damned him. It feels like Deku is climbing over him, rising higher as he drags Katsuki deeper. It feels wrong. It tastes like ash and copper, a single warbling, high-pitched note. Everyone stares at him, but their faces all look warped, like plastic, like they‚Äôre not human. They stare at him like he‚Äôs not human.

Katsuki realizes he has been speaking. He hasn‚Äôt heard a word of what he‚Äôs said.

Hobo-Sensei is a dark silhouette in the doorway, with hellfire in his eyes.

Katsuki thinks he must be in hell.

Chapter Text

Shouta leaves the class alone for fifteen minutes.

It‚Äôs fine ‚Äì it should be fine. He does it all the time. They‚Äôre big boys and girls, and Vlad is right next door in case they get up to anything they really shouldn‚Äôt. Shouta can take fifteen minutes out of their study period to discuss the upcoming internships with Nedzu without the world ending.

A monitor beeps.

Nedzu‚Äôs computer makes any variety of noises. Shouta has learned to just ignore the whistles and chimes, same as Nedzu does. This particular tone catches the rat‚Äôs attention, and he spins away from Shouta midsentence to click around, faster than Shouta can register, until tinny audio fills the room.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt talk about my mother,‚Äù Izuku says. Shouta‚Äôs spine straightens, a rigid line of steel to match the unyielding harshness of Izuku‚Äôs voice.

‚ÄúAbout what?‚Äù Bakugou‚Äôs voice, but uncanny. It‚Äôs dull and level, hardly rising with his question. ‚ÄúAbout how she lied for years?‚Äù

Shouta meets Nedzu‚Äôs eyes. Something is wrong with Bakugou. Something is wrong. It‚Äôs a rare occasion ‚Äì and not a desired one ‚Äì where the rat stops smiling. Now, the black specs of his eyes are no longer glinting or mischievous. He looks grim.

Reaching over the desk between them, Shouta grabs Nedzu by the collar of his suit, tugging him out of his seat and dumping him unceremoniously in the loops of Shouta‚Äôs capture weapon. ‚ÄúBakugou,‚Äù Shouta growls, surprised at the gravel of his own voice.

Bakugou blinks ‚Äì once, slowly and slightly out of sync, twice. His mouth twitches. An explosion pops in palm, barely anything more than a wisp of smoke that Shouta snuffs out immediately with Erasure. Staring at his own hand, Bakugou‚Äôs eyes widen abruptly, lips curling back over his teeth in a snarl.

‚ÄúBakugou!‚Äù Shouta shouts, just as Bakugou begins to turn back to Izuku, a harsh, unformed syllable already spilling out of his mouth. ‚ÄúOut!‚Äù

‚ÄúHuh?!‚Äù

‚ÄúWe need to talk.‚Äù

Nedzu pats a small paw against Shouta‚Äôs cheek. Shouta flinches away from the unexpected gesture. Unraveling part of Shouta‚Äôs capture weapon from around his neck, Nedzu uses the length to rappel to the floor.

‚ÄúLet me take this, Shouta,‚Äù he says, smiling in a way that shows the tiny points of his teeth. ‚ÄúI think Bakugou and I are overdue for a conversation. How about you handle things here?‚Äù

A vicious part of Shouta wants to protest. He‚Äôs tired of Bakugou. Tired of all his bullshit and the way he keeps, keeps relentlessly, dragging Izuku down into whatever mire his head is stuck in. Sure, yes, Bakugou has been improving, Shouta can acknowledge that. The boy he met on the first day of school never would have voluntarily started therapy, never would have requested help or even admitted that he needed it. Of course, all these reasons Shouta wants to protest are also reasons that Nedzu should be the one to handle to boy. ‚ÄúCome with me, Bakugou,‚Äù Nedzu says, pushing against Shouta‚Äôs shin until Shouta gets the hint and steps out of the door. Bakugou wobbles subtly on his feet when he stands and crosses the room. ‚ÄúDo you like tea?‚Äù Nedzu asks as they go on their way.

1-A is still silent. Shouta takes advantage of the moment, the calm before the storm, closing his eyes and taking a deep breath. He doesn‚Äôt know the whole of what Bakugou said, but he has his suspicions.

A voice breaks the silence, ‚ÄúThere, there, Izuku. It‚Äôs alright.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou can steal me if you want to. I wouldn‚Äôt even mind, you‚Äôre nice and I like you!‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not a quirk,‚Äù Tokoyami reminds Dark Shadow quietly, defusing any further attempts she might make at misguided comfort.

The door catches as it slides open, clattering on its tracks as it sticks, then banging the rest of the way into place. Chapter Text

There will be no more good days.

That‚Äôs what Izuku thought, when the aghast stares of class 1-A dug into his skin like frayed splinters. Dreams he had only half-dared to dream shattered just like that, scattered into fleeting little rainbows like a popped bubble, tacky and cold like drying tears. So long to peace and belonging and the hesitant sense of dawning hope that his life could ever be more than endless restitution.

That‚Äôs what Izuku thought.

By lunch the next day, he‚Äôs starting to think he could have been wrong.

Izuku slips into the classroom right before the bell rings. Eraser gives him a look as he slides into his seat, but says nothing, glaring at the whole of the unusually tame class before starting on the morning‚Äôs business.

When Izuku dares an investigative glance around the room, he sees several people darting him similar, cautious looks. Koda startles as their eyes meet, but after a nervous moment, signs a shaky, one-handed greeting that nearly reduces Izuku to tears. Ojiro looks back at Izuku as well, but he does so with a frown, lines creased into his forehead. The tip of his tail twitches restlessly next to the leg of his desk. Briefly, his eyes dart past Izuku‚Äôs shoulder, and then he flinches into his shoulders and turns to face the front.

Looking behind him, Izuku is greeted by Yaoyorozu‚Äôs fierce glare, though surprisingly, it‚Äôs aimed around the room instead of at him. Her face smooths into a smile, hesitant and weak, when she looks at him.

‚ÄúGood morning,‚Äù she whispers, even though Eraser is still drawling on with information about internships. It‚Äôs nothing they haven‚Äôt heard at least twice before, but it‚Äôs unlike her to speak over him.

‚ÄúM-morning,‚Äù Izuku says back. The word has barely any air behind it, practically a silent movement of his lips. The burning behind his eyes intensifies, and he turns away, blinking rapidly.

Her defensive glare and reassuring smile set a precedent for the rest of the day. Despite her claims against leadership, Yaoyorozu steps up. She is a firm and protective presence at Izuku‚Äôs back, discouraging people from so much as looking at him wrong throughout the first half of the day. He has no idea what he‚Äôs done to deserve that kind of loyalty, but when the bell rings for lunch, he can be nothing but grateful that he won‚Äôt have to spend it hiding in the teacher‚Äôs lounge again.

Yaoyorozu leads him to their normal table and sits across from him, as has become routine over the last week, and while Izuku may be relieved for her presence, he can‚Äôt help but tense up as he waits for others to join them. Or not, as the case may be.

Tokoyami had been quiet all day, not necessarily ignoring Izuku, but not engaging with him, either. Arriving to class as late as he had, Izuku had seen little of Kasumi ‚Äì classes bored her, so she tended not to manifest during them, though she had made a brief appearance during English to bite Izuku‚Äôs ear, laugh, and then disappear again.

Aoyama, on almost the exact opposite side of the classroom, hadn‚Äôt interacted with Izuku at all yet today. That wasn‚Äôt necessarily abnormal for them, as far apart as their seats were. Sometimes, they talked before homeroom began, if they were both there early, but Izuku had intentionally left no time for socializing in his morning. Occasionally, Aoyama would lean back to say something to Ashido and Kaminari, who spent most of the morning whispering together. Call him paranoid, but Izuku suspects that his own name is probably woven into those quiet conversations.

In the middle of overthinking exactly what all that could mean, the seats on either side of Izuku are filled. Aoyama clatters about with large, exaggerated arcs of his limbs as he settles down with his meal. Tokoyami sits in a smooth, silent movement, that could have gone entirely unnoticed, if not for Kasumi darting around him to steal a slice of meat from Izuku. Mic has actually started to make extra, specifically for her, but she likes to think she‚Äôs doing something she‚Äôs not supposed to, so Izuku plays along and pulls his food closer to himself, as if to guard it.

‚ÄúBonjour,‚Äù Aoyama greets with a beaming smile, pulling his food away from Kasumi‚Äôs claws. ‚ÄúJirou and Mei haven‚Äôt joined us yet?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhoever knows what Mei is getting up to,‚Äù Yaoyorozu says, nose scrunching delicately. ‚ÄúBut Jirou‚Ä¶‚Äù Her eyes skirt to the side. A few tables away, Jirou sits with Ojiro and Shoji. Yaoyorozu avoids looking at Izuku as she purses her lips and fiddles with her fingers.

Jirou has only been eating with them for a couple of days. Before that, she bounced between eating with Yaoyorozu and Todoroki, and Ojiro and Shoji. She could very well be doing the same thing now ‚Äì dividing her days between the different groups of people she was interested in spending time with. The timing could be a coincidence.

Izuku stares at the ceiling, strips of fluorescent lights distorting through a film of tears as he compels himself not to start crying. Yaoyorozu hums a distressed note; Aoyama pats Izuku between the shoulder blades. The casual, unwary touch makes the tears brim over, and Izuku slams his eyes closed to try to stem the flow before it really gets going.

‚ÄúCertainly she only needs a moment to sort this new chaos into her thoughts,‚Äù Tokoyami offers softly.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs n-not that,‚Äù Izuku says, shaking his head. ‚ÄúI just ‚Äì th-thank you.‚Äù

He is not crying because Jirou left. He is crying because the others stayed.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs nothing to thank us for,‚Äù Aoyama says. ‚ÄúNow, I demand opinions.‚Äù Without further delay, he launches into a dramatic retelling of a story he insists happened to his older sister, away at college in France. As with most stories Aoyama tells, there is very little room to actually offer any opinions, but he effectively captures everyone‚Äôs attention and diffuses the tension growing around them.

It's another thing to be grateful for, Aoyama‚Äôs knack for navigating tense situations without making it obvious that his distractions are deliberate. So Midoriya has a villain brother. Considering the whole villain father thing, Hitoshi shouldn‚Äôt be so surprised. Any brother of Midoriya‚Äôs was bound to be a villain, given the circumstances. That‚Äôs way more than kinda-sorta. That‚Äôs highly dangerous, don‚Äôt approach levels of villainy. Looking at Midoriya ‚Äì the slump of his shoulders, the bend of his neck, the shadows under his eyes, the scars around his wrist ‚Äì it occurs to Hitoshi that it has always been real. Fuck Shigaraki Tomura, and fuck whoever their father was, and fuck every link in the chain of events that led to Midoriya‚Äôs hands shaking over the titles of games he doesn‚Äôt even play. Family is a fucked up thing, Hitoshi knows. It can fuck people up.

The silence is smothering, and Midoriya seems to shrink more and more with every moment. He closes a hand around his right wrist, fingers slotting into the grooves of the scar there in a smooth, habitual movement that speaks of countless repetitions. Unconsciously, Hitoshi brings a hand up to his face, running his fingers over the divot on the bridge of his nose, nearly invisible but just deep enough that his nails catch in the groove every time he passes over it.

 ‚ÄúMy mom kept me muzzled.‚Äù

Hitoshi doesn‚Äôt realize he has spoken aloud until he notices Midoriya. His kicked-puppy raw-nerve vulnerability shifts instantaneously to a rictus of horror that makes Hitoshi‚Äôs stomach turn over and try to crawl up his throat.

‚ÄúI mean,‚Äù he says. Battery acid coats his tongue and teeth. He‚Äôs not sure what he means. He babbles, ‚ÄúYou know how it is. Turn four, get your quirk, it‚Äôs great, except four-year-olds aren‚Äôt really known for their, uh, control. Quirk control, impulse control, take your pick.

‚ÄúMy parents divorced when I was, I don‚Äôt know, two or something, right, and my mom took custody and my dad moved to the city for work, and I only saw him maybe a handful of times a year. ‚ÄúAnyway, Dad finally visited, um, a couple of months after. Got right pissed, took my mom to court, yada yada. The point is ‚Äì family is fucked up. Family fucks you up. But really‚Äì‚Äù Hitoshi clears his throat, voice scratchy and crackling. ‚ÄúFuck them.‚Äù

Excellent recovery, Hitoshi thinks to himself, lightheaded. Follow one incriminating statement up by word-vomiting even more. You know what would fix this mortifying situation? More mortification. Just overshare and make everyone uncomfortable, then the discomfort cancels out and you can all have a good laugh and move on. That‚Äôs definitely how it works. Good going, Hitoshi. ‚ÄúFuck them,‚Äù Todoroki repeats slowly, like he is testing the words. He says it again, more confidently, nodding once. Then, ‚ÄúMy father wants to use me as a tool to surpass All Might. He married my mother specifically in hopes of bearing a child with a quirk stronger than his own.‚Äù

‚ÄúA quirk marriage,‚Äù Midoriya spits, surprisingly vitriolic.

‚ÄúQuirk marriages are illegal,‚Äù Hitoshi says dumbly, still processing Todoroki‚Äôs words, the grim look on the boy‚Äôs usually impassive face. Todoroki scoffs. The sound seems inappropriately coarse coming from someone so quiet, so reserved, so distant.

‚ÄúNothing is illegal when you have money and power. He forced my mother to marry him, made her carry child after child, neglected them when they didn‚Äôt meet his standards, and drove my eldest brother to destruction with his ‚Äòtraining.‚Äô‚Äù

‚ÄúFuck him,‚Äù Hitoshi decides. ‚ÄúHe fucked you up, and he fucked your mom up. Fuck him.‚Äù

‚ÄúFuck All for One,‚Äù Todoroki says.

They don‚Äôt owe anything to anyone. If they fuck you up, then fuck them.

 

 

Entropy reigns supreme. Everything trends towards disorder.

Chapter Text

Shinsou and Todoroki get on like a house on fire. Which is to say, everything is terrible and Shouta feels the immediate need to evacuate. He thought Shinsou‚Äôs animosity was going to be tiring, but he takes it back; he‚Äôd take the snark and sarcasm over whatever weird bond they‚Äôve established, especially since Shinsou somehow still manages to be nearly as standoffish as before. ‚ÄúRight on time!‚Äù a chirpy voice greets the moment the group enters the gym.

Shouta freezes in mixed dread and relief. Nedzu stands expectantly at the center of the large room, hands folded politely behind his back as he smiles at them. ‚ÄúWhat are you doing here?‚Äù Shouta asks flatly.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm here to help!‚Äù Nedzu says. Shouta doubts that. ‚ÄúIzuku is still my personal student, after all. It only seems right that I assist with his internship where I can.‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt you have work to do?‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve cleared my schedule!‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat did you have in mind?‚Äù he asks.

‚ÄúJust a simple exercise,‚Äù Nedzu responds. He is likely trying to be reassuring, but he misses by a mile. ‚ÄúA game! Ground Beta has already been prepared.‚Äù

‚ÄúGround Beta?‚Äù Izuku asks.

‚ÄúAh, of course ‚Äì this will be a first for you and Shinsou, won‚Äôt it?‚Äù The rat grins. ‚ÄúGround Beta is one of our immersive training grounds. It‚Äôs generally used to teach students to be cautious of their environment and to avoid collateral damage, but in my experience it‚Äôs also great for scavenger hunts.‚Äù

The thin thread of restraint Izuku had been clinging to snaps. He bounces up on his toes. Shouta reaches back and grabs him by the skull to hold him down, not breaking eye contact with Nedzu. Shinsou is so desperate for sleep that Lullaby sweeps him away in only a handful of seconds. Izuku forces his tears to wait until he is sure Shinsou won‚Äôt wake up. Panic flashes through Izuku like a firecracker and he squeezes his eyes shut and takes a deep breath. No ‚Äì Shinsou will wake up, he will, just not for several hours, at least. When it is over, he is exhausted and his pulse throbs in his fingertips, but he feels better for having cried. He feels hollow now, too; there is a new emptiness inside him, but it is a cavern where all the pain and bitterness and grief had made their home. They have been washed away and the rest of him has been left behind. This is the kind of crying that is cathartic instead of catastrophic. He has been tired for hours ‚Äì hours, days, weeks, months, years, he has been tired ‚Äì and now he finally thinks he‚Äôll be able to get some sleep.

First, he gets up, careful not to step on any of the gangly limbs that Shinsou has splayed about the floor, to visit the kitchen. Izuku stifles a snort, moving as quietly as he can as he retrieves a glass from the cabinet and fills it from the tap.

He‚Äôs wearing his goggles, which look incredibly goofy with the brightly colored T-shirt advertising Mic‚Äôs radio show. Things decay. It‚Äôs what they do.

‚ÄúMidoriya?‚Äù Iida questions, faint and incredulous. His voice is strained, forced out of his throat. Stain has already rolled away and climbed back to his feet.

‚ÄúA friend come to rescue you. How nice,‚Äù he sneers, an absurd mix of mockingly saccharine and viciously derisive. To Izuku, he speaks with blunt dismissal, ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no point in trying to save him. Run along home. Playing hero will only seal your fates together.‚Äù

The alley is a dead end and the Hero Killer stands near the back of it, separated from Iida and Native and the rest of the city only by Izuku and a prayer. He looks more like a monster than a man.

Well ‚Äî the worst of the worst may look like monsters, may live like monsters, but they still die like men. Izuku knows that better than most. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not a hero,‚Äù Izuku says. ‚ÄúAnd I‚Äôm not playing.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd how are you helping, exactly?‚Äù Izuku asks, which is a different conversation all together. This is the question they can never answer. ‚ÄúI am the plague,‚Äù Stain replies, as if he has been sent by god. ‚ÄúI am the purge. Until this world realizes its mistake, I will cull the herd. Move, child,‚Äù he commands harshly. ‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt like to have to kill you tonight.‚Äù

Izuku activates Bullet Time just as Stain starts to move. He‚Äôs had the quirk on the back burner this whole time, a lucky bit of foresight, considering that Stain has already halved the distance between them in the split moment it took for time to stretch across Izuku‚Äôs eyes.

Izuku sees Stain coming, and he sees the knife, and with another quirk tossed into the mix, he can even see the arc the blade is most likely to take. But here‚Äôs the thing ‚Äî there are two important components of decision making in combat: processing time and reaction time.

Bullet Time only helps with one of those.

Izuku can hardly control the fingers of his left hand. They tremble violently, which only jostles his wound, but all he needs is to tap the metal of Stain‚Äôs weapon twice to magnetize it. ‚ÄúHis quirk!‚Äù Iida yells, speaking for the first time since Izuku engaged Stain. His voice is stronger now, and Izuku suspects that Stain‚Äôs quirk is beginning to wear off. Of course, Izuku doesn‚Äôt need a warning. He isn‚Äôt entirely sure how Stain‚Äôs quirk works. Izuku disarms Stain just as he had when he first entered the fight. Two more quirks take care of the pain and bleeding in his hand, numbing and sealing the wound.  Then, in that bare moment where Izuku can still move, he does so without thinking at all.

And Izuku is ‚Äî he‚Äôs angry. Izuku has never been angry like this, before. He has rarely been angry at all. It‚Äôs like cinnamon on the back of his tongue. Sweet and hot. The longer its there, the hotter it gets, until it‚Äôs not like cinnamon at all.

Anger ‚Äî real anger ‚Äî is a chili pepper. It burns. Hot enough to hurt. It makes your eyes water and your nose run and your stomach roll. That‚Äôs your body‚Äôs way of warning you off. Of saying, This is not good for you. This is toxic.

Instead of listening, Izuku eats it raw.

He has never burned before.

It feels better than drowning.

Izuku can barely feel his left hand, can‚Äôt feel it move, but he sees it wrap around Stain‚Äôs tongue, sees it and is grateful that the numbness means he can only feel the flexing wetness of it faintly, at the very tips of his fingers. A knife from Hatsume Mei was never going to be anything less than razor sharp.

The knife falls to the ground next as Izuku‚Äôs fingers go slack. His knees give out, crash into the concrete, he sways, tips forward. From the corner of his eye, Izuku can see the chunky soles of Stain‚Äôs boots, can see the man‚Äôs shadow shifting as he moves. Blood drips steadily from above, splashing onto Stain‚Äôs toes, starting to pool on the ground.

Izuku thinks of blood on concrete. He thinks of blades and executions and of what it means to kill someone kindly. The best death is a quick one, Izuku had thought. A person like Stain only needs a second to kill someone, which is quick, but it certainly won‚Äôt be kind.

His boot presses Izuku‚Äôs face further into the concrete, grinds against his ear like he‚Äôs nothing more than a bug. The blood keeps dripping. Izuku hopes the villain fucking chokes on it.

Stain may only need a second to kill someone, but he‚Äôs exactly the type of sadist who draws these things out. Unfortunately for him, Aizawa Shouta only needs a second to save a life, and he‚Äôs not arrogant or fool enough to waste an opening.

Izuku can‚Äôt see Aizawa, can‚Äôt see what‚Äôs happening, but he hears the commotion. The commotion‚Äôs name is Shinsou Hitoshi.

‚ÄúHey fuck face!‚Äù Shinsou shouts, breathless and vitriolic. ‚ÄúPick on someone your own size!‚Äù

 

 

There is blood in the alley.

Not as much as there could be, but too much. Too much because Shouta‚Äôs fucking kid is here, has been here, alone with one of the most prolific serial killers Japan has seen in years, for nearly ten minutes.

Shouta recognizes Native slumped against the wall, blood smeared down to the hero‚Äôs form. He‚Äôs alive. His eyes are open, and they lock on Shouta before swiveling frantically towards the others, as if there was any way Shouta hadn‚Äôt noticed them.

Iida is prone on the ground, blood on his face and one of his legs. He‚Äôs alive. He began shouting the moment Shinsou announced their presence, and his arms are twitching slightly by his sides.

Izuku is a dark, still shape, only a couple of meters away from Iida, and directly at the Hero Killer‚Äôs feet. Beneath the Hero Killer‚Äôs feet. He has a boot on top of Izuku‚Äôs head, and a dagger above his spine. Blood leaks steadily from the villain‚Äôs mouth, falling in fat droplets against Izuku‚Äôs hair, his ear, his neck, his shoulders. He‚Äôs alive.

He has to be alive.

There is barely a pause between Shinsou‚Äôs declaration and the Hero Killer‚Äôs attack. He springs at them, leaping over Izuku like he‚Äôs just another piece of ruble in the ruined city. Definitely a concussion, probably a severe one. Normally, Shouta wouldn‚Äôt approve of using such force.

Shouta prides himself on a lot of things. His rationality is chief among them, especially when it comes to his work. There are few heroes that can keep as level a head as Shouta can in the field, who can efficiently and appropriately prioritize their response to a scene like this.

He has done it right, so far. Assess the situation. Neutralize any immediate threats. The next step is to ascertain the condition of anyone else on the scene. Both Iida and Native are stable, and Izuku might not even be alive ‚Äî so it is Shouta‚Äôs job to check on him. It is not Shouta‚Äôs job to drop to the ground, to skid on his knees to Izuku‚Äôs side. Scrambling around on the ground to see Izuku‚Äôs face is not rational or level-headed. Entirely ignoring Native and Iida and Shinsou is not appropriate or efficient. Slamming the Hero Killer against the wall as hard as he did and wishing ardently to do it again is not heroic.

Shouta is proud of his hero work. He takes his job very seriously. But at the moment, he is not proud; he is terrified. And at the moment, he is not a hero; he is a parent.

Izuku‚Äôs eyes are glazed, but he blinks blearily, and relief slams into Shouta like that fucking nomu slammed into their train at the beginning of the night. Shouta wants to hold his kid so fucking bad, and he knows he can hardly even touch him, because he doesn‚Äôt know what kind of injuries Izuku may have, and jostling him risks doing permanent damage. 

‚ÄúHey ‚Äòzawa,‚Äù Izuku says, slurred and broken, muffled because slightly because more than half of his face is squished into the ground. Shouta can see abrasions along his forehead, skims his thumb over one of them. Shouta leans over, keeps Izuku‚Äôs head between his arms while carefully not touching. ‚ÄúHow are you feeling?‚Äù Shouta asks. His voice is embarrassingly rough, but the place Shouta is in right now is so far from removed from embarrassment that dignity isn‚Äôt even a footnote in his considerations.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not,‚Äù Izuku says. Then adds, ‚ÄúPhysically, I mean. It's a quirk. Nerve deadening. Can‚Äôt really feel anything.‚Äù

Shouta can‚Äôt help but snort. He hunches further over Izuku and presses a hand over his eyes. He is used to them burning, but he‚Äôs not used to them being wet. He hasn‚Äôt been this afraid since he was a teenager. He doesn‚Äôt think he‚Äôs been this relieved ever.

‚ÄúHoly shit,‚Äù Shinsou says. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a tongue.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah. It‚Äôs Stain‚Äôs,‚Äù Izuku confirms as Shouta spine snaps straight. His eyes find the muscle, discarded like a hunk of bad meat.

‚ÄúWhy is it on the ground? Instead of, you know, his mouth?‚Äù

‚ÄúI cut it out,‚Äù Izuku responds flatly. Shinsou pales slightly, resolutely turning away from the gore, looking to Izuku with a crease between his eyebrows. Then he looks back to Shouta. If he notices that Shouta struggles to keep his attention from drifting, Shinsou doesn‚Äôt call him out.

‚ÄúSo, uh, what are we going to do about that?‚Äù he asks, jerking his head in the Hero Killer‚Äôs direction.

‚ÄúTie him up,‚Äù Shouta replies, pulling out a coil of the cable he prefers to use to bind criminals while waiting for the police to pick them up and tossing it Shinsou‚Äôs way. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs out,‚Äù Shouta assures. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll send out a message,‚Äù Shouta continues, communicator already in hand. ‚ÄúThen we wait for someone to make their way to us. It shouldn‚Äôt take too long if I mention that we‚Äôve detained the Hero Killer. Though the city is in shambles tonight, so there may be a delay.‚Äù

The wait has blurry edges. It is intolerably long and surprisingly short. Shouta sits by Izuku, keeps touching his hair, almost compulsively, and finally gets his shit together enough to check in with Iida and Native. The paramedics are the first to arrive, and when they do, the red and blue of their emergency lights wash into the alley and splash across the walls like strobes. Things shift second to second, too much between each blink, like the world is missing frames.

The facts are these:

The paramedics arrive first. Native and Stain are both taken directly to the hospital. Iida‚Äôs left leg can‚Äôt support his weight. Izuku‚Äôs left arm is broken in three places. Both boys will need surgery. All three will need therapy. Shouta is bullied into taking a shock blanket.

The pro heroes are last. They‚Äôre not needed, but they come anyway. Endeavor‚Äôs fire flashes brighter than the police lights. His glare is hotter than his flames. Shouta stands between him and Izuku. People are still screaming blocks away.

The nomu‚Äî

The night‚Äôs not over. One battle has been won, but the war still rages around them. Shouta has been processing the aftermath like he would write a mission report, all the while failing to realize that they haven‚Äôt actually made it to the after, not yet.

Shouta is standing between Izuku and Endeavor. Izuku is within arm‚Äôs reach. Shouta wants him closer, but Izuku had brushed him away. Izuku‚Äôs eyes droop each time he blinks. Without seeming to realize, he leans his shoulder against Shinsou‚Äôs, who stands stiff and pale besides him.

Izuku looks small, even as he glowers at the ground. He looks small, and tired, and Shouta wants to take him home, shove a cat into his arms, and insist he rest.

He is so, so small. And the nomu is so big. And Shouta is so fucking useless.

No one sees it coming until it is already on top of them, dropping from the sky and rising back up just as abruptly. It‚Äôs leathery wings carry it in a jerky, lopsided flight, and carrying Izuku along with it.

He had been within arm‚Äôs reach.

 

 

Reality is an unstoppable force.

 

A regret:

The light at the end of the tunnel is only the light of an oncoming train.

 

 

Hope is not an immovable object.

Chapter 42: Bloodcurdle - Part VI
Notes:

    A reunion. Of sorts.

    Nothing is as bad as it seems. Except Tomura. He is probably worse. Wind him up and watch him go :))

Chapter Text

It is so anticlimactic that Tomura is nearly disappointed. Then again, the traitor doesn‚Äôt deserve anything grand. ‚ÄúLook at this, Kurogiri!‚Äù Tomura laughs. It‚Äôs a high, giddy sound that is rusty in his throat, like a creaking hinge. ‚ÄúWhat are the chances? RNG‚Äôs on my side tonight.‚Äù

Kurogiri merely hums. It‚Äôs not the amount of enthusiasm the circumstances call for, but Kurogiri rarely cares the right amount about the right things, and Tomura rarely cares. The warp gate can be as dry and boring as he likes so long as he does his job. Tomura doesn‚Äôt keep him around for his sparkling personality. Tomura is getting less and less sure why he keeps him around at all, actually.

The traitor is still on the ground, where he should be, all low and pathetic and weak. His silence grates on Tomura‚Äôs nerves. His voice would grate, too, with the warbling tones and anxious stuttering, but the silence is worse. Like Tomura doesn‚Äôt deserve an explanation, like everything that has happened between them isn‚Äôt even worth the pretense of apology. Maybe ‚Äî maybe the traitor is just resigned, maybe he realizes that there‚Äôs nothing he can say to save himself now; maybe he realizes that Tomura is the judge, jury, and executioner here. Tomura‚Äôs lips crack and sting around his grin. ‚ÄúNothing to say?‚Äù he prompts.

Tomura‚Äôs grin twitches into a sneer. The skin of his neck crawls but he keeps his hands by his side, fingers loose and open and ready because he is going to need them.

The traitor brings a hand up to his chest, rubs a circle flat and stiff over the place where his heart would be if he had one. Kurogiri hums, a different note, more drawn out, like a wordless language that he has never bothered to share with Tomura.

Well fuck it, then. Fuck them both. No one wants to talk to Tomura, then Tomura won‚Äôt bother with talking. They‚Äôre past that, anyway. Words have always been flimsy things, pretending at power.

Tomura stalks a step forward. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs all this?‚Äù Tomura scoffs. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve always been soft, but you could hold your own in a spar, at least. A few weeks with some heroes and you‚Äôre already this dull?‚Äù

The traitor just shakes his head, reaching yet again for Tomura, for his face. Tomura growls through his teeth, grabs the traitor by the arm and tosses him to the ground. It‚Äôs easy; too easy. Tomura steps over him, straddles him with a foot on either side of his hips. Shouta and Shinsou have been given a chance to wash up ‚Äî which Shinsou took notably better advantage of than Shouta ‚Äî and change into loaned scrubs, a sea-foam color that looks ghastly on them both. Having already received a clean bill of health, at least physically, Shinsou sits cross-legged on the second hospital bed in the room, which is reserved for Izuku.

Izuku, of course, is in surgery. His ulna and radius need reconstruction. Whatever substance he used to seal the wound in his hand needs to be removed. He has lost a lot of blood, but one of the doctors on his surgical team has a blood replenishing quirk. When Shouta asks for updates, everyone says Izuku is doing well. That is the only thing any of them have to say.

‚ÄúHow is he?‚Äù Hizashi asks before the door has even closed behind him.

He is doing well. Shouta can‚Äôt bring himself to repeat it.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry,‚Äù he says instead. Hizashi‚Äôs eyebrows shoot up, high above the frames of his glasses. 

‚ÄúFor what?‚Äù he asks.

They stare at each other.

Todoroki shoots them a blandly curious look as he moves into the room, standing between the two beds, leaning against the end of Iida‚Äôs. He looks between Shouta and Hizashi again before turning to Shinsou.

‚ÄúWere you even trying not to die?‚Äù he asks, muted, as if not to interrupt, but still clearly audible because Shouta has yet to answer Hizashi‚Äôs question. Todoroki sounds so deeply disapproving that Shouta nearly laughs.

‚ÄúI lived, bitch,‚Äù Shinsou responds dryly.

‚ÄúAm I a bitch now?‚Äù The curse sounds odd from Todoroki‚Äôs mouth, but he says it without hesitating, with the same flat affect as everything else he says. ‚ÄúI thought I was a sucker.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou‚Äôre actually the first documented case of someone being both,‚Äù Shinsou tells him. ‚ÄúCongrats!‚Äù

‚ÄúOh. Thank you?‚Äù

That‚Äôs it. That‚Äôs the tipping point. The straw that breaks the camels back. The final nail in the coffin. When Shinsou laughs, Shouta does, too. That Shouta is the more hysterical-sounding of the two is alarming, to say the least, but he can‚Äôt quite reign it in. Todoroki jumps like a spooked cat.

Hizashi huffs a sympathetic little oof, grabbing Shouta‚Äôs hands to pull him up out of the chair he had been sitting in, walking backwards to lead him towards the door. Shouta‚Äôs eyes catch on the the point where their skin touches, where Hizashi smooths his thumb over the skin of Shouta‚Äôs inner wrist. It reminds him of the paramedic, how she kept her fingers on Izuku‚Äôs pulse, how her eyes lit up with it.

For what?

Shouta takes a breath. He swallows.

The walls of all the little compartments he‚Äôs built collapse in on him.

Hizashi yanks him forward, wrapping an arm around his waist as Shouta finally stops laughing and starts fucking crying instead. He hasn‚Äôt cried in ‚Äî he doesn‚Äôt even know how long. Long enough that he‚Äôs shocked when the tears actually manage to spill over. Hizashi is still in costume, but he‚Äôs removed his bulkier gear, and Shouta is glad for it when he ducks his head down against Hizashi‚Äôs shoulder.

‚ÄúAlright!‚Äù Hizashi calls, all injected cheer. ‚ÄúYou kiddos will be fine on your own for a bit, won‚Äôt you? Of course you will! There‚Äôs officers outside if you need anything. Don‚Äôt try to enact any vigilante justice while we‚Äôre gone, ya dig? We‚Äôve got some stuff to take care of, back soon. Peace!‚Äù

With that, Hizashi reaches behind himself for the door handle, kicks the thing wide open, and drags Shouta first out into the hall and then into a stairwell. He herds Shouta into a corner and leans against him. Thankfully the stairwell is empty, at least for the moment, but the space magnifies every small noise, amplifying the ragged sound of Shouta‚Äôs breathing as he tries to get himself back under control.

He is, in a word, mortified. Not one, not two, but three of his students just played witness to his meltdown. He‚Äôs fairly sure that none of them actually saw him crying, but he‚Äôs equally sure that they knew. Hizashi‚Äôs little act wasn‚Äôt fooling anyone. It‚Äôs transparently obvious that Shouta is the stuff that needs taking care of ‚Äî and god damn it, he‚Äôs still crying.

He‚Äôs not equipped for this. He‚Äôs not equipped to care this much. With Hizashi he at least knew what he was getting into, and it happened nice and slow, gave him plenty of time to acclimate. It still hurts sometimes, just loving him. This is too much, too fast. Shouta didn‚Äôt know it would be like this. He doesn‚Äôt want it; he couldn‚Äôt bear to lose it.

The police are already asking questions. Endeavor had been there, and he would never be their ally in this. And that fucking portal.

Shouta needs to tell Hizashi. It‚Äôs all his fault. He can‚Äôt even speak to own up to it. How pathetic.

Hizashi keeps Shouta insulated from the world, pinned between concrete and leather. He murmurs sweet nonsense into Shouta‚Äôs hair. God, does Shouta love him.

Izuku is still in surgery.

Everyone says he is doing well.

 

 

Nothing lasts forever.

When Izuku dreams, his family is with him.

They are never there, when he wakes.

 

Izuku can‚Äôt breathe. The smell of antiseptic assaults his nose. It feels flammable in his lungs. All of him feels a spark away from combustion. Overheated and unstable. Where is‚Äî he is in a hospital. Izuku hasn‚Äôt been in a hospital since before his mother died in one.

‚ÄúWoah there,‚Äù says the owner of the hand on Izuku‚Äôs arm. ‚ÄúEasy, Sprout.‚Äù

There are three people leaning over Izuku, and none of them are who they are supposed to be. He cringes away, but his deflated pillow has little give to it, meaning he can‚Äôt go far.

Everything is all messed up in his head. He‚Äôs in the hospital. He was shot‚Äî Wait. No. That was a while ago. When was it? When is it?

Hosu. Right. The train, and Iida, and Stain, and the nomu, and Tomura.

‚ÄúHey, hey, hey,‚Äù Mic soothes, easing Izuku back towards the bed when he struggles upright. He doesn‚Äôt want to lie down, but his limbs are heavy, body sluggish, so he has no choice but to let Mic guide him flat. ‚ÄúCan you take a breath for me, bud?‚Äù

Izuku gasps. It hisses in and out from between his teeth, shuddering.

‚ÄúTomura?‚Äù

‚ÄúHe was spotted during the attack,‚Äù Eraser says, eyes dark and watchful. ‚ÄúNo sign of him since.‚Äù

‚ÄúHosu?‚Äù

‚ÄúIs recovering.‚Äù

‚ÄúFatalities?‚Äù

‚ÄúLay down, problem child. You‚Äôve been out for days, you need to take it easy. We‚Äôll catch you up in time.‚Äù

‚ÄúWere there fatalities?‚Äù Izuku demands.

A pause drags into a silence that speaks volumes. What‚Äôs the point? Why even bother asking? Half a dozen nomu and a handful of explosions. Of course there were causalities. There‚Äôs no way everyone got out of that city with their life. Hell, the nomu that stopped their train had done so with the corpse of a hero in its clutches. Izuku knows what dead people look like, and that man was gone before he hit the ground.

‚ÄúGod damn it.‚Äù Izuku doesn‚Äôt sound like himself. Mic‚Äôs eyebrows jump in surprise. Eraser remains impassive. Likely, this is what he was waiting for, with that guarded look in his eyes.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt beat yourself up about it,‚Äù Mic says, brushing Izuku‚Äôs curls from his temples with gentle hands. His hair is lank with grease. How long has it been? ‚ÄúYou saved a lot of people that night. There‚Äôs nothing more you could have done.‚Äù

His hand, his words, are so tender and affectionate, and Izuku can‚Äôt stand it. Izuku waves him away. He is coiled too tightly to be touched, blood itching under his skin like it is trying to escape, like Izuku hasn‚Äôt already lost enough of it to the streets of Hosu. Mic doesn‚Äôt look as hurt by the rejection as Izuku would expect ‚Äî which is good, because he‚Äôs done nothing wrong, but it also means that they have been talking about him.

Which is normal. Of course they‚Äôve been talking about him. They‚Äôre his guardians, he‚Äôs in the hospital, his behavior has been‚Ä¶ erratic. Of course they talk about him, and of course Eraser warned Mic about Izuku‚Äôs mood. He is frustrated to find that the tension, the anger, that had been building inside him hasn‚Äôt dissipated while he slept.

Mic is right that Izuku is blaming himself, though entirely wrong about the validity and reasoning. There‚Äôs so much more Izuku could have done. Not for Hosu, at least not directly. He has no idea what his clones were getting up to after he left them, but he equipped them as best as he could, and from there he just had to trust their judgment. They weren‚Äôt really sentient, but they were reasonably sapient, and they would have proceeded according to Izuku‚Äôs intent when he made them: to help. Ten of them, with the quirks he gave them ‚Äî he‚Äôs certain they made a difference.

During the attack itself, Izuku did all he could. He pushed himself to breaking, and there‚Äôs nothing past that. There‚Äôs no more. He gave all he had. He just gave it to the wrong people. If only Izuku had had his priorities straight, Hosu never would have happened at all.

Here is what Izuku blames himself for: Tomura.

Izuku leaves him alone for six weeks, and his self-destructive idiot NEET of a brother goes and makes himself a fucking terrorist. The USJ ‚Äî Tomura probably could have come back from that. First documented offense. No deaths. Only two substantial injuries. This though? There was no coming back from this. How did Izuku let this happen? He‚Äôd gotten so caught up in this fantasy of redemption, of making friends, of having a life and being good, that he‚Äôd forgotten why he created this mess in the first place. This was always meant to be Tomura‚Äôs happy ending, but Izuku has hijacked the whole story.

What the fuck is Izuku doing? The last thing he did for his brother was fucking abandon him. Tomura is worse off than ever, and that is all Izuku‚Äôs fault. Killed his father-figure, left him behind, pushed him off the deep end. Went to play house with the heroes who never helped them. It is past time for Izuku to get his shit together and do something about this problem.

Acid climbs up his throat. He looks to Mic and Eraser.

Eraser must see something on Izuku‚Äôs face, and it must be alarming, because his mouth flattens out and he asks, ‚ÄúHow are you feeling?‚Äù

I hate you.

The words sit on the tip of Izuku‚Äôs tongue like something fiercely sour, and he wants so badly to spit them out. He doesn‚Äôt, because he knows he shouldn‚Äôt, knows that he‚Äôd regret it. He is just so angry. He is angry at Tomura, for doing something he can‚Äôt come back from. He is angry at himself, for letting it happen. He is angry at All for One, for being a shit father. He is angry at Mic and Eraser, for being good ones.

Why do they stay with Izuku while he sleeps? Why do they touch his hair and hold his hands? Why do they even care?

Why does Izuku let them? Why does he want them to?

Izuku‚Äôs eyes burn. His throat burns. His chest burns. This is immolation. It doesn‚Äôt feel nearly as good now as it did in that alley way. Izuku can‚Äôt breathe. That‚Äôs the thing about burning ‚Äî give it a bit of time, and it will suffocate you just as surely as drowning.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm feeling,‚Äù Izuku says, instead of any of the things inside his head.

‚ÄúTell them it‚Äôs a copy quirk. Call it Memorial.‚Äù

When Hitoshi smiles, Izuku smiles back.

Hizashi never thought he would. Izuku‚Äôs loss of control had never been a one-man job.

Atomize can reduce an object into fine particles. Through physical contract, large amounts of energy are disseminated from the user to the target, destroying it at a molecular level. It takes time to generate the energy required, resulting in a delay between initial contact and final activation, the exact length of which depends on the mass of the target ‚Äî and if this process is interrupted, the backlash on the user can be devastating. On paper, this makes Atomize a high stakes gamble, but in reality, the most dangerous applications of the quirk can be achieved so quickly that the risk of the user being interrupted is minimal. Every star in the universe balances on the precipice of utter annihilation.

For all that there are billions upon trillions of them, each and every star is a marvel. Not this time.

Izuku‚Äôs dream sticks with him like shrapnel. It seems like a miracle that he can look in the mirror and see no evidence of how it‚Äôs torn through him and lodged itself in his head. Rain falls in sheets, the sound of it melding together into a solid wall of rushing white noise. Wind cuts in at an angle that foils any hopes of protection an umbrella might have offered.

‚ÄúWe should just go back to sleep,‚Äù Aizawa says before they step outside, disdain written into the slump of his shoulders. Why couldn‚Äôt we just take a nap?

‚ÄúHe hates getting wet,‚Äù Mic tells Izuku conspiratorially. His good mood and bright grin defy the weather. ‚ÄúLike a‚Äî‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt.‚Äù

Cat, Mic mouths behind a hand, for Izuku‚Äôs eyes only. Aizawa shoulders past them into the rain with a hiss that only supports Mic‚Äôs assertions. Izuku laughs and jogs to catch up. Things are better when we do them together.

The driest person in class 1-A is, ironically, Tsu, who cheerfully tells Uraraka that she has a bright green, full-length raincoat and enjoys getting the opportunity to wear it. Shouto is half-wet half-dry, but doesn‚Äôt seem to mind ‚Äî not that it would be all that obvious if he did. ‚ÄúSet her on fire,‚Äù Kasumi demands. I‚Äôm not bothering them! Izuku drops his bag next to his desk and decides that he doesn‚Äôt want to wrangle the chaos that is about to unfold. 

Across the room, Aoyama lounges extravagantly atop his desk, drenched to the bone because he is apparently too fabulous for things like raincoats and umbrellas. His hair drips steadily onto the floor. Ashido circles around him, taking pictures on her phone from different angles as he strikes another pose. He starts shivering a moment later.

‚ÄúCome on,‚Äù Izuku says, stepping past Ashido, who grins at him and snaps a photo when he smiles back. He pulls Aoyama from his desk to his feet. ‚ÄúRecovery Girl will have a spare uniform you can change into.‚Äù I‚Äôll take care of you. They nearly run into Aizawa on their way out the door, and he presses himself ‚Äî sleeping bag and all ‚Äî flat against the wall to avoid contact.

Throughout his classes, Izuku is unsurprised to find that he can‚Äôt focus. The sudden lack of the pulsing anger that‚Äôs possessed him since Hosu is an incredible relief, but he nevertheless finds himself somewhat unsettled in its absence. Attempting to pay attention to his teachers while simultaneously trying to properly engage with the friends he has been neglecting feels like a juggling act, and with each ball Izuku drops, overwhelm creeps higher up his throat. You‚Äôll love me, then.

Leaving 1-A for his lesson with Nedzu is a reprieve that Izuku guiltily latches onto. Most of these lessons involve complex, mentally taxing exercises and conversations on all manner of subjects, but today, most of the period will be devoted to mathematics ‚Äî the one class Izuku is exempt from because he tested far enough below his peers to warrant remedial lessons. We have more important things to do. Normally, Izuku finds the math tutoring tedious, but today, he‚Äôs grateful not to have to think about anything more complicated than calculus.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure Shouta filled you in on the happenings of yesterday‚Äôs committee meeting?‚Äù Nedzu asks pleasantly shortly after giving Izuku the problem set that they‚Äôll be working through that day. Izuku nods, squinting at the equation at the top of the page. ‚ÄúOrder of operations,‚Äù Nedzu reminds. Izuku erases the number he had barely begun to write. ‚ÄúThankfully, the committee is firmly on your side. You know, Izuku, you really are quite charismatic.‚Äù

Izuku scrunches up his nose, erasing yet again as he realizes another mistake in the midst of making it. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt try to be.‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs why it works so well. It‚Äôs a good thing! Charm like that can be a useful tool. He cuts Nedzu a leery glance that Nedzu meets with a sparkling smile. Regardless of how civil and humane a mask he wears, his teeth always reveal the predator he is at his core. ‚ÄúWith the quirks at your disposal, and your skills besides, there‚Äôs quite a lot that you could get away with.‚Äù You can‚Äôt just take whatever you want.

‚ÄúGet away with?‚Äù Izuku echoes after a long, incredulous pause. ‚ÄúLike what?‚Äù

‚ÄúOh,‚Äù Nedzu says lightly, pressing his paws together. Izuku feels hunted. ‚ÄúAny number of things, really.‚Äù Of course I can.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt‚Äî I‚Äôm not going to do anything like that.‚Äù I don‚Äôt want to do those things. Nedzu hasn‚Äôt made a secret of his social and political aspirations for Izuku. Many of his motives for teaching Izuku are aggressively reformist, but none of them are ulterior. Or maybe he simply hides more than Izuku realized, and trusts less than Izuku thought.

‚ÄúI never said you were,‚Äù Nedzu agrees, in the default chipper tone that makes it impossible to  get a read on his real meaning, ‚Äúbut it‚Äôs not a crime to consider the possibilities. ‚ÄúI won‚Äôt‚Äî‚Äù Izuku cuts himself off before he can get to his actual denial. What was he supposed to say that wouldn‚Äôt be a lie? He won‚Äôt do anything he shouldn‚Äôt do? He won‚Äôt break the law? It‚Äôs too late for that. Hasn‚Äôt he just recently acknowledged that something needs to be done? What will you do, then?

‚ÄúWon‚Äôt what?‚Äù Nedzu prompts, feigning ignorance so well that Izuku could nearly buy it, if he believed that true ignorance was something Nedzu had ever experienced.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm stuck on question three,‚Äù Izuku says. Nedzu clicks his tongue, an odd sound given the shape of his mouth, and leans forward to teach Izuku more socially acceptable things. The devious sparkle in his eyes never dims.

Lunch brings a second chance for the respite that Izuku had hoped to find in Nedzu‚Äôs office. The break begins immediately after their lesson, which makes it easy for Izuku to evade the grasp of his friends, even if he feels horrible for doing it. I don‚Äôt feel good. He just‚Äî he needs space. You‚Äôre always tired. He needs room to think, to make sense of all these thoughts that don‚Äôt feel like his own, to process the ghosts that are sitting so heavily on his shoulders, whispering into his ears.

Let‚Äôs go on an adventure. You‚Äôll love me, then. It‚Äôs too late for that. I‚Äôm already gone. Does it hurt? Doesn‚Äôt everyone?

The idea of being alone is suddenly intolerable, but Izuku barely registers that as a problem before he is already seeking out the solution. Hitoshi slouches, but his hair still sticks out of the crowd. He doesn‚Äôt respond to Izuku‚Äôs shout, and for a moment, Izuku wonders despairingly if he is being avoided, again. Where are you going? Then, Izuku remembers how quickly Hitoshi had said, ‚ÄúWe are, we‚Äôre friends,‚Äù and he remembers how easy it was to believe. Hitoshi isn‚Äôt avoiding Izuku; Hitoshi is just a stubborn misanthrope who doesn‚Äôt expect anyone to seek him out.

Izuku slips through the crowd to dart into Hitoshi‚Äôs path, grabbing him above the elbows before they can collide. Held at arm‚Äôs length, Hitoshi jolts to a stop. In the moment he glances up, the look on his face is absolutely biting, but his sneer falls slack the instant his eyes meets Izuku‚Äôs.

‚ÄúWhat do you want?‚Äù Hitoshi asks, expression hardening into vague suspicion while he removes one earbud. ‚ÄúIs this about yesterday? Have you come for your revenge?‚Äù

‚ÄúNot revenge,‚Äù Izuku denies. ‚ÄúLunch.‚Äù Things are better when we do them together.

Hitoshi‚Äôs expression flattens. ‚ÄúHuh,‚Äù he says, maybe a bit nonplussed, from what little Izuku can read in his tone. He unplugs his headphones, ears reddening gradually as he winds the cord around his hand.

Hitoshi puts up token resistance ‚Äî Izuku would expect nothing less ‚Äî but he doesn‚Äôt make Izuku drag him, and he doesn‚Äôt ask any questions, even when Izuku leads them away from the cafeteria. There aren‚Äôt any windows in Izuku‚Äôs favorite hiding place, but the noise of the rain reaches them, echoing in the small, dark room when he shuts the door behind them. He still has access to his night vision quirk, but he has spent so much time here that he doesn‚Äôt need it to navigate through stacks of books and boxes to the back of the room, where an old desk has been pushed against the wall. By feel, he locates and switches on the lamp he knows to be there.

‚Äú‚Ä¶Did you drag me into a closet?‚Äù Hitoshi asks, looking around the small, cluttered space. Izuku frowns at him, pushing a chair in his direction with a bit more force than necessary. Hitoshi grabs the back of it before it can bump into his shins and wheels it back towards Izuku, who takes a seat, legs crossed on top of the desk.

‚ÄúNo! It used to be someone‚Äôs office, I think.‚Äù Hitoshi sits, kicks his feet up next to Izuku‚Äôs knee, and shoots Izuku a dubious look. Izuku sighs. ‚ÄúThey have maybe been using it as a closet,‚Äù he admits.

‚ÄúWhy are we in a closet?‚Äù

‚ÄúI figured you‚Äôd be more comfortable, here.‚Äù

‚ÄúIn a closet?‚Äù Hitoshi repeats. His ears are turning red again, though it‚Äôs not as obvious in the dim lamplight as it was under the fluorescents in the hallway. ‚ÄúWhat are you trying to say?‚Äù

‚ÄúW-we can go somewhere else, if you want?‚Äù Izuku offers. ‚ÄúThis is where I come when I need to, uh,‚Äù Izuku grimaces and rushes through his next words, ‚Äúavoid my friends. ‚ÄúHuh,‚Äù Hitoshi says.

‚ÄúI‚Äî I wasn‚Äôt really feeling super up to the whole p-people thing today, either, so.‚Äù I‚Äôm tired.

‚ÄúOh.‚Äù

‚ÄúI had‚Äî I had a really weird dream last night,‚Äù Izuku finds himself volunteering, much to his own surprise. He closes his teeth around the tip of his tongue. He didn‚Äôt mean to share that. ‚ÄúOh?‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah,‚Äù Hitoshi nods, unexpectedly invested in the turn of the conversation, his brows drawing together as he seems to gather his recollection, ‚Äúit was‚Äî my dad had decided to become a hero, I guess to support me or some shit? ‚ÄúThat bastard,‚Äù Izuku intones. Classes come to an end. Izuku gives his friends an over-due apology. ‚ÄúDo you love me?‚Äù Izuku asks in the middle of dinner, apropos of nothing, one of the many questions that‚Äôs been chewing on him all day. ‚ÄúOf course!‚Äù he replies immediately.

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù Aizawa says, similarly unhesitating. His eyes, though, when they meet Izuku‚Äôs, are sharper, contemplative as opposed to Mic‚Äôs guileless affection. Izuku swallows. ‚ÄúIs it supposed to hurt?‚Äù he asks, voice rasping through the sudden tightness of his throat.

Mic‚Äôs bright grin flips into a mild frown. ‚ÄúWell,‚Äù he hedges, ‚ÄúI wouldn‚Äôt say it‚Äôs supposed to, but it always does. It‚Äôs too important not to hurt at least some of the time.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat if it‚Äôs all of the time?‚Äù

‚ÄúThen maybe it‚Äôs better to let go,‚Äù Mic says, so gently, talking around their shared awareness that this not hypothetical. ‚ÄúAnd being with someone you love doesn‚Äôt always mean being happy,‚Äù Aizawa adds.

You‚Äôll fight me? asks one of the ghosts in Izuku‚Äôs head.

Do you love me? Yes.

Until the end, replies the other.

Does it hurt? More than anything.

That‚Äôs just another kind of together, says the first, and with those six words, it‚Äôs too late for them. Together, in the way of two nameless brothers on opposite sides of each other‚Äôs stories, their love defined by the suffering it inspired.

Is it worth it?

Later, Izuku lays in the dark and stares at the ceiling above his bed. Lucy purrs on his chest, sleeping the unburdened sleep of a creature that is has never had to make a choice important enough to worry about making the wrong one.

Sometimes, though, there is no right or wrong choice. Sometimes, right and wrong has nothing to do with it.

Is it worth it?

Izuku picks his phone up off the side table, fingers tingling as the screen lights up beneath them. In this day and age, technological quirks are a powerful thing, and that‚Äôs precisely the reason his father made sure to give Izuku several. He has a general idea of what they all do, of course, but Izuku‚Äôs inherent awareness of quirks doesn‚Äôt tell him how they actually work. Nedzu has taught Izuku a lot, though. At least enough for him to be smart in how he goes about making a very dumb decision.

Is it worth it?

‚ÄúYes,‚Äù Izuku says aloud.

Sometimes, when no one does right by you, two wrongs are the best you'll get. Izuku makes a choice that he can live with, and he sets his phone aside.
